headline: Attack Kills One at Meeting Of Opposition in Bangladesh
abstract: LEAD: Attackers threw bombs and sprayed gunfire at members of an opposition party who were meeting today, killing one person and wounding more than a dozen, the police and witnesses said.

headline: German Factory Orders
abstract: LEAD: Orders for industrial goods in West Germany rose 7.4 percent in August, but economists were not sure if the official figures signaled a rebound in the most powerful West European economy. The Federal Statistics Office today attributed the rise partly to strong demand for machinery and electrical engineering goods.

headline: Market Place; High Fliers That Plunged
abstract: LEAD: WHILE the stock market seems to be holding its own, some individual issues have taken stunning drubbings in recent weeks.

headline: Gorbachev Mix On TV Is Tough But Cooperative
abstract: LEAD: In a prelude to next week's summit meeting in Washington, Mikhail S. Gorbachev went on American television today in a mixed posture of conciliation and toughness.

headline: Jury to Ponder Tax Shelters
abstract: LEAD: Charles A. Atkins, the New York financier accused of engineering one of the largest illegal tax shelter conspiracies in history, was described by prosecutors yesterday as a man who descended into a ''world of fraud'' because of his own ''greed and lies.''

headline: Britain Sees 4% Growth
abstract: LEAD: Britain's economy will grow about 4 percent this year despite the recent stock market plunge, but growth may slow to 2.5 percent in 1988, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, said today.

headline: Wall Street Reviews 'Wall Street'
abstract: LEAD: For many investment banking luminaries at a private screening of ''Wall Street'' on Monday night, watching the new film was like watching home movies.

headline: International Report; Swiftly Rising Prices Alarm China's Leaders
abstract: LEAD: There is a new ugly word in China: inflation.

headline: Pakistani Persecution Charged
abstract: LEAD: The spiritual leader of the Ahmadi Moslem sect, on a visit to the United States, has blamed the Government of Pakistan and some Moslem clergymen there for what he calls ''the continuing legalized persecution'' of the Ahmadis in Pakistan, where the sect is concentrated.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  International

headline: Salvador Acts to Prosecute Rightist Tied to Killing
abstract: LEAD: A court began proceedings today to strip a rightist political leader, Roberto d'Aubuisson, of legal immunity that would protect him from prosecution for the 1980 killing of the Roman Catholic Archbishop of El Salvador, the Salvadoran Justice Minister said.

headline: ELIE WIESEL IN PLEA TO GERMANS
abstract: LEAD: Speaking, he said, from the ''very rostrum'' from which his death and that of his people were ''decreed and predicted,'' Elie Wiesel, chronicler of the Nazi crimes, appealed to German youths today to ''fight forgetfulness'' about their past.

headline: Firestone Reorganizing Into Three Divisions
abstract: LEAD: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that its board had approved a reorganization that will establish a parent company and divide its operations into three independent subsidiaries.

headline: A Leading Chinese Dissident Is Freed After 6 Years in Jail
abstract: LEAD: A prominent dissident active in the Democracy Wall movement in the late 1970's has been freed after a six-year jail term, Chinese sources said today.

headline: Import Quotas
abstract: LEAD: An international trade tribunal has ruled that some Japanese import quotas on food are illegal, and the United States is expected to use the ruling to put pressure on Tokyo to end other farm-trade barriers, American trade officials said today. The ruling by a three-member panel established by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade was said to have been quietly conveyed to Tokyo and Washington this week.

headline: Turner, Time And NBC Meet
abstract: LEAD: Top officials of NBC, the Turner Broadcasting System and Time Inc. met in New York yesterday to discuss NBC's possible investment in Turner Broadcasting, according to executives at the companies.

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi Wins Two $10 Million Billings
abstract: LEAD: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, New York, won two pieces of business yesterday, each of which bills a healthy $10 million. One is Fruit Corners from General Mills. The other is Little Caesars Pizza, the largest pizza take-out chain in America.

headline: AT LAST, HELP ON THE CROSSWORD PUZZLE
abstract: LEAD: A crossword puzzle solver trying to figure out an eight-letter word whose second letter is ''u'' and fifth letter ''d'' might once have been in a quandary. But help is now at hand. A new electronic spelling checker resembling a large handheld calculator can instantly retrieve words that fit a given pattern.

headline: France's Deficit In Trade Grows
abstract: LEAD: The Trade Ministry of France reported today that the nation's trade deficit doubled last month to 4.9 billion francs, or $860 million, from September.

headline: Economic Scene History as a Guide In Difficult Times
abstract: LEAD: DESPITE the steep fall of stock markets around the world, the standard forecast of official and private economists in the United States, Europe and Japan is that 1988 will be a year of slow growth but no recession or depression -which, if true, constitutes a blessing.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Issues Dip in Price
abstract: LEAD: Prices of short- and long-term debt securities fell modestly yesterday as market participants continued to expect that a strong economy and a more restrictive Federal Reserve policy would lead to higher interest rates.

headline: Ex-Viacom Officer Joins Aaron Spelling
abstract: LEAD: Jules Haimovitz, one of a group of managers who attempted a leveraged buyout of Viacom International Inc., yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of Aaron Spelling Productions Inc. in Los Angeles.

headline: Vote on Unesco Chief Delayed by a Wrangle
abstract: LEAD: The executive boad of Unesco put off voting on a new Director General today, as the board's factions wrangled over election procedures.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Stock Market Turmoil

headline: Big Money Fund Influx
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 412 money market mutual funds increased $2.45 billion, to $260.52 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 112 institutional funds were up $2.47 billion, to $73 billion. Assets of the 207 general purpose funds were up $61.2 million, to $79.41 billion.

headline: Two Tell of Harsh Captivity in Beirut
abstract: LEAD: The hostages spent months chained to a wall, told to keep silent in the solitude of their dark, windowless rooms. They were treated, one of them said, ''like an animal, like a dog,'' often not able to get a drink, to wash, to go to the bathroom. They saw only masked gunmen.

headline: Amoco Profit Up Sharply
abstract: LEAD: The Amoco Corporation reported yesterday that its third-quarter profits were $412 million, or $1.60 a share, a substantial improvement over the comparable quarter last year, primarily because of higher crude oil prices.

headline: Hawaii Bonds
abstract: LEAD: Hawaii's $80 million of general obligation bonds were offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.80 percent in 1990 to 6.75 percent in 1997 and 7.70 percent in 2007 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The bonds are rated Aa by Moody's and AA by S.&P.

headline: CHINESE CURFEW IN THE TIBET CAPITAL
abstract: LEAD: The Chinese authorities imposed a curfew today and tried to stop at least one busload of foreign tourists from leaving this Tibetan capital after pro-independence demonstrations in which at least six people were reported killed.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN SNACK FOOD
abstract: LEAD: IN the battle for the allegiance of taste buds, snack food makers have been caught in the crossfire between the consumer's desire for something old (read comforting) yet new (meaning fast, different-tasting and preferably nutritious). ''Snack foods are life-style driven,'' said Mona Doyle, president of the Consumer Network, a consumer research company.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.75   8.75   7.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.69   N.A.   6.03        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.63   N.A.   5.38        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.20   6.14   5.41        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.88   N.A.   6.96        30-YR.

headline: Sinai Reported To Weigh Shift
abstract: LEAD: Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers, whose views have commanded a wide following, is considering a new position at Shearson that, some sources at the firm say, may resemble an independent consulting arrangement.

headline: Arkla Will Buy Entex in Swap
abstract: LEAD: Entex Inc., a natural gas distribution company in Houston, has agreed to be purchased by Arkla Inc. in a stock transaction valued at $25.30 a share, or $572 million.

headline: Bond Activity Suggests Rate Cuts
abstract: LEAD: Ten weeks after the steep decline in stock prices on Oct. 19, credit market participants are still guessing about the likely effects on consumer spending, the economy and interest rates.

headline: Patents; Students Honored For Inventions
abstract: LEAD: Schoolchildren are being honored for their inventions in a program started a year ago by President Reagan and supported by Federal agencies. Each winner, chosen as the best inventor of his or her grade level in the state, will receive a $200 savings bond, and the teachers and schools will receive larger grants.

headline: 5 Reagan-Gorbachev Sessions Are Planned in Summit Talks
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan's summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev will include five direct meetings as well as a state dinner at the White House, the Administration announced today.

headline: Tribune's New Defense
abstract: LEAD: Directors of the Tribune Company, trying to make the diversified publishing and broadcasting conglomerate a less attractive takeover target, have approved a more bitter ''poison pill'' contingency plan.

headline: Shultz Is Expected to Meet Shevardnadze Next Week
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet next week in Geneva with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, to resolve remaining differences on a missile treaty and to review the agenda for the summit meeting next month, Reagan Administration officials said today.

headline: Midi Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: The Department of Trade and Industry in Britain has cleared the way for the takeover of the British life insurance concern Equity and Law by the French financial services group Compagnie du Midi, the French company said. The decision marks the end of the first takeover battle for a big British life insurance concern since the 1960's.

headline: Mexican Ambivalence
abstract: LEAD: Repeatedly over the last seven years, the Reagan Administration has expressed hopes of creating a North American common market that would link the United States and its neighbors. But in concluding a bilateral commercial accord here on Friday, Mexico and the United States showed that an enormous gap remains between that dream and current reality.

headline: Government Clears British Air Merger
abstract: LEAD: British Airways, Britain's biggest airline, received the Government's conditional approval today to acquire British Caledonian Airways, the No. 2 carrier.

headline: Reports of Psychiatry Abuse Counter Talk of a Soviet Shift
abstract: LEAD: A political dissident recently released from a Soviet psychiatric hospital said today that the habitual use of punitive psychiatric treatment in the Soviet Union remained unchanged despite recent criticisms of such practices in the Soviet press.

headline: STABILIZING THE CURRENCY: Peg the Dollar's Value to Commodities
abstract: LEAD: MAINTAINING the stable purchasing power of a currency is the key policy objective of any central bank. Recently, Secretary of the Treasury James A. Baker 3d called for the use of a broad commodity basket, including gold, as an indicator to be used in the monetary policy formulation process.

headline: U.S. Outpost Feels Threat Of Budget Ax
abstract: LEAD: What malaria, murder and green mamba snakes could not achieve, Washington's new spirit of cutting budgets may soon accomplish in this island capital in the Atlantic.

headline: Copter Crashes in Colombia
abstract: LEAD: Two American soldiers were injured when their Army CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed and burned Friday in Colombia, the Pentagon said today. The helicopter's pilot reported engine failure while it was returning to its base in Panama from a refueling mission. The soldiers suffered first- and second-degree burns over about 30 percent of their bodies when the Chinook crashed near the city of Monteria, Colombia, the Pentagon said.

headline: U.S. TV BROADCASTS BANNED BBC DATA
abstract: LEAD: Portions of a television documentary barred in Britain on security grounds have been shown to American audiences on two occasions in recent days.

headline: I.B.M. Moves Up OS/2 Shipping Date
abstract: LEAD: Putting an end to months of speculation, the International Business Machines Corporation said today that it would begin to ship the first release of its OS/2, the next generation of its personal computer operating system, in December, a few months ahead of schedule.

headline: How Commodity Indicator Works
abstract: LEAD: As an example of how today's proposal to stabilize currencies would work, interest rates would rise if prices for commodities, including gold, move higher.

headline: U.S. Oil Rigs Fall by 22
abstract: LEAD: The number of oil drilling rigs operating in the United States fell by 22, to 1,152, in the latest week but was still above the 952 working in the comparable week a year ago, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.

headline: Ford Payment In South Africa
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company's former subsidiary in South Africa confirmed that it had received about 200 million rand, or about $103 million, from the American auto maker as part of its disinvestment arrangement. Leslie Boyd, chairman of the

headline: The U.N. Today: Dec. 7, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: Your Money; Yields Stressed By Investors
abstract: LEAD: DAVID PEARL, a New York apparel manufacturer, has been selling some of his stocks since the steep October market decline. ''I decided to redirect my allocation of assets that were geared toward growth into income-oriented securities,'' he said. ''You look for some security.''

headline: Peru Bank Still Closed
abstract: LEAD: Peru's largest private bank, the Banco de Credito, remained closed today as employees refused to cooperate with Government administrators sent in under a bank expropriation law. Luis Nieri, the bank's institutional relations manager, said employees were back at their desks after a two-day closure ordered by the administrators but were refusing to work.

headline: Loss at MCO And Maxxam
abstract: LEAD: Two companies controlled by the Houston investor Charles E. Hurwitz said today that the stock market's steep decline since the beginning of October had resulted in $33.8 million in losses, which would adversely affect both concerns' fourth-quarter results.

headline: Opposition Politician Seized by Malaysians
abstract: LEAD: The Government announced today the detention without trial of another member of the opposition Democratic Action Party.

headline: Advertising; Carter-Wallace to Offer College Health Message
abstract: LEAD: Carter-Wallace, whose product line includes Trojan condoms, will be sponsoring two- to three-minute public service video messages reaching college campuses, intended to inform students on the diseases that threaten them, from AIDS to anorexia, according to the announcement.

headline: HIGH-LEVEL MOONLIGHTER: Charles E. Hugel; Tackling the Top Job at Two Companies
abstract: LEAD: LAST month, when RJR-Nabisco named as its chairman Charles E. Hugel, Combustion Engineering's chief executive, eyebrows shot up throughout the business community. Why, people asked, would an Atlanta consumer products company pick an Easterner who has no packaged goods experience, has never worked for RJR, and has his hands full running a $2.7 billion company some 900 miles away?

headline: ASIANS END TALKS IN MOOD OF RELIEF
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia put into words today the relief felt at the uneventful end of a two-day meeting of six Southeast Asian leaders, a gathering held reluctantly and with unusually tight security in this volatile capital.

headline: Marine Bank Chief Named
abstract: LEAD: In a move that was expected by analysts, the Marine Midland Bank said that Geoffrey A. Thompson, its president, would take on the additional role of chief executive. Mr. Thompson, 47 years old, replaces John R. Petty, 57, who will continue as chairman of the bank and the chairman and chief executive of its holding company.

headline: A GENERAL STRIKE BY ISRAEL'S ARABS DISRUPTS COUNTRY
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of thousands of Arabs inside Israel joined others in the occupied territories today in a general strike protesting Israel's handling of a wave of protests.

headline: Mozambique Downs Plane
abstract: LEAD: Armed forces shot down an unidentified plane near Mozambique's border with Malawi on Friday, Maputo radio said today. The radio quoted military sources as saying the plane was violating the country's airspace about 10 miles from Malawi's western border. The radio said the authorities were still trying to identify the plane.

headline: Iraqi Jets Strike 5 Tankers; 2 Iran Missiles Hit Baghdad
abstract: LEAD: Iraqi planes struck five tankers, one of them the world's largest, in raids Monday, on Iranian oil targets at both ends of the Persian Gulf, and Iran fired two a missiles into Baghdad, one Monday and one early today, for the first time in nearly eight months.

headline: Stake Is Raised In Crazy Eddie
abstract: LEAD: An investment group consisting of Entertainment Marketing Inc. and Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P., disclosed that it had raised its stake in Crazy Eddie Inc. to 15.6 percent, from 14.6 percent.

headline: Many Wary on Impact Of B.P. Offering Now
abstract: LEAD: Britain's planned sale on Friday of its 31.5 percent stake in the giant British Petroleum Company is creating concern among international financiers that the offering could set off another dramatic plunge in the London stock market.

headline: A DEPRESSED MEXICO TURNS TO ENTREPRENEURS
abstract: LEAD: Long a country run from the top down and from the center outward, Mexico has begun awakening to the advantages of encouraging the development of independent, small-scale private enterprise.

headline: The Monthly Trade Figures: A Closely Watched Barometer
abstract: LEAD: The monthly trade figures have become a litmus test of sorts for the health of the overall United States economy. This is why investors and traders in all the financial markets pay so much attention to the report - and, correspondingly, why the prices of stocks and bonds and the value of the dollar in relation to other major currencies can rise or fall, depending on how the actual figures stack up against expectations.

headline: Belgium's Jobless Rate
abstract: LEAD: Belgium's unemployment rate fell to 12.1 percent in October, from 12.2 percent in September, the National Labor Office said today. Belgium's jobless rate is one of the highest in the European Community, surpassed only by Ireland and Italy.

headline: Careers; Job Plight Of Middle Managers
abstract: LEAD: THE plight of middle managers who are at least 50 years old and face dismissal because companies are reducing staffs continues to be sad.

headline: Korea Suspects Bomb Downed Jet
abstract: LEAD: A missing South Korean passenger plane was reported today to have crashed in the jungle along the Thai-Burmese border, and the airline president said a terrorist's bomb was the most likely cause.

headline: British Put Off B.P. Decision
abstract: LEAD: The British Government, facing mounting pressure politically and from financial markets, said today that it would wait until Thursday to decide whether to postpone the $12.2 billion sale of British Petroleum Company shares.

headline: Queen Pleads for Ulster Peace
abstract: LEAD: Queen Elizabeth II made a Christmas plea today for an end to the intolerance and violence that have led to acts like a recent Irish Republican Army bombing that killed 11 people.

headline: Palestinian Riots Hit Jerusalem; Banks Attacked and Roads Seized
abstract: LEAD: Palestinian rioting spread to Jerusalem today, with crowds of rock-throwing youths attacking Israeli-owned banks and taking over the streets of the Arab district for hours.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1987
abstract: LEAD: Markets

headline: Fed Backs Regulatory Umbrella
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board today supported the creation of an umbrella agency to more closely coordinate policy among the major Government bodies that regulate financial institutions.

headline: Standard Brands Recapitalization
abstract: LEAD: The Standard Brands Paint Company, which rejected a takeover bid last month, said it had begun a $193 million recapitalization plan that would increase the company's debt and adopted a poison-pill style shareholder rights plan to deter an unfriendly takeover.

headline: Soviet Says Special Push Is Needed in Arms Treaty
abstract: LEAD: Senior Soviet officials said today that high-level attention would be required to resolve remaining technical differences in a treaty to eliminate intermediate range missiles.

headline: TEXACO REPORTED TO REACH ACCORD ON PENNZOIL SUIT
abstract: LEAD: A tumultuous four-year legal battle that pitted the Pennzoil Company against the giant Texaco Inc. was brought to a conclusion last night when Texaco agreed in principle to give Pennzoil $3 billion, a lawyer for Texaco said.

headline: New Attack on Iranian Nuclear Plant Is Reported
abstract: LEAD: Iran said today that Iraqi warplanes had raided an unfinished nuclear power plant for the second time this week, and Iraq said it bombed three tankers in Iran's waters and shot down two enemy planes.

headline: Regain Leadership by Working Together
abstract: LEAD: ONLY a few years ago I used to brag about how the American electronics industry single-handedly kept the United States trade balance positive. Over the past year or so, my little joke soured. Last year, the United States imported $13.5 billion more in electronics products than it exported.

headline: Putting Faith in Madison Avenue
abstract: LEAD: THREE men, one black, one white and one Hispanic, are pictured above the line ''We Want to Collar a Few Good Men.'' A young man strolls down a darkened hospital corridor puzzling over his career while a narrator says, ''The work is hard but the rewards are infinite.'' At first glance they seem like just another series of recruitment ads for the armed forces.

headline: Two Dead of Radiation in Brazil
abstract: LEAD: A 6-year-old girl and her aunt have died of radiation poisoning, becoming the first fatalities in a radiation accident last month that contaminated at least 243 people, officials said.

headline: Two Accept Challenge Of Ailing Crazy Eddie
abstract: LEAD: Unlike other turnaround specialists, who tend to stick to healing ailing companies in one industry, Victor H. Palmieri takes a more catholic approach to the recovery game.

headline: Sudan Is Said to Talk With Leaders of Rebels
abstract: LEAD: The Khartoum Government held secret peace talks in London this month with representatives of the rebel army fighting in the southern Sudan, officials said today.

headline: American Greetings Rewards President
abstract: LEAD: Morry Weiss, president of the American Greetings Corporation, has been named to the additional position of chief executive, the company said yesterday.

headline: Sottomarina Journal; The Waters, Befouled, 'Cry Out for Vengeance'
abstract: LEAD: All summer long this year the Adriatic was hot and languid and getting sicker by the day. Eventually, one little part of the sea almost died when pollutants dumped by the Po River helped kill nearly all the fish in an area of nearly 400 square miles.

headline: 'A BUSINESSOF SECONDS'
abstract: LEAD: LIKE their counterparts in instant publishing, executives who produce instant video cassettes tend to describe themselves as high-stakes gamblers.

headline: HAITIAN ELECTIONS FEARED IMPERILED
abstract: LEAD: Two weeks before Haiti is supposed to have its first presidential election in 30 years, the place designated as national election headquarters is still filled with carpenters and the racket of hammers and power saws.

headline: Sandinistas and Contras Accused of Rights Abuses
abstract: LEAD: ''Ongoing and serious human rights violations'' have resulted from the Nicaraguan Government's continued use of tribunals outside the regular court system to try people accused of national security offenses, a New York-based human rights organization has charged in a report.

headline: NEW MIDEAST PLAN DISCUSSED BY U.S., ISRAEL AND JORDAN
abstract: LEAD: Israel, Jordan and the United States are discussing a new proposal for Middle East peace talks in which Jordan and Israel would negotiate directly under the joint auspices of Moscow and Washington, a senior Israeli official said today.

headline: Advertising; New Blair President
abstract: LEAD: It takes a special sort of guy with a special sort of dedication - or greed - to desert Tampa, Fla., for Rochester as the winter begins to bare its icy talons. Just that sort of man is Edmond C. Froehlich, 41 years old, who has left behind Young & Rubicam/ Zemp, where he was president and chief executive, to join Blair Advertising, one of the Omnicom Group, as president and chief operating officer.

headline: Don't Forget to Dust the House
abstract: LEAD: IT may not be nice to fool Mother Nature but it can be profitable. In 1986, the Weyerhaeuser Company of Tacoma, Wash., purchased the United States patent rights to a process invented in Sweden 10 years ago in which certain types of plants and trees are ''interiorized'' - that is, preserved in their natural state for many years.

headline: Trial Is Set On E.S.M.
abstract: LEAD: A Federal district judge today scheduled for June 13 the trial of a lawsuit by the trustee for E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. against Marvin Warner intended to recover assets lost during the collapse of E.S.M.

headline: MacGregor to Sell Three Companies
abstract: LEAD: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc. said it had agreed to sell three of its businesses to the Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P. for up to $73.5 million. The partnership would pay $63.5 million for Chicago-based Riddell Inc., which makes and markets football helmets and accessories; the Sports Specialties Corporation, a distributor of licensed sports caps, and the Equilink Licensing Corporation, a licensor of the MacGregor trademark.

headline: Bozell, Jacobs Head Sees Mega-Agency Decline
abstract: LEAD: Interestingly enough, Charles D. Peebler Jr., chief executive of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, chose yesterday to predict the decline of the mega-agencies, with Saatchi & Saatchi leading the way.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allegis Corp., Chicago, has completed the divestiture of its Hertz Corp. car-rental subsidiary for $1.3 billion.

headline: No Tax Shift Seen by Baker
abstract: LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today that President Reagan remains firmly opposed to any new taxes and that any legislation to increase taxes could lead the nation into a recession.

headline: House Bars Embassy Relocation
abstract: LEAD: The House today turned aside an effort to require the Soviet Union to abandon its new embassy on a hilltop overlooking Washington and find a site less suited to electronic eavesdropping.

headline: A State Dinner for the Gorbachevs: Front-Row Seat on World History
abstract: LEAD: President and Mrs. Reagan invited a cross-section of America - 126 stars of business, science, sports, politics and the arts - to the White House state dinner this evening in honor of Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa.

headline: In Saigon '87, Ho, Ho, Ho, Ho Chi Minh
abstract: LEAD: At the Dong Khanh Bakery in Cholon the other day, the pastry chefs got to work on the first of the season's traditional French Christmas logs.

headline: Leader of Uprising Captured in Manila
abstract: LEAD: The colonel who led an August coup attempt was captured today in a raid on a Manila townhouse and will face ''due process of law,'' the military said.

headline: New Violence Rocks Haiti as Vote Nears
abstract: LEAD: With the Haitian presidential election six days away, a new wave of violence apparently intended to disrupt the voting swept through the capital today.

headline: Italy Presses Case Against Vatican Bank Officials
abstract: LEAD: The Italian magistrates investigating the Vatican bank scandal remain determined to prosecute an American Archbishop despite a court ruling in July that declared him beyond their juridiction, judicial officials say.

headline: PATENTS; Image Displays
abstract: LEAD: A new technique for the assembly of images and their immediate display was patented this week for Computer Graphics Laboratories Inc. of New York. Patent No. 4,700,181 was awarded to Stephen Maine, Duncan Harrower and Abraham Mammen. The principal use is to overlay images on a display screen. The technique can free store owners, for example, from keeping an inventory of all the items they want to sell.

headline: Editors' Note
abstract: LEAD: An article on Sept. 10 described the withdrawal of an 80-page proposal for a book by Joan Braden and Les Whitten. The proposal promised a book of reminiscences by Mrs. Braden, the Washington social figure, and accounts of capital intrigues, amorous and otherwise. The Times's article said Mrs. Braden accused Mr.

headline: S.E.C. Files Payout Plan On Levine
abstract: LEAD: Dennis B. Levine's insider-trading activities in 54 companies over a five-year period have led a myriad of investors, corporate acquirers and creditors to assert they have been injured by his illegal use of confidential information.

headline: Alaska Air and Pepsi Are Winners at Festival
abstract: LEAD: When the names of the winners of the best TV campaign and best TV commercial were read at the International Film and TV Festival of New York on Friday, it was just like old times.

headline: Seabrook Utility Formulating Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire is formulating a capital restructuring plan that would give the majority of its common stock to the holders of unsecured debt, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company said it could not predict that the restructuring could be achieved ''on a timely basis'' or before it might be forced into bankruptcy.

headline: Despite Soviet Move, Jews Will Protest in Capital
abstract: LEAD: Calling the Soviet Union's announcement that it would approve the emigration requests of 60 to 75 people only a good-will gesture, leaders of American Jewish organizations said yesterday that they would not be deterred from going ahead with a rally tomorrow in Washington on behalf of Soviet Jews.

headline: Former Belfast Councilman Critically Hurt in a Shooting
abstract: LEAD: A former Protestant city councilman who once said Roman Catholics should be burned was shot in the head and critically wounded today, the police said.

headline: Icahn to Get Big Block Of Texaco
abstract: LEAD: Trans World Airlines Inc. agreed yesterday to pay $348 million for 12 million shares of Texaco stock and the voting rights of an additional 12.1 million shares.

headline: Europe Inflation Slows
abstract: LEAD: Consumer prices in the European Community edged up two-tenths of a percent in November, a much smaller increase than October's five-tenths of a percent, the community's statistics office, Eurostat, said today. It said the community's inflation rate for the year should come to a modest 3.4 percent, up from last year's 2.9 percent.

headline: Superpowers And the Gulf
abstract: LEAD: After a period of competitive maneuvering over the war in the Persian Gulf, the United States and the Soviet Union seem on the verge of some wary diplomatic cooperation in moving toward a Security Council resolution imposing an arms embargo on Iran. But some uncertainties lie ahead.

headline: Gephardt Defends Trade Plan
abstract: LEAD: As members of Congress flee from trade bill provisions with any hint of protectionism in the wake of the stock market tumble, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, who has made such measures a centerpiece of his Presidential campaign, said today that he was holding firm.

headline: 'Star Wars' Isn't Tied To Pact, Reagan Says
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would never give up plans to develop the ''Star Wars'' space-based missile defense system to achieve a strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

headline: 'We're Going to Vote Anyway, 'Haitians Insist
abstract: LEAD: By nightfall, the streets of this city rapidly drain of their bustle and traffic, giving way to an eerie stillness, as Haitians abandon public places to avoid the violent death that each night claims more victims.

headline: Across U.S., Anxiety Without Panic
abstract: LEAD: It was the talk of grocery shoppers like Maria Lacombe at the Lucky Store in Madera, Calif., and of customers like Carl Schobinger, in for a haircut at Hanna's Barbershop in Watford City, N.D.

headline: Industrial Capacity Is Up to 81.3%
abstract: LEAD: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 81.3 percent of capacity in October, the highest operating rate in more than three years, the Government reported today.

headline: For MCI, a Return to Health
abstract: LEAD: A year ago, things could not have been worse for the MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company, and its chairman, William G. McGowan.

headline: Japan's New Cabinet Gets Old Face
abstract: LEAD: Noboru Takeshita was elected Japan's 17th postwar Prime Minister today, and he immediately formed a Government bearing the stamp of his predecessor in top positions.

headline: Prince Weighs Cambodia Talks
abstract: LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk is planning to travel to France this week amid reports that he may meet there before the end of the year with Cambodia's Prime Minister, a spokesman for the Prince said here today.

headline: Advertising; Hal Riney, In Surprise, Drops Gallo
abstract: LEAD: HAL RINEY & PARTNERS resigned the E.&J.; Gallo Winery account yesterday after seven years of award-winning work on its behalf.

headline: Restructuring Plan At Cleveland-Cliffs
abstract: LEAD: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., an iron ore mining company under siege from dissident shareholders, said it had proposed a recapitalization and restructuring plan. The company also said it was seeking a buyer.

headline: Indian Tamils' Support for Sri Lanka Rebels Appears to Wane
abstract: LEAD: When politicians called for a citywide strike last weekend to protest the Indian Army assault on Tamil separatist rebels in Sri Lanka, the police here were prepared for the worst.

headline: Soviet Invites Inspection of Atom Power Plant
abstract: LEAD: To allay fears about the safety of its reactors after the Chernobyl disaster, the Soviet Union has invited an international team to inspect safety arrangements at a civilian nuclear power plant, according to officials involved.

headline: Offer From Singer
abstract: LEAD: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, said today that the Singer Company, an aerospace concern based in Stamford, Conn., had offered him access to certain nonpublic information if he agreed to purchase no more of the company's shares for 18 months. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr.

headline: Arms Dealer Indicted In Copter Sale to Iraq
abstract: LEAD: A Miami man described by Federal officials as the largest arms dealer in the United States was indicted Wednesday on charges that he conspired to smuggle 103 combat helicopters armed with wire-guided TOW missiles to Iraq.

headline: Governing Party Is Set Back In Bolivian Municipal Voting
abstract: LEAD: Bolivia's governing party was set back in municipal elections as leftist and conservative opposition parties were leading in eight provincial capitals, including La Paz, according to initial results reported today.

headline: Group Lifts Stake In Bell & Howell
abstract: LEAD: A group led by Robert M. Bass of the wealthy Fort Worth family said it had raised its stake in the Bell & Howell Company to 11.1 percent, from 9.6 percent. The move makes the Bass group the largest shareholder and set off new takeover speculation about the business-equipment manufacturer. Its stock rose by $2.75, to $70.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Business and the Law; Fewer Applicants To Law Schools
abstract: LEAD: FEWER of the best and brightest students have been applying to law schools, forcing many schools to be less selective, a recent study has concluded.

headline: Prague Awaits the Glasnost Invasion
abstract: LEAD: For many Czechoslovaks, the Soviet Union, which led the 1968 invasion that ended the brief cultural and intellectual flowering of the ''Prague Spring,'' has become the main hope for a widening of freedom in their severely restricted country.

headline: Japan Cuts Overseas Investment
abstract: LEAD: The flow of money from Japan, a stream that has helped to finance the United States budget deficit and to influence stock prices on Wall Street, is slowing dramatically as investors here wait to see what steps the United States will take to cut its budget and trade deficits.

headline: Texaco Creditors Back Plan
abstract: LEAD: The committee of general creditors of Texaco Inc. yesterday approved an interim settlement proposal in the oil company's three-year battle with the Pennzoil Company, but it declined to disclose its terms until a crucial showdown in bankruptcy court today.

headline: Collecting Art? Beware the Wrinkles
abstract: LEAD: COLLECTING art requires a great deal of faith. One has to trust one's tastes, the art dealer and the market. But even with art prices soaring - a trend underscored earlier this month by the astronomical $53.9 million that Van Gogh's ''Irises'' brought at auction - faith can take you just so far. Increasingly, buying and selling is being regulated through legislation and case law, and consumers need to be aware of their rights to negotiate better deals.

headline: Advertising; Rumrill-Hoyt Making Executive Changes
abstract: LEAD: Rumrill-Hoyt of Rochester, a Saatchi & Saatchi company, has had executive movement in its upper reaches. Richard D. Thomson, 51 years old, the chief executive, has moved from the president's office to the vacant chairman's chair, allowing Nicholas J. Orloff, 55, to assume the role of president. He will also be chief operating officer.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Hadco Corp. has signed a $10 million revolving credit agreement with the Bank of Boston Corp.

headline: More Cuts At Coleco
abstract: LEAD: Coleco Industries gave layoff notice to 25 workers at its headquarters Friday and the company said there could be further staff cuts throughout the corporation by the end of the month.

headline: MARCH BY 200,000 IN CAPITAL PRESSES SOVIET ON RIGHTS
abstract: LEAD: On the eve of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's arrival in the United States, about 200,000 marchers streamed down Constitution Avenue to Capitol Hill today to send the message that Jewish emigration and human rights should figure prominently in the Soviet leader's meeting this week with President Reagan.

headline: Market Place; Mixed Views On Aerospace
abstract: LEAD: IN a market grown increasingly hostile toward the stocks of giant aerospace companies, the General Dynamics Corporation and the Boeing Company are selling at their lowest prices in three years.

headline: INVESTING; A Fund With Three Strategies
abstract: LEAD: IN the last year or so, Wall Street has sold value funds, country funds, hot-manager funds, sector funds, bond funds and even a fund investing in emerging countries. What most of these closed-end investment companies have in common, apart from tidy fees for their underwriters and an annuity-like stream of income for their managers, is losses for those who invested at the initial offering prices when they came to market.

headline: Treasury Bonds Retreat Slightly
abstract: LEAD: The rally in the bond market lost some momentum yesterday, as a rebound in oil prices from their intra-day low led to a slight decline in Treasury bond prices.

headline: 3 Die as Police Clash With Protesters in Bangladesh
abstract: LEAD: At least three people were shot and killed by the police here today as thousands of rioters set fire to cars and buildings, and threw bricks and homemade bombs in an attempt to force President H. M. Ershad from office.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: CONTAINING RETIREE HEALTH CARE EXPENSES; Company Liabilities Are Soaring
abstract: LEAD: ''AT American Airlines, we are spending $16 million annually on medical benefits for retired employees,'' Robert L. Crandall, the chief executive, said recently. ''We expect these costs to reach over $100 million in less than 10 years.''

abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: The Law Against Fraud
abstract: LEAD: Here are excerpts of the two provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 involved in the Winans case. Reference to ''the Commission'' means the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Advertising; Lintas's 'Hot' Idea For Lipton
abstract: LEAD: ''WE'RE out to make hot tea hot,'' exclaimed Susan Read, effusive executive vice president and executive creative director of Lintas:New York, as she turned to the VCR to bring the new campaign for Lipton tea to the screen. It was, she promised, a big idea.  In any event it was big enough to supplant Don Meredith, the one-time Dallas Cowboys quarterback who had been spokesman for the flow-through tea bags for more than a decade.

headline: What Do People Want, Anyway?
abstract: LEAD: THE Campbell Soup Company, like most consumer products companies, has always asked its customers lots of questions. Last year alone, its field researchers contacted close to 110,000 people to talk about food - taste, preparation, nutritional value, the works. On the basis of what they said, Campbell changed the seasonings in five Le Menu dinners and introduced a line of low-salt soups called, appropriately enough, Special Request.

headline: Amoco Seems on Verge Of Finishing Dome Deal
abstract: LEAD: After seven months of legal wrangling and secret negotiations, the Amoco Corporation appears close to wrapping up the biggest corporate takeover in Canada's history.

headline: Plunge Threatens Governments' 'Privatization' Programs
abstract: LEAD: There were growing signs today that one of the most important financial trends of this decade, the sale around the globe of government-owned companies to the public, could be jeopardized by the unprecedented plunge in stock prices over the last two days.

headline: The Growing Need for Bridge Loans
abstract: LEAD: MANY home buyers are still feeling shockwaves from last month's stock market collapse. Some were relying on now-devalued securities for the down payment while others lost buyers for their own homes. Now, unwilling or unable to back out of contracts for new homes, they are scurrying for quick cash to close their deals.

headline: Telex Extension
abstract: LEAD: The investor Asher B. Edelman said he had extended until Nov. 20 his $65-a-share offer for the outstanding shares of the Telex Corporation. Meanwhile, the Tulsa, Okla., computer concern said it expected its pretax earnings and revenues to rise steadily from 1988 to 1993. The company said the projection had been reviewed by its board in determining to submit a $775 million recapitalization plan to shareholders if the takeover offer from Mr.

headline: Buyout of Eastern Air Urged
abstract: LEAD: As pink slips went out today to the first of 3,500 workers being laid off at Eastern Air Lines, a union official urged an employee buyout of the carrier.

headline: A SOVIET SCHOLAR IS MISSING IN INDIA
abstract: LEAD: A young Soviet research scholar disappeared last week during a shopping trip in New Delhi, and police officials said today that they suspected he had defected to a Western country or had been kidnapped by Afghan exiles.

headline: Soviet Appears to Shun Compromise on Arms
abstract: LEAD: Soviet arms negotiators in Geneva have surprised the American side by appearing to back away from a key compromise on a treaty to ban medium- and shorter-range missiles, Administration officials said today.

headline: Interruption at Pacific Exchange
abstract: LEAD: The Pacific Stock Exchange closed its automatic execution system for five hours this morning and blamed transmission problems for the shutdown.

headline: U.S. Debt Issues Rise Strongly
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury securities market benefited tremendously from the steep drop in stock prices yesterday as the inflow of money from investors who sold stocks and prospects for a weaker economy helped raise prices and lower interest rates in all maturities.

headline: Carbide Settlement On Bhopal Is Seen
abstract: LEAD: Lawyers for the Indian Government and the Union Carbide Corporation were scheduled to appear at a court hearing in India today, amid wide speculation that they were close to an agreement on compensation to be paid the victims of the Bhopal disaster.

headline: Quiet Day for the Dollar As Budget Talks Go On
abstract: LEAD: The dollar was little changed in quiet trading yesterday.

headline: British Caledonian
abstract: LEAD: Scandinavian Airlines System has made a bid of $:110 million, or about $199 million, for a 26 percent stake in British Caledonian, the money-losing airline that is also talking with British Airways P.L.C., British Caledonian said. S.A.S. could also raise its interest in Caledonian to 40 percent under a capital restructuring plan.

headline: Corruption in Drug Industry Is Focus of Bombay Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: An investigation of a scandal involving contaminated drugs that killed 14 people in a local hospital two years ago has provided a glimpse of the murky world of politics, business and bureaucracy in India.

headline: Compaq Net Up Sharply
abstract: LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation, buoyed by rising demand, said today that its profits jumped fourfold in the third quarter.

headline: Acting Webb Chief May Be Permanent
abstract: LEAD: Philip J. Dion, a financial executive, will probably succeed Robert K. Swanson as chairman and chief executive of the Del E. Webb Corporation when its directors convene next week, industry analysts said yesterday. The 42-year-old Mr. Dion is already serving as acting chief executive.

headline: Holly Sugar Gets $91-a-Share Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Holly Sugar Corporation, the target of a recent series of unsuccessful takeover bids, said it had received a merger offer of $91 a share, or $102 million, from an investor group led by the Illinois financier Peter Harvey. Assuming the cash tender offer for two-thirds of Holly's shares is successful, the group, Plum Associates, proposes exchanging the remaining third of

headline: Market Place; Dollar's Fall Aids Global-Fund Rise
abstract: LEAD: THE weakness of the United States dollar against major world currencies has played havoc lately with the stock market. But this same dollar instability has helped to turn mutual funds that invest mainly in bonds of foreign governments into star performers this year.

headline: Comments From Shultz After Moscow Meeting
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's news conference in Moscow today:  OPENING STATEMENT

headline: U.S. Doctor Challenged on Brazil Radiation Aid
abstract: LEAD: An American physician's assertion that he led an international medical team treating victims of a recent radiation accident here has been challenged by American diplomats and Brazilian doctors and officials.

headline: Caesars Stake Cut
abstract: LEAD: Martin T. Sosnoff, the New York investor, has reduced his stake in Caesars World Inc. to 16 percent, from 17.4 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Sosnoff said that he continued to hold all shares acquired by him ''principally for investment purposes.'' Mr. Sosnoff, whose earlier offer to purchase Caesars World was defeated, has criticized the company's plan to buy back 11 million of its shares for prices ranging from $29.50 to $34 a share.

headline: Nicaragua Captures American; C.I.A. Link Charged
abstract: LEAD: An American pilot was shot down over Nicaragua on Sunday while ''clearly engaged in enemy activity against our country,'' the Nicaraguan Defense Minister said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: Bonus Halt Is Denied By Hutton
abstract: LEAD: The president of E. F. Hutton & Company said yesterday that, contrary to widespread fears among professional employees, the firm would pay bonuses to those who were eligible and who had earned them. ''We're paying them,'' Robert P. Rittereiser said.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * Apple Computer Inc., San Francisco, nominated the former astronaut Sally Ride as a director on its six-member board to replace Henry Singleton, chairman of Teledyne Inc. who is not standing for re-election.

headline: A Free Mandela Could Aid Peace, Nationalist Tells South Africans
abstract: LEAD: Nelson R. Mandela, the 69-year-old jailed leader of the outlawed African National Congress, would ''bend all his efforts'' toward a peaceful solution in South Africa if he were freed, his colleague Govan A. Mbeki said today.

headline: Advertising; Big Plans In Sales Promotion
abstract: LEAD: PETER H. ENGEL's American Consulting Corporation announced a small acquisition last week. It's only the beginning. The former Procter & Gamble, Philip Morris and Colgate-Palmolive marketing executive has had big growth plans for his eight-year-old company, especially since it went public last August.

headline: INDIA REPORTS GAIN IN SRI LANKA DRIVE
abstract: LEAD: India said tonight that its troops had broken into the center of the Sri Lankan city of Jaffna after a 10-day military campaign against ethnic Tamil rebels it had pledged to disarm.

headline: Advertising; Grey's Chicago Office Is Sold to GGK
abstract: LEAD: Grey Advertising is selling its Chicago office to GGK, the Swiss-based agency that already owns Lois, Pitts, Gershon, Ponn/GGK in New York.

headline: NICARAGUA PLANS MILITARY BUILDUP
abstract: LEAD: Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua plans to more than double its military forces over the next seven years and increase the number of warplanes and other weapons over fear of a United States invasion.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Sotheby's Good Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Sotheby's auction house, which in November set the world record price of $53.9 million for a painting, with the sale of Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises,'' announced Friday its best-ever fourth-quarter results. It reported worldwide auction sales of $:340 million, or about $622 million, for the latest three months, up 2.7 percent over the corresponding period last year.

headline: And Now, the Sound of Plastic
abstract: LEAD: What the world needs is a paper-thin piece of plastic that can be rolled into an oddly-shaped speaker that emits tinny-sounding music. No? Well that's what Japan has and the rest of us may soon get, thanks to the Mitsubishi Petrochemical Company.

headline: New Agency For Schrafft's
abstract: LEAD: The name Schrafft's, which has a bright and shining image to a certain age group of New Yorkers, is barely known to the up-and-coming generation.

headline: Institutional Investors Support Shorter Day
abstract: LEAD: Judging by the relative quiet on the trading desk of Jefferies & Company, which offers its clients a chance to buy and sell when the stock markets are closed or trading in a stock is halted, institutional investors are not at all displeased by the shorter trading hours set by the exchanges.

headline: Cuomo's View Of Economy
abstract: LEAD: Governor Cuomo said tonight that the plunge in stocks had ''finally jolted the American people into a recognition that there are serious economic problems in this country.''

headline: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
abstract: LEAD: ''THERE'S the regular way to install this program into your computer, and then there's a shortcut,'' the message said as it crept haltingly across my screen, occasionally backspacing to fix a typo. ''One takes about three to five minutes, the other about two. Which do you want to try?'' ''Short,'' I typed back.

headline: 300 DEFY STOPPAGE AT PAPER IN INDIA
abstract: LEAD: Three hundred editors, reporters and other workers returned to their jobs Wednesday at India's largest newspaper, defying a 15-day-old work stoppage that they said had been sponsored by politicians close to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.

headline: Verity Aide Appointed
abstract: LEAD: Edwin L. Dale Jr., spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget since 1981, will become a top aide to the new Secretary of Commerce, C. William Verity Jr., Administration officials said today. Mr. Dale will be a counselor to Mr. Verity, who was confirmed by the Senate on Tuesday and is expected to be sworn in soon.

headline: European Steel Quotas
abstract: LEAD: The steel ministers of the European Community have extended its quota system on steel production for six months to allow the industry more time to cut surplus production. Without the decision, the community quota system, which has shielded the steel industry from competition since 1980, would have expired on Dec.

headline: READER'S DIGEST MAN JOINS ANTI-DRUG EFFORT
abstract: LEAD: The Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America, advertising's biggest voluntary effort since the bond drives of World War II, has announced thet Lynn C. Mapes, recently retired Reader's Digest executive, has joined the organization as a volunteer to serve in the important job of media director.

headline: Advertising; Trillion Is Set To Return
abstract: LEAD: When Hoyt (Pete) Spellman and Richard W. Lynch set up their publishing unit within the British-owned Moorgate Group here last April, they said that one of their priorities was to ac-quire magazines.

headline: The U.N. Today; Nov. 27, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: ATTACKS IN HAITI CONTINUE IN SLUM
abstract: LEAD: While many downtown stores opened for the first time today since Sunday's aborted election, and life in much of Port-au-Prince continued to return to normal, residents of one section of the capital fled continued attacks from heavily armed thugs.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Patrick Hillman has been promoted to executive vice president at H.D.M.'s New York office.

headline: Reagan Confidant Urged Pardons in Iran Case
abstract: LEAD: William P. Clark, the former national security adviser, said today that he wrote President Reagan at the end of the Iran-contra hearings in August asking him to grant pardons to Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

headline: New Capital Raised by Haas
abstract: LEAD: The Haas Securities Corporation, which stopped trading on the New York Stock Exchange last week when its capital fell below the exchange's minimum requirements, said yesterday that it had raised between $3 million and $5 million in financing from two private investors, allowing it to resume operations.

headline: Alexandria Recovering Its Arab Soul
abstract: LEAD: The myths have been stripped from this city, and the outsiders' fables of love and war are lost in the land they saw as only backdrop and metaphor.

headline: U.S., After Debate, Rejects Negotiations On 'Star Wars' Tests
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration has spurned a Soviet proposal to negotiate the scope of ''Star Wars'' tests, a senior Administration official said today.

headline: Exchange Employees Begin Strike
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of employees went on strike at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, seeking improved pension benefits.

headline: Israelis Kill 3 in Gaza as Arabs Are Exhorted to Protest
abstract: LEAD: Three more Palestinian demonstrators were shot to death in clashes with Israeli troops today as widespread violence again swept through the occupied Gaza Strip.

headline: ADVERTISING;
abstract: LEAD: American consumers last year saved $2.75 billion on their shopping bills through the use of cents-off coupons, according to the A.C. Nielsen Company, which monitors such activity.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: Morton Baran has joined the Martin Agency, Richmond, as senior vice president and director of broadcast production.

abstract: LEAD: Following are key sections of the majority report, issued today, of the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair:  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY  SUMMARY OF THE FACTS  Nicaragua

headline: FIRST DIRECT RAID
abstract: LEAD: An American-registered tanker was hit by a missile, apparently Iranian, in Kuwaiti waters this morning, Kuwaiti and American officials said.

headline: A Market View From the Inside
abstract: LEAD: John J. Phelan Jr., at the center of a maelstrom as the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, called for action to reduce the budget and trade deficits to lower interest rates and calm market fears.

headline: Gorbachev on History; Revolution's Road From 1917 to Now: The Leader Takes Stock
abstract: LEAD:  Following are key sections of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech in Moscow yesterday, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:  It is 70 years since the unforgettable days of October 1917, those legendary days that started the count of the new epoch of social progress, of the real history of humankind.

headline: REAGAN REAFFIRMS 'STAR WARS' STAND
abstract: LEAD: Two weeks before his summit conference with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Reagan vowed today to deploy the space-based antimissile system that the Soviet Union adamantly opposes.

headline: Reagan Delay Expected On Contra Aid Request
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration is expected to delay its request to Congress for a $270 million package of military and nonlethal aid to the Nicaraguan rebels until the beginning of next year, Administration officials said today.

headline: OUTLOOK FOR THE MARKETS: Equities at Risk; Bonds Promising; But Certain Issues Win Favor
abstract: LEAD: ON Oct. 19, the bull market met the matador.

headline: F.T.C. Acts to Bar Acquisition by Dun
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission voted unananimously to have its staff seek a preliminary injunction blocking the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation's acquisition of Information Resources Inc.

headline: Amoco '88 Budget
abstract: LEAD: The Amoco Corporation's board approved a $3.8 billion capital and exploration budget for 1988, a 17 percent increase over the company's $3.25 billion budget in 1987. Richard M. Morrow, Amoco's chairman, said in a prepared statement that the company's ability to carry out 1988 spending plans depend on price levels for crude oil, natural gas and refined petroleum products.

headline: Talking Deals; Pan Am Pilots At the Controls
abstract: LEAD: NEVER before have trade unions played such a key role in determining the outcome of mergers and acquisitions. That is especially true in the airline industry, where decisions by unions on whether to make concessions decided the fate of Trans World Airlines and Eastern Airlines.

headline: China Display Of the Shoddy Breaks Down
abstract: LEAD: Consumers in China, a land where refrigerator doors fall off, the frames of bicycles crack as they are wheeled from the store and the hands of doughnut-sized watches ignore conventional notions of time, are up in arms. Or so the country's newspapers say.

headline: Countdown to Christmas at K Mart
abstract: LEAD: PAUL PORADA looked purposeful. With intense absorption, he strode through the shopperless K Mart, eyes dancing across the shelves, as he began another too-many-hour day during the Christmas shopping explosion.

headline: BASS GROUP MEETS WITH BELL & HOWELL Special to The New York Times
abstract: LEAD: A group led by the Fort Worth financier Rob-ert M. Bass said it had met with offi-cials of the Bell & Howell Company to discuss the investment in the com-pany by the Mawell Communica-tions Corporation. The British compa-ny, headed by the publisher Robert Maxwell, has said it would seek to buy more that 50 percent of Bell & Howell, an information services com-pany based in Skokie,

headline: Seoul Candidate Faces Violence at Kwangju Rally
abstract: LEAD: In the worst outbreak of violence yet in this country's presidential campaign, the ruling party candidate, Roh Tae Woo, dodged rocks, sticks and tear gas canisters today as he faced crowds aflame with bitter memories of the harsh Government suppression of a 1980 uprising here.

headline: Trade Gap With Japan Gets Wider
abstract: LEAD: Japan's surplus in trade with the United States grew in September despite a 10.5 percent increase in Japanese imports of American goods and a decline in Japan's overall trade surplus.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD:  Allied-Signal Inc., Morris Township, N.J., an advanced-technology company, said Forrest N. Shumway, vice chairman and a director, would take early retirement, effective Jan. 1.  Butler National Corp., Lenexa, Kan., which provides aircraft-modification products and has acquired HSD Inc., a Kansas City, Mo., consulting engineering firm, named HSD's chairman, John Dixon, president of Butler.

headline: POTAMKIN HITS A SNAG IN ITS SALE TO PENSKE
abstract: LEAD: The owners of Potamkin Cadillac are encountering difficulty in selling their dealership in Manhattan to the Penske Corporation, a company that is probably best known for its auto racing operations. A major obstacle is a delay by the General Motors Corporation in giving its approval to the sale.

headline: Nicaraguan, at U.N., Asks Direct Talks With U.S.
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua invited the United States today to resume a dialogue with his Government after a Central American peace plan goes into effect.

headline: Burlington Plans To Sell 3 Divisions
abstract: LEAD: Burlington Industries plans to sell three industrial fabrics divisions under a restructuring aimed at helping pay off debt incurred when it went private in a $2.5 billion leveraged buyout, the company said. Divisions to be sold have combined annual sales of $300 million and include the company's Precision Fabrics, Glass Fabrics and Industrial

headline: WRIGHT HAS TALKS WITH BOTH PARTIES IN NICARAGUA WAR
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua and the leaders of the American-backed rebels conferred separately today with the House Speaker, Jim Wright, as efforts to negotiate a cease-fire appeared to be stepping up.
