headline: Suriname Voters Give a Strong Rebuff to Military
abstract: LEAD: A three-party opposition coalition in Suriname won a landslide election victory today in a popular rebuke of the South American country's seven years of military dictatorship.

headline: Bitterness and Apathy in Nicaragua
abstract: LEAD: A white dove curls toward the sky on a billboard splashed with soft pastels of green and blue. The visual message is made explicit in the words below the affecting scene: ''We want peace.''

headline: Pearson Up On Rumors
abstract: LEAD: Pearson P.L.C. was the biggest gainer on the London Stock Exchange today, sparked by rumors that the publisher Rupert Murdoch was about to increase his stake of nearly 15 percent and might begin a takeover bid, brokers said.

headline: Year-End Tax Tips for the Investor
abstract: LEAD: INVESTORS scanning their portfolios for last-minute ways to cut taxes this year will find their task substantially complicated by the recent changes in the tax law. ''This year is particularly important because it's a bridge from the old law in 1986 to 1988, when the new rules fall into place,'' said Joan S.

headline: Koreans Fight Police in an Opposition Stronghold
abstract: LEAD: Street battles broke out here today as students and workers vented their anger at the electoral defeat of this city's favorite son, Kim Dae Jung.

headline: Japan Trade Surplus Off
abstract: LEAD: Japan reported today that its trade surplus for the first 20 days of November plunged almost 50 percent, to $2.09 billion, from $3.9 billion a year earlier. Although the yen's increasing strength against the dollar did not inhibit Japanese exports from growing at a rate of 16.4 percent, to $12.16 billion, imports surged 53.7 percent, to $10.07 billion.

headline: U.S. Cutting Sugar Imports In Blow to Trading Partners
abstract: LEAD: The United States will cut its 1988 sugar imports by 25 percent, to the lowest level in more than 100 years, the Reagan Administration announced today. The action is expected to increase prices for consumers and hurt the debt-burdened economies of some of America's trading partners among developing nations.

headline: William Clay Ford Named to Key Post
abstract: LEAD: William Clay Ford, who has spent most of his business life in the long shadow cast by his older brother, Henry Ford 2d, was named yesterday as chairman of the finance committee of the Ford Motor Company's board. He succeeds his brother, who was chairman of the powerful committee until his death at 70 on Sept.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD:

headline: Thompson Medical
abstract: LEAD: The Thompson Medical Company said its board had received a proposal for a management-led buyout of the company from a group headed by S. Daniel Abraham, its chairman and chief executive. Under the proposal, shareholders would receive $15 in cash for each of their shares in a merger. Thompson shares gained 87.5 cents, to $10.875, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

headline: Asuncion Journal; In Autumn of the Patriarch, Murmurs Grow Loud
abstract: LEAD: Presidential elections are still eight weeks away and campaigning has not yet begun, but the winner, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, is already receiving the ''profound and sincere thanks'' of his acolytes for his ''inexhaustible vocation'' for serving Paraguay.

headline: G.M. Seen Closing Plant Temporarily
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation will temporarily close its assembly plant in Hamtramck, Mich. in January, idling 2,500 workers, while it redesigns models produced there, according to a report published today. The Detroit Free Press said the nation's largest auto maker would close the $600 million plant for three weeks as workers begin converting it for production of 1989 Buick Riviera and Oldsmobile Toronado models.

headline: GORBACHEV ASSAILS CRIMES OF STALIN, LAUDS KHRUSHCHEV
abstract: LEAD: Resuming a painful examination of Soviet history that was all but suspended for the last 25 years, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that Stalin was guilty of ''enormous and unforgivable'' crimes and praised two Soviet figures who had been officially repudiated.

headline: Portfolio Insurance Is Growing
abstract: LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange's decision to extend its restrictions on the use of computer-aided program trading as a way of curbing volume and easing volatility was not warmly received by the institutions and securities exchanges that rely on such techniques to do business in the stock market.

headline: Westinghouse Profit Up 8.7%
abstract: LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 8.7 percent, to $184.1 million, or $1.28 a share, from $169.3 million, or $1.11 a share, a year before. Sales totaled $2.59 billion, up less than 1 percent from $2.57 billion.

headline: Boesky Gets Jail For Insider Role
abstract: LEAD: Ivan F. Boesky was sentenced to three years in prison for his part in Wall Street's biggest insider trading scandal. Mr. Boesky, once a leading arbitrager who amassed a fortune speculating in corporate takeovers, had pleaded guilty in April to one count of conspiracy to make false statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: New Soviet Clubs Find Freedom in the Rough
abstract: LEAD: In the first minute of Tuesday night's meeting of the unofficial Perestroika Club, an argument broke out over who would serve as chairman. It was followed by an argument over the agenda, and another argument over who was authorized to speak for the group in interviews with the press.

headline: Swiss and U.S. In Insider Pact
abstract: LEAD: American and Swiss officials are scehduled to sign an agreement Tuesday giving the Americans greater access to the records of suspected insider traders who are trying to shield their transactions by taking advantage of Swiss bank secrecy laws.

headline: U.S. Envoy Cautions Pretoria on Its Future
abstract: LEAD: The United States Ambassador declared today that South Africa could not endure into the next century if it turned its back on the West.

headline: No Offer for Calmat
abstract: LEAD: - A group of companies led by Industrial Equity Ltd. said it had decided not to make a takeover bid for the Calmat Company. Industrial Equity of Hong Kong already owns 19.1 percent of the common stock of the Los Angeles cement maker. Industrial Equity said its decision is a result of the stock market's volatility and litigation brought by Calmat against the group.

headline: Hungary in a Sour Mood as Leadership Shifts
abstract: LEAD: Hungary is facing the new year in a mood so sour and apprehensive that even the Government has had to acknowledge it.

headline: Stocks Fall Sharply In Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plummeted today, but then recovered some of their losses late in the session in roller-coaster trading that apparently reflected worries here about Wall Street's health.

headline: INVESTING; Why This Market Cycle Isn't Different
abstract: LEAD: THE four most dangerous words in investing are ''this time it's different,'' according to John Templeton, the highly regarded 74-year-old mutual fund manager. At stock market tops and bottoms, investors invariably use this rationale to justify their emotion-driven decisions.

headline: Merck Offers Free Distribution of New River Blindness Drug
abstract: LEAD: Merck & Company announced today that it had developed a drug to treat river blindness and would distribute it free to countries that request it.

headline: STOCKS CONTINUE TO CLIMB SHARPLY IN HEAVY TRADING
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rallied again yesterday as more investors edged back into the market after its historic midmonth collapse.

headline: Tax Rises Expected Primarily for Corporations and the Rich
abstract: LEAD: The $9 billion of tax increases included in the budget package announced today were not designated, but they will likely be relatively limited in scope, with corporations and wealthier individuals shouldering most of the burden, according to Congressional tax writers.

headline: Train Students in the Art of War
abstract: LEAD: MONTHS before I started teaching a class at the Columbia University Business School, I described to my faculty superior a class that would be eccentric by the business school's standards.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Citicorp Official Takes Job At Household International
abstract: LEAD: Edwin P. Hoffman, a key officer at Citicorp, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of Household International Inc., a leading financial services and manufacturing company based in Illinois.

headline: Berkshire-Salomon
abstract: LEAD: Salomon Inc. and Berkshire Hathaway Inc. said they had consummated their previously announced agreement for the sale of 700,000 shares of Salomon's series A cumulated preferred stock for $700 million. The transaction was part of an agreement reached last weekend under which Berkshire Hathaway, based in Omaha, is acquiring a 14 percent stake in the investment banking firm.

headline: Market Place; Analysts Await Move on Trade
abstract: LEAD: PESSIMISM hung over the stock market as prices took another plunge yesterday, but most analysts shied away from predicting that investors should brace for a collapse as steep as the 508-point fall last Oct. 19.

headline: Two Frenchmen Freed in Beirut; Talks Reported
abstract: LEAD: Two Frenchmen held hostage in Lebanon were released today by a shadowy group identifying itself as the Organization of Revolutionary Justice.

headline: Ford Completes Divestment in South Africa
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company completed its disinvestment from South Africa today with a deal that involves donating a 24 percent equity interest in its former subsidiary to an employee trust.

headline: Proposal for Nutrasweet
abstract: LEAD: The Nutrasweet Company said Friday that it had asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve the use of the artificial sweetener aspartame in baked goods and baking mixes. In the past, the F.D.A. had said that aspartame, sold under the trade name Nutrasweet, was unacceptable for baking because the sweetener would break down at high temperatures.

headline: Edelman Begins Telex Offer
abstract: LEAD: Asher B. Edelman began a $65-a-share cash tender offer yesterday for the Telex Corporation, a telecommunications company based in Tulsa, Okla., that is already about 8 percent owned by a group led by the financier.

headline: U.S. Official Urges New Aid to Pakistan
abstract: LEAD: A senior State Department official asked Congress today to renew aid to Pakistan, despite concerns that Pakistan may be trying to develop nuclear weapons.

headline: Dollar Perplexes Candidates
abstract: LEAD: What the Republican and Democratic candidates for the Presidency are saying about the dollar is, mostly, the obvious: it will remain weak until a workable long-term agreement is reached to reduce the nation's budget deficit.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Robert Jaczko, creative director, has been promoted to senior vice president at Doremus & Co., Boston.

headline: Spanish Leader Is Firm in Opposing U.S. Jets
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said Friday that Spain would stick to its decision to bar United States F-16 jet fighters from Spanish soil, despite strong pressure from European allies on behalf of the United States.

headline: Stock Price of Drug's Maker Jumps on Word of Clearance
abstract: LEAD: The price of Genentech Inc. shares rose $3.25 today, to $42.75, on anticipation that the company would receive Government approval on Friday to market its drug for dissolving blood clots, called tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A.

headline: Options' Risks Shown By Stock Market Slide
abstract: LEAD: The stock market's collapse on Oct. 19 showed once again the potential volatility of the securities markets. And it demonstrated to thousands of investors around the country that options can be among the most volatile of all instruments in these markets, even for those who use them in conjunction with other strategies.

headline: After Compromise Fails, Nakasone Picks a Successor
abstract: LEAD: Noboru Takeshita, a former Finance Minister and a master of political compromise, was virtually assured today of becoming Japan's next Prime Minister when the incumbent, Yasuhiro Nakasone, designated him as his successor.

headline: Pan Am And Braniff Set Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Pan Am Corporation announced last night that it had reached a tentative deal with Braniff Inc. that could result in the merger of Pan American World Airways and Braniff if certain conditions are met.

headline: Aide to Nicaragua Defense Chief Is Reported to Defect to the U.S.
abstract: LEAD: A senior Sandinista military officer apparently defected to the United States last week, diplomats and politicians said today.

headline: Japan Video Output Off
abstract: LEAD: Japanese output of video cassette recorders and color televisions fell 6.8 percent and 2.1 percent, respectively, in November from a year earlier because of slow exports, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan said today. November's production of 2.3 million video recorders marked the 12th straight monthly decline from the previous year and was down 6.6 percent from October, a spokesman said.

headline: Advertising; New Job: Reassuring Investors
abstract: LEAD: NOW IS the time for all good men (and women) whose companies' images have been buffeted by the Wall Street bears to turn to public relations for a repair job.

headline: 'Loophole' Tax Plan Criticized
abstract: LEAD: Congressional tax writers said today that they need to go far beyond the Reagan Administration's suggestion of closing ''loopholes'' in the income tax code if they are to raise $12 billion in new revenues to meet 1988 budget needs.

headline: 1,155 G.M. LAYOFFS
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would indefinitely lay off about 1,155 of its hourly employees in January, when it will slow auto production at three of its United States plants. The cut would increase the company's list of indefinitely laid-off workers by 2.5 percent. A Lansing, Mich., plant that makes the Buick Skylark and Oldsmobile Cutlass will lay off 850 of its 4,350 workers.

headline: New York City Raises Offering to $750 Million
abstract: LEAD: Strong investor demand led New York City to increase the size of its bond sale to $750 million, from $600 million, and allowed securities dealers to reduce interest rates a tenth of a percentage point for some maturities.

headline: Mitsubishi Ruling Is Upheld
abstract: LEAD: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said that a Court of Appeals in Washington had upheld a lower court ruling favorable to it in a suit brought in 1984 by the Tandon Corporation. Tandon had appealed last year's ruling by a Federal District Court in Los Angeles, which found that Mitsubishi had not infringed on Tandon's double-sided disk drive technology.

headline: DO NEW LIMITS MEAN NEW TRAPS?
abstract: LEAD: WHEN the speed limit on some highways returned to 65 miles an hour earlier this year, manufacturers of radar detectors were more than a little concerned. After all, while commercial radar detectors had been around for 20 years, their business came to life only in 1974, when the highway speed limit was cut to 55 m.p.h.

headline: Court Is Picked For LTV Case
abstract: LEAD: Federal District Judge Robert Sweet has ruled that a dispute over who has financial responsibility for the LTV Corporation's pensions would be litigated in Federal district court rather than bankruptcy court.

headline: Sears to Acquire Pinstripes Petites
abstract: LEAD: Sears, Roebuck & Company has agreed to acquire Pinstripes Petites, a women's specialty-store chain based in Minneapolis, for an undisclosed sum. It is Sears's second specialty-store acquisition in recent months - the first was Eye-Care Centers of America Inc., a 41-store chain based in San Antonio.

headline: Hungary Takes Note of Its Troubled Youth
abstract: LEAD: A Hungarian ''tinedzser'' is subject to the same psychological pressures as teen-agers elsewhere.

headline: Sierra Pacific In Timberland Deal
abstract: LEAD: Sierra Pacific Industries has agreed to buy 520,000 acres of timberland in Northern California owned by the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, the companies said. The price was not disclosed.

headline: Buyer Is Sought For Executive Life
abstract: LEAD: The First Executive Corporation said it is seeking a buyer for its Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, which analysts estimate could bring between $600 million and $900 million. In March, the unit was fined $250,000 by New York regulators, who disallowed $151.5 million in reinsurance contracts, under which insurers pass on some risks to other carriers.

headline: Lipton Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: Thomas J. Lipton Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the herbal tea maker Celestial Seasonings from Kraft Inc. Terms of the deal, which is scheduled for completion next year, were not disclosed. Lipton said that Kraft was selling Celestial Seasons as part of its move away from the beverage industry.

headline: ISRAEL ARMY READY TO START TRIALS FOR PALESTINIANS
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army is preparing to begin military trials for nearly a thousand Palestinians rounded up after two weeks of disturbances in the occupied territories, Israeli military officials and lawyers said today.

headline: For Small Planes, More Buyers Think Brazil
abstract: LEAD: IN a cavernous hangar at the headquarters of Embraer, as the Brazilian Aerospace Corporation is known, work has begun on the first of 20 twin-prop Brasilia aircraft on order from Texas Air. Near the plant's runway, technicians are testing five single-engine Tucano trainer planes, with the colors of the Peruvian Air Force.

headline: Hemmeter Cancels Hawaiian Air Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Hemmeter Corporation said that a two-month-old merger agreement to acquire HAL Inc., the parent of Hawaiian Airlines, for $50 a share, or $100 million, had been terminated because of lack of financing.

headline: REINVENTING THE AMERICAN AUTO
abstract: LEAD: THE American car has been the stuff of legend - in lyrics, literature, even love - since the early part of this century. But in the last 10 years, it has been transformed more drastically than at any other time in the previous 50 years. Faced with two energy crises in the 1970's and fierce competition from Japan,

headline: Reporter's Notebook: Foreigners in Tibet Protest
abstract: LEAD: Over the last three weeks, Lhasa has been shaken by three demonstrations against Chinese rule, protests led by shaven-headed monks from monasteries hammered into the mountains edging the north of the city.

headline: Staff Cutbacks For Boeing Jet
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company said today that it was continuing to cut back the manpower being assigned to develop its futuristic 7J7 aircraft and said it was no longer predicting when the aircraft would be available.

headline: Specialists Man the Ramparts
abstract: LEAD: All 52 specialists on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange lost money during the enormous sell-off on Monday and Tuesday, possibly as much as $750 million, trying to fulfill their traditional role of maintaining an orderly market, John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the exchange, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

headline: Contras Set New Demands for Talks
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels, hardening their negotiating position, presented several new demands today for their participation in peace talks with the Sandinista Government.

headline: European Plan To Tax Fats
abstract: LEAD: A controversial proposal to tax vegetable oils and fats, which is opposed by Europe's trading partners, will be submitted to the European Community summit meeting this week.

headline: 3d Chernobyl Reactor Runs
abstract: LEAD: The third reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear power station, damaged in an explosion and fire in April 1986, has been repaired and put back in operation, the press agency Tass said today. The fourth reactor at the Ukrainian plant was damaged beyond repair in the accident, which killed at least 31 people.

headline: Advertising; Amnesty International Volunteers
abstract: LEAD: ''A STUDENT in South Africa. A journalist in Chile. A dissident in the Soviet Union,'' the TV commercial's voice-over will intone, and the camera will open on a single eye, an eye filled with fear and panic. Then it will slowly pull back to reveal the other eye and the nose of a frightened man.

headline: AC&R to Withdraw From Public Relations
abstract: LEAD: Stephen Rose, chief executive of AC&R/DHB & Bess, a Saatchi & Saatchi company, has eliminated the agency's 15-year-old public relations operation because it has not been growing fast enough.

headline: Investors Sue Gap Over Disclosures
abstract: LEAD: The Gap Inc. said four class action suits had been filed in Federal District Court in San Francisco contending that the company made ''purported misstatements and omissions'' in its public disclosures. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Gap said the suits name certain officers and directors of the San Bruno,

headline: Congress Says El Salvador Misuses U.S. Aid
abstract: LEAD: A bipartisan Congressional caucus charged today that United States aid to El Salvador was being largely misused by the Salvadoran military and ruling party to conduct the civil war against rebel forces.

headline: Cannon to Sell Certain Assets
abstract: LEAD: Cannon Group Inc. has agreed to sell its real estate holdings for at least $300 million and lease them back from a company affiliated with a major shareholder.

abstract: LEAD:       $         Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   9.00   9.00   7.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.27   7.00   5.90        3-MO. headline: Last Treasury Sale for '87 Scheduled
abstract: LEAD: The last Treasury note auctions of 1987 are scheduled this week, with a $9.25 billion two-year issue tomorrow and a $7 billion four-year issue on Wednesday.

headline: TURNING MIGHTY ARMS INTO MUSTY ARTIFACTS
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet-American treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces provides for eliminating missiles by smashing, exploding, crushing, burning, launching and static display.

headline: THE DOLLAR'S DROP
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Wendy's Buffet
abstract: LEAD: Wendy's International Inc. said it plans to invest $35 million to expand its Superbar program, a new all-you-can-eat hot and cold food buffet. Robert L. Barney, chairman and chief executive, said that incremental sales gains averaging 15 percent in Superbar company stores had encourgaed Wendy's to expand the test program.

headline: Signet Bank Offer
abstract: LEAD: Signet Bank of Virginia, a subsidiary of the Signet Banking Corporation, a holding company, is offering $100 million of 9 1/4 percent deposit notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.93 to yield 9.27 percent through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding. Rated Aa-3 by Moody's and A by S.&P, the noncallable issue yields about 95-hundredths of a percentage point more than four-year Treasury bills.

headline: Tokyo Journal; Nakasone Bows Out, but Old Passions Never Die
abstract: LEAD: ''Let me join you from now on as a private,'' Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone told members of his ruling party the other day.

headline: Malaysian Car for U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Malaysia's money-losing national auto manufacturer, Proton, signed an accord today to distribute its Proton Saga car in the United States. Proton America Inc., headed by Malcolm Bricklin of Bricklin Industries, will import the car. ''Production of the models bound for the United States will begin in October 1988, once modifications to meet U.S.

headline: Swiss Vote Insider Curb
abstract: LEAD: Swiss legislators voted overwhelmingly today to outlaw insider trading, removing a longstanding source of tension with the United States.

headline: In Jerusalem, Sharon Apartment Creates a Stir
abstract: LEAD: Ariel Sharon slept over in his new apartment in Jerusalem on Tuesday night. Moslems called it a threatening act meant to drive them out of the city, Mayor Teddy Kollek labeled it ''counterproductive'' and Mr. Sharon just shrugged and said all he was doing was promoting real coexistence between Arabs and Jews.

headline: ACCORD IS REACHED ON MISSILE TREATY BY U.S. AND SOVIET
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union said today that they had resolved their remaining differences over a new treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev are due to sign in Washington in two weeks.

headline: Day to Remember In Financial District
abstract: LEAD: From the trading floors of the big brokerage firms to the stock exchanges to the shoeshine stands in the heart of the financial district, it was clear that yesterday would be a day etched in people's memories for years to come.

headline: Lebanese Suspect Linked to '85 T.W.A. Hijacking
abstract: LEAD: A Lebanese citizen awaiting trial in the United States on charges that he took part in the June 1985 hijacking of a Jordanian airliner was also involved in the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet the same month, Reagan Administration officials said today.

headline: U.S. Tax Sanction Angers Pretoria
abstract: LEAD: The vote by Congress to deny tax credits to American companies for taxes paid by their subsidiaries in South Africa is being viewed here as potentially one of the most damaging economic measures taken by the United States against apartheid.

headline: Dollar Climbs in Europe But Later Eases in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Coordinated moves by European central banks to reduce their basic lending rates caused the beleaguered dollar to register strong initial gains yesterday against all key foreign currencies. But some gains were pared in later trading in New York.

headline: Talking Deals; The Liquor Consolidations
abstract: LEAD: FACED with declining worldwide liquor consumption, the international liquor industry is turning to consolidation as a way to prop up sagging sales. Indeed, analysts say that by the end of the decade the industry, traditionally the domain of small, independent operators, will consist of a handful of conglomerates.

headline: Salvador Rebels to Boycott Talks After Killing of Rights Advocate
abstract: LEAD: - Leftist guerrillas said today that they would not attend a new round of peace talks with the Salvadoran Government, blaming it for the killing of a prominent human rights advocate.

headline: I.R.S. Won't Penalize Those Underwithheld on 1987 Pay
abstract: LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it would not penalize Americans who had too little withheld from their paychecks this year.

headline: 3 Partners to Buy Lorimar TV Units
abstract: LEAD: Joseph Goldfarb, a Lorimar Telepictures Corporation executive, said he and two partners had agreed to buy three television stations from the parent company for $23 million and that he plans to resign when the deal is completed.

headline: Business and Health; Rehabilitation In Head Injuries
abstract: LEAD: THANKS to medical-evacuation methods perfected in the Vietnam War and neurosurgery in specialized hospital trauma centers, tens of thousands of Americans survive brutal highway and other accidents that would have meant certain death only a decade ago.

headline: Mutual Lowers Datapoint Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Mutual Shares Corporation, a New York investment firm, and a group of its affiliates have lowered their stake in the Datapoint Corporation to 5.2 percent from 6.5 percent.

headline: Trout & Ries Going Into Strategy Business
abstract: LEAD: ''We're going to become what most people think we are,'' said Jack Trout, president of Trout & Ries, as he announced that he and his partner, Al Ries, were getting out of the agency business and getting into the strategy business.

headline: PATENTS; A Composition to Aid Body's Immune System
abstract: LEAD: Dr. A. Arthur Gottlieb, president of Imreg Inc., a biotechnology company in New Orleans, was granted a patent this week for a composition stimulating the immune system of the body.

headline: Carey Joins a New Firm As Old One Dissolves
abstract: LEAD: As the partners in Finley, Kumble continue to work out the dissolution of the giant law firm, one of them, Hugh L. Carey, the former Governor of New York, has made his own plans.

headline: Chip Industry Sees Big Gains
abstract: LEAD: Amid a recovery, the semiconductor industry projects sales growth of 17.9 percent in 1988, to $37.8 billion, an industry committee reported today. Citing substantial growth in application-specific integrated circuits and other new technologies, the committee also forecast sales of $40.6 billion in 1989 and $45 billion in 1990.

headline: Economic Scene; Opportunities And Dangers
abstract: LEAD: DID Black Monday plunge the economy into a black hole, or did it just represent the bursting of a speculative bubble that has not seriously impaired the business outlook?

headline: Full Program Trading To Resume on Wall St.
abstract: LEAD: Program trading, a sophisticated form of securities trading that critics have blamed for contributing to the stock market plunge three weeks ago, will resume today, leaving some analysts concerned about renewed volatility in stock prices.

headline: Prudential Real Estate Chooses Backer
abstract: LEAD: Backer Spielvogel Bates, one of the largest components of Saatchi & Saatchi, announced yesterday that it had become the agency for Prudential Real Estate, which will franchise a nationwide chain of real estate offices a la Century 21.

headline: Canada Bank Seeks 75% of Brokerage
abstract: LEAD: The Royal Bank of Canada, the largest bank in the country, announced yesterday a complex plan to acquire 75 percent of Dominion Securities Ltd., Canada's largest full-service securities firm. The deal is worth $385 million (Canadian), or $294 million in United States currency.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1987
abstract: LEAD: INTERNATIONAL  Prospects for relief in the third-world debt crisis are brighter. Under an innovative proposal, banks would forgive billions of dollars of Mexican debt in return for bonds of lesser value issued by Mexico. The new bonds would be backed by United States Treasury bonds bought by Mexico.

headline: Oshman's Calls Off Abercrombie Sale
abstract: LEAD: Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc. has terminated its agreement to sell all of the assets of its Abercrombie & Fitch division to an investor group headed by Michel Zelnik, the former president of Bidermann Industries Inc. It had been announced that the group would pay $30 million in cash and $20 million in junior subordinated notes for the sporting goods chain.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 7:  MONDAY  Barry Wright Standard Products  Jamesway Corp. Unocal Corp.  Rykoff-Sexton Inc.  TUESDAY  Allen Group Int'l. Flavors & Fragrances  Boise Cascade Oklahoma Gas & Elec.

headline: World Bank Urges More Austerity by Poland
abstract: LEAD: The World Bank has urged Poland to speed up the pace of economic change and enact even tougher austerity measures than Warsaw is planning.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Mary Alice LeDuc has been promoted to senior vice president, management supervisor at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton.

headline: Unit of BASF In U.S. Gas Deal
abstract: LEAD: A wholly owned subsidiary of BASF A.G., one of West Germany's largest chemical and plastics producers, said it would buy Houston-based Tenneco Inc.'s Mid-Louisiana Gas unit for around $80 million. The purchase would strengthen the existing position of the subsidiary, Wintershall A.G., in the Monroe natural gas field in northeast Louisiana.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.  Monday  Farm Prices... Oct.  Tuesday  Construction Spending... Oct.  Leading Indicators... Oct.  Wednesday  New-Home Sales... Oct.  Thursday  Factory Orders...

headline: U.S. Rates Non-Atom NATO Arms
abstract: LEAD: While outnumbered by Soviet forces, NATO has sufficent conventional strength to make a Soviet attack highly unlikely, according to a classified ''net assessment'' of opposing strengths and weaknesses prepared by the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

headline: Korean Trade Gain
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus widened to $5.52 billion in the first 11 months of the year from $2.93 billion a year earlier, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today. Officials said that Korean exports during the period rose 34.3 percent, to $41.91 billion, while imports rose 28.7 percent, to $36.39 billion.

headline: Award and Job Set By Magazine Publishers
abstract: LEAD: The Magazine Publishers of America yesterday heralded the names of the 1987 Publisher of the Year and of the group's new executive vice president/ marketing development.

headline: Art Center For Tower In Midtown
abstract: LEAD: AFTER more than six years of planning and construction, a 32-story office tower at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 57th Street, which will have an opulent marketplace for art and antiques as its centerpiece, is nearly finished. The antique center opens next week and the office space early next year.

headline: Texaco's Best Hope: U.S. Supreme Court
abstract: LEAD: The price of Texaco Inc.'s stock fell almost 10 percent while the Pennzoil Company's shares soared more than $10 yesterday as the financial and legal communities pondered the significance of the Texas Supreme Court's decision to let stand the $10.53 billion judgment against Texaco.

headline: Careers; Fostering Engineers' Creativity
abstract: LEAD: LAST week, professors, government officials and corporate executives met at the Stevens Institute of Technology, in Hoboken, N.J., to discuss changes needed in engineering education - creative ones that will allow engineers to prepare for the next century. Similar discussions are being held at engineering schools all over the country.

headline: The U.N. Today: Oct. 14, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: Union Pacific Has 16.4% of Beard
abstract: LEAD: The Union Pacific Corporation said it holds 16.4 percent of the Beard Company and may seek control of the Oklahoma City-based oil and gas concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Union Pacific said it might acquire Beard to obtain the company's 28 percent stake in USPCI Inc.

headline: Gibbons, Green Wins Argonaut
abstract: LEAD: Gibbons, Green, Van Amerongen Ltd. said today that it planned to buy Argonaut Group Inc. for about $620 million, a deal that apparently ends a long courtship for the workers' compensation insurer.

headline: At Least 15 Are Dead in Peru After Mudslide Hits Villages
abstract: LEAD: At least 15 people were killed and about 100 missing after mudslides swept through four villages in the foothills of the Peruvian Andes, the police said today.

headline: Pretoria Frees A Black Leader Jailed 23 Years
abstract: LEAD: A longtime leader of the outlawed African National Congress was freed today by the Government after 23 years in prison.

headline: Equitable to Sell Part of Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States plans to sell almost one-quarter of its money management affiliate, the Alliance Capital Management Company, in a public offering next year. It will also sell an 18 percent stake to 70 Alliance employees by year-end.

headline: Hopes Grows for Progress on Long-Range Arms Pact
abstract: LEAD: As President Reagan made final preparations for his summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, several of the President's senior advisers expressed optimism today that the two leaders could make significant progress next week toward a further agreement reducing the level of long-range nuclear weapons deployed by each side.

headline: Rights Group Faults Taiwan
abstract: LEAD: Taiwan is making some progress but has quite a way to go to live up to its stated commitment to human rights and greater democracy, according to the rights group Asia Watch.

headline: The Woman in the Race Gives Korea a Jolt
abstract: LEAD: Barring miracles, which occur with about as much frequency here as anywhere else, Hong Sook Ja will not become South Korea's next President.

headline: Commodities Fine Is Paid by Hutton
abstract: LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said that E. F. Hutton & Company and four current or former employees had paid civil penalties totaling $145,000 involving 14 purported violations of commodities law.

headline: Holiday Today: Many Closings
abstract: LEAD: Businesses, banks, exchanges and government offices will be closed today for Thanksgiving.

headline: As Terrible Turned Worse: A Broker's Harrowing Week
abstract: LEAD: Last Saturday. some members of Monness Crespi Hardt & Company, a small stock brokerage firm, were annoyed that they had missed a chance to take profits when the market dropped 100 points the day before. By yesterday afternoon, they felt lucky to be alive.

headline: Oil Pollutes Lithuania River
abstract: LEAD: More than 60 miles of river in the Soviet Baltic republic of Lithuania have been polluted by an oil leak from a power station, the trade union daily Trud said today.

headline: Insider Purchases Soaring
abstract: LEAD: Executives are putting their money where their mouths are. Ever since Oct. 19, the day the stock market plunged 508 points, they have been insisting that their companies are fundamentally sound. Now a survey shows that executives have been putting their own money into their companies' stock at an unprecedented rate.

headline: Bonn Pursues Privatization
abstract: LEAD: The West German Government said today that it would proceed with its privatization program next year despite the slump in world stock prices.

headline: Ortega Attacks U.S. but Calls for Talks
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua combined a sharp attack on the United States today with a renewal of an offer to negotiate directly with the Reagan Administration on security issues.

headline: Dollar Drop For Months Is Predicted
abstract: LEAD: The dollar's value is likely to continue to decline for at least the next few months, many economists and participants in the foreign-exchange markets say.

headline: Commodore Unit Chief
abstract: LEAD: Commodore International Ltd. said yesterday that it had named Max Toy president and chief operating officer of its Commodore Business Machines unit. Mr. Toy formerly was senior vice president of sales and government products at Xtra Business Systems, a unit of the ITT Corporation.

headline: Honduran Bombing Suspect Is Given Asylum by Mexico
abstract: LEAD: Mexico has granted permanent asylum in its embassy here to a man suspected of planting a bomb that exploded in a Chinese restaurant in August, slightly wounding six United States soldiers and a Honduran civilian.

headline: Sears's Net Buoyed by Allstate
abstract: LEAD: Benefiting from a strong performance by its Allstate insurance subsidiary, Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's biggest retailer and a leading financial services company, yesterday posted a sharp increase in its third-quarter earnings.

headline: G.M. Job Transfers
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation has begun processing applications by workers at two Saginaw plants seeking jobs at Central Foundry division plants in Ohio and Illinois. G.M. said 1,066 Saginaw Nodular Iron and Saginaw Grey Iron plant workers are seeking transfers to plants in Danville, Ill., and Defiance, Ohio.

headline: Stocks, Dollar Advance In Asia on U.S. Report
abstract: LEAD: Share prices climbed this morning, as traders, buoyed by news of a shrinking American trade deficit and a stronger dollar, flooded the market with buy orders.

headline: New Commerce Post Stirs Up Storm
abstract: LEAD: A power struggle has broken out in the Commerce Department under its new Secretary, C. William Verity Jr., over his choice to fill the new job of Under Secretary for Export Administration, Commerce officials said today.

headline: Apple Investment Post
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would broaden its strategic investment activity to potential acquisitions of public or privately held companies. Apple said it had promoted Daniel L. Eilers to vice president of strategic investments, a new position; as director of strategic investments he has been responsible for the company's venture capital efforts.

headline: 4,300 Opponents of Regime Reported Held in Bangladesh
abstract: LEAD: Security forces have detained 4,300 opposition leaders and workers in a five-day sweep intended to silence demands that President H. M. Ershad resign, opposition leaders said today. Government officials acknowledged that 519 people had been detained.

headline: Personal Spending Off Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Americans' consumer spending fell sharply last month, the first decline since January. Analysts said the September setback was likely to be followed by even worse news in the months ahead because of the jolt to consumer confidence from the huge declines in the stock market.

headline: Glaxo Profit Up, Stock Off
abstract: LEAD: Britain's Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., one of the world's biggest drug companies, today reported a 22 percent jump in its annual pretax profits to $:746 million, or $1.23 billion, but that was well below analysts' expectations.

headline: Tide Is Out for Risky Debt
abstract: LEAD: The last month has been a tough time for the junk bond market as the drop in the stock market and fears of a recession discouraged many buyers. That anxiety culminated Tuesday in the withdrawal of a proposed $1.5 billion financing for the Southland Corporation.

headline: Oil Imports a Problem Again
abstract: LEAD: The stubbornly high trade deficits in recent months are making the United States rediscover an old nemesis: oil imports.

headline: Iceland Power Link Plan
abstract: LEAD: North Venture Shipping Agencies Ltd., of Britain, today proposed to import electricity from Iceland through what would be the world's longest undersea transmission cable.

headline: LTV Granted An Extension
abstract: LEAD: The LTV Corporation, a diversified manufacturing company in Dallas, said today that a Federal bankruptcy judge in New York had granted the company an additional 120 days to file its plan of reorganization.

headline: U.S. Aides Say Panama General Proposed Sabotage in Nicaragua
abstract: LEAD: Panama's military leader offered to undertake sabotage and possibly assassinations in Nicaragua for the Reagan Administration, Government officials said today, explaining a veiled allusion to the matter in the Iran-contra report.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:       $         Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.75   8.75   7.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.73   7.06   6.02        3-MO. headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''This is more fallout from the crash.''  - eter Cohen, chairman of Shearson Lehman, potential bidder for E. F. Hutton

headline: Contra Fund-Raisers: Dispute Over Payment
abstract: LEAD: Just how much is a meeting with President Reagan worth?

headline: RUSSIAN PREDICTS ARMS ACCORD SOON
abstract: LEAD: The chief Soviet arms-control negotiator predicted today that a treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles would be completed within six days. But important verification issues reportedly remained unresolved after two days of high-level talks here.

headline: Dollar Firmer Amid Rumors As It Ends a Volatile Week
abstract: LEAD: After a volatile week, the dollar closed on a firmer note in slow trading yesterday. But currency dealers attributed the dollar's strengthening to additional, modest interventions by the major central banks, including the Federal Reserve.

headline: Under Fire, Spanish Socialists Defend Budget and Economy
abstract: LEAD: Facing strong union dissent and increasing pressure, Spain's governing Socialists are defending their budget proposals as necessary for continued economic growth.

headline: British Gas to Lift Bow Valley Stake
abstract: LEAD: The British Gas Corporation has offered $837 million (Canadian), or $644 million in American currency, to increase its stake in Bow Valley Industries Ltd., the Canadian oil and gas producer. The deal restricts British Gas's stake in Bow Valley's voting stock to 33 percent to satisfy Canadian regulatory authorities, the company said.

headline: With Calmer Markets, Pacific's Head Resigns
abstract: LEAD: A week before the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19, James S. Gallagher, the president of the Pacific Stock Exchange, informed the chairman that he planned to quit.

headline: RUMANIAN RECALLS DEAL FOR EMIGRES
abstract: LEAD: Israel paid millions of dollars to the Rumanian Government over several decades to permit emigration of Jews, according to a senior Rumanian intelligence official who defected in 1978.

headline: Management Shifts At McGraw-Hill
abstract: LEAD: In a series of management changes at McGraw-Hill Inc., John G. Wrede was named yesterday as president of its book company and Harold McGraw 3d has been named to head the publications company.

headline: New Methods Of Handling Toxic Waste
abstract: LEAD: FOR decades environmental engineers cleaned up toxic waste in one way: by enclosing and burying it, either in landfills or at the site.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly

headline: NEW HAITIAN LAW WILL LET OFFICIALS VIEW ALL BALLOTS
abstract: LEAD: The military-dominated Government today published a new election law that bars independent observers but not soldiers from polling stations, and lets the authorities examine every voter's ballot.

headline: British Airline In Other Talks
abstract: LEAD: Sir Adam Thompson, the chairman of British Caledonian Airways, said today that his company has held serious merger talks with six or seven European airlines in case a planned takeover by British Airways fails.

headline: Market Place; Texaco, Pennzoil: Their Prospects
abstract: LEAD: TEXACO INC. and the Pennzoil Company have ridden Wall Street's roller coaster in recent years and now, with the proposed settlement of their mammoth legal dispute, some analysts see both stocks poised for possible further gains.

headline: In Search of a Lightweight Tomato
abstract: LEAD: POPCORN is a favorite low-calorie snack - but many people sneak a little butter on for flavor. Soon it may be possible to have buttery tasting popcorn without the calories or the guilt.

headline: In Nicaragua, Economy Is Hobbling Sandinistas
abstract: LEAD: By traditional measures, 1987 is the year the Nicaraguan economy essentially collapsed. And if fundamental changes do not occur, 1988 will see the national currency become worthless, according to diplomats, local economists and trade union leaders.

headline: ON THE SUNNY SIDE OF THE STREET
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's latest car model holds only one person and has a top speed of about 60 miles an hour, but the fuel economy is hard to beat. The Sunraycer gets its power from a 90-square-foot array of 7,200 cells that convert sunshine into electricity.

headline: Bring Big Business to the Campus
abstract: LEAD: ONE lesson highlighted by the recent technological challenge from Japan is that America's primary competitive advantage - the capacity to innovate - is under attack. But now big business has found an ally in its battle to become more competitive - the university.

headline: Allied Signal's Net Up 16.8%
abstract: LEAD: Allied Signal Inc., the diversified high-tech conglomerate, said today that its operating profits rose 16.8 percent in the third quarter, but the company continued to suffer from a slump in its aerospace business.

headline: Vehicle Sales Up 10.8% Despite Wall St. Plunge
abstract: LEAD: Domestic auto makers today reported strong sales for the last 10 days of October. Buyers appeared unaffected by the stock market's 508-point plunge on Oct. 19 and the subsequent turmoil.

headline: After 16 Years, Soviet Jew Is Told She Can Go to Israel
abstract: LEAD: A prominent Jewish campaigner, denied permission to emigrate to Israel for 16 years, was told today that she could leave the Soviet Union.

headline: Showdown At Texaco Is Possible
abstract: LEAD: Committees of Texaco Inc.'s creditors and shareholders will meet in Manhattan this morning, attempting in a pivotal round of talks to agree to the proposed $3 billion cash settlement of the legal battle between Texaco and the Pennzoil Company.

headline: American Brands Units
abstract: LEAD: American Brands Inc., a diversified company based in Old Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that it plans to sell its Sunshine Biscuits and Pinkerton's subsidiaries.

headline: A New Use For Sludge: To Make Oil
abstract: LEAD: OVER the years, cities have tried all manner of methods to dispose of sludge, the end product of the typical sewage treatment plant. They have burned it, buried it, dumped it in the ocean, spread it on farms and even made bricks of it.

headline: Chrysler Closes Troubled Plant
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation has closed its Bramalea, Ontario, assembly plant indefinitely to correct quality problems with the Premier car it inherited from the American Motors Corporation and Renault.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., said it had sold two of its gift and glassware companies for an undisclosed amount of cash. Alco said Silvestri Corp. and Toscany Imports Ltd. had been sold in leveraged buyouts. The units contributed about $84 million in revenue in the 1987 fiscal year.

headline: Economic Scene; Europe Wants Leadership
abstract: LEAD: AFTER the Wall Street plunge, which is still reverberating in markets around the world, Europeans are again looking to the United States for leadership to prevent the financial crisis from becoming a worldwide slump. But they are fearful that sufficiently strong leadership will not be forthcoming either in Washington or Bonn or Tokyo or in the West collectively.

headline: Glaxo Hunts a New Winner
abstract: LEAD: DR. RICHARD B. SYKES, who heads the research arm of Britain's big pharmaceutical maker, Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., says that trying to develop a major new drug is like betting on race horses, with one notable difference.

headline: First Executive Won't Issue Shares
abstract: LEAD: The First Executive Corporation said it was dropping a plan made last month to issue 10.5 million shares at $17.15 each, or $180.1 million, to the ICH Corporation. First Executive's stock has declined sharply since the market's collapse, and closed today at $9.75, down 12.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

headline: Triangle Industries To Merge With CJI
abstract: LEAD: CJI Industries, a producer and distributor of coin and currency handling products. proposed a $35-a-share merger yesterday with Triangle Industries, the nation's biggest container maker.

headline: Nicaragua Hints at Truce Talks
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra suggested today it might be possible for his Government to negotiate a cease-fire indirectly with leaders of the United States-backed rebels.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.  Monday  Industrial Production... Oct.  Capacity Utilization... Oct.  Tuesday  Inventory-Sales... Sept.  Wednesday  Housing Starts... Oct.  Thursday  None  Friday  Consumer Price Index...

headline: Japan Trade Surplus Down
abstract: LEAD: The broadest measure of Japan's trade surplus fell 21 percent in October from its level of a year earlier, shrunken by the effect of the strong yen, the Finance Ministry said Friday.

headline: Top 40 for 'the Shave Crowd'
abstract: LEAD: The bandleader Mitch Miller once warned a group of radio announcers in the 1950's that financial ruin awaited those stations that played rock-and-roll music, then a newcomer on the scene. ''You have abdicated your programming to the pre-shave crowd that makes up zero percent of the country's buying power, once you eliminate ponytail ribbons,

headline: Iranian Boats Are Reported To Hit 2 Greek-Flagged Ships
abstract: LEAD: Iranian naval gunners fired on two Greek-registered vessels in the Persian Gulf over the weekend in apparent retaliation for Iraqi attacks on shipping bound for Iran.

headline: MARKETS PLUNGE
abstract: LEAD: The nation's trade deficit shrank in August from its record level, but the improvement was only half as much as expected and sent prices sharply lower in the financial markets.

headline: Pretoria Leader Backs Some Housing Integration
abstract: LEAD: President P. W. Botha said today his Government planned to permit some multiracial neighborhoods, but is not ready to scrap the law that segregates public facilities.

headline: Senate Protests Soviet Tests
abstract: LEAD: The Senate approved a non-binding resolution today condemning the Soviet test firing of intercontinental ballistic missiles last week within 600 miles of Hawaii. The vote was 96 to 0. Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming and sponsor of the measure, called the tests a ''deliberate provocation.

headline: Leslie Fay to Buy Albert Nipon Inc.
abstract: LEAD: The Leslie Fay Companies, a leading manufacturer of women's dresses and sportswear, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Albert Nipon Inc., the internationally known women's fashion house.

headline: Florida Tax Deadlock
abstract: LEAD: A special legislative session on Florida's services tax deadlocked today when Gov. Bob Martinez vowed to veto a bill that would have put the question to voters in a January referendum. Governor Martinez called a second special session on the tax just moments after the Senate voted 21 to 16 to accept a House bill.

headline: Toys 'R' Us Prospers As Holiday Sales Rise
abstract: LEAD: Ida and Joseph Gabay may forgo a vacation and otherwise scrimp because of the money they lost when the stock market plunged. But the Gabays have no intention of playing Scrooge when it comes to their grandchildren.

headline: Insider-Case Delays Seen
abstract: LEAD: David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that it would probably be months before the agency would bring any new insider trading cases.

headline: Sales to Soviet Bloc Charged
abstract: LEAD: Representative Duncan L. Hunter, Republican of California, said today that in the last seven years, the Toshiba Company of Japan, whose subsidiary had violated export control laws by selling silent propellers to the Soviet Union, and other Japanese companies have been ''heavily involved in illegally enhancing the microelectronic capability of Warsaw Pact nations.

headline: G.M.-Toyota Australia Deal
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation confirmed today that it would establish a joint venture in Australia with the Toyota Motor Corporation in 1988.

headline: U.S. MAY BE EASING ARMS TALKS STAND
abstract: LEAD: The United States may drop its demand that an overall limit be placed on warheads on Soviet land-based missiles as part of a larger compromise on reducing long-range nuclear arms, senior Administration officials said today.

headline: U.S. News Adopts Ad Reward System
abstract: LEAD: Faced by two competitors who have introduced discount programs that reward advertisers for increasing their market share in their newsweekly, U.S. News & World Report is instead adopting a more conventional reward system.

headline: Movie Magazine Joins Campaign by Showtime
abstract: LEAD: Premiere - The Movie Magazine, a monthly owned by Rupert Murdoch that made its debut in October, is going to benefit from a promotion being started by Showtime/The Movie Channel.

headline: Aix Journal; Blight of Hate Creeps Over a Political Landscape
abstract: LEAD: Across a lovely stretch of southern France best known for its sunshine and beaches, unlovely racist sentiments have seeped into the mainstream of political debate as France gears up for a presidential election next spring.

headline: Airline Ticket Fraud
abstract: LEAD: Ticket fraud costs the world's airlines up to $500 million a year, according to estimates by the International Air Transport Association published today. In its latest quarterly magazine, the I.A.T.A. said it had begun a training program to help staff from its 168 member airlines spot fraudulent tickets.

headline: 2 Platforms Called Base For Raids
abstract: LEAD: The two linked Iranian offshore platforms destroyed by American naval gunfire this morning have long served as an important base for Iran's raids against shipping in the lower Persian Gulf, according to knowledgeable Congressional and Pentagon officials.

headline: B.P. Forges Ahead With Bid for Britoil
abstract: LEAD: The British Petroleum Company announced this afternoon that it would go ahead with a multibillion-dollar takeover bid for Britoil P.L.C. despite the British Government's decision earlier today to invoke special powers to block British Petroleum from gaining control of Britoil.

headline: The Dollar Moves Higher As Precious Metals Slump
abstract: LEAD: The dollar moved higher in fairly active trading yesterday, bolstered by widespread indications that a statement reaffirming the need for currency stability may come from seven leading industrial nations over the weekend.

headline: A.T.&T.-Telerate
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Telerate Inc. said they had agreed to form a partnership to develop and market electronic transaction services for global financial markets. The two companies said that they plan to offer a system that would give international money traders the ability to make instantaneous transactions.

headline: OPEC Pact Sends Oil Price Down
abstract: LEAD: Oil prices fell again on world markets yesterday after OPEC decided to extend its current production and pricing levels through the middle of next year.

headline: Cadbury Expands
abstract: LEAD: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. of London announced that it would purchase Chocolat Poulain, a French chocolate company, from Midial S.A. for a price of 950 million French francs, or about $170 million. Cadbury Schweppes, which has a strong presence in the soft drink business in addition to confectioneries, said that Chocolat Poulain was a leading French maker of branded chocolate products, employing 760 people at two factories at Blois in southern France.

headline: Turkish Silver Mine
abstract: LEAD: Turkey has opened its first silver mine and expects to earn about $30 million a year from exporting silver, the state radio said Thursday. It added that a unit of the state company, Etibank, would process one million metric tons of ore a year and produce 122 tons of pure silver, most of which will be sold outside the country.

headline: Market Chaos
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Fokker Stock Falls
abstract: LEAD: Shares in N.V. Fokker, the Dutch aircraft maker, fell sharply on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange on news of major cash problems and costly delays in the introduction of two new aircraft. The stock, barred from trading Tuesday when the company announced it was seeking extra cash from the Government and banks, sold today for as low as 37.70 guilders, or $18.43, down more than one-third from Monday's closing price.

headline: Restructuring Plan for Cliffs
abstract: LEAD: The New Jersey investment banker David F. Bolger today proposed a restructuring plan for Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. that he valued between $18.72 and $20.22 a share, or a total of $250.7 million. Cleveland-Cliffs announced

headline: Gdansk Journal; Mood Over Dockyards Is New Mirror for Poland
abstract: LEAD: Down along Dock Street, Poland's powder keg, there is an air of uncertainty.

headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; A Reactor That Can't Melt Down?
abstract: LEAD: MORE than a decade after the last order was placed in this country for a commercial nuclear plant, some engineers and utility analysts think it is time to start developing a second generation of reactors that would be meltdown-proof. Their hope is that these reactors would be available when the demand for power picks up and when cost or environmental impact makes fossil fuels unattractive.

headline: A Telemarketing Plan With a European Twist
abstract: LEAD: There is nothing novel about a retailer running a toll-free number in a print ad in hopes of attracting the less adventuresome or combative shopper. It's called telemarketing.

headline: Auditing Rule Impact Cited
abstract: LEAD: A study said today that anticipated new accounting regulations could have a major impact on big business -reducing stock market prices, affecting corporate takeover decisions and altering benefits to retired Americans.

headline: Data General Joins N.T.T. in Venture
abstract: LEAD: The Data General Corporation announced an usual alliance yesterday with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the Japanese communications giant, to jointly develop a digital switching technology for sale in the United States and Japan.

headline: Paris Is Cool To Pere Noel: Is He Passe?
abstract: LEAD: Ferdinand Bachmann, a 30-year veteran of the Salvation Army, had an insider's explanation for why the Christmas shoppers sliding by him in front of Galeries Lafayette were plunking fewer francs into his metal drum this year. It was too warm. ''The colder it is,'' he said, an idle bell dangling in his left hand, ''the more they give.

headline: Engineering in a Slump, But Future Is Bright
abstract: LEAD: AS CORPORATE AMERICA restructures itself to meet the needs of a changing marketplace, career opportunities for science and engineering graduates have waned considerably over the last three years.

headline: Shoppers Shrug Off Market Turmoil
abstract: LEAD: Consumers don't seem too worried about the general state of the economy, to judge from the first indicators of their sentiments since the stock market collapse. Polls produced mixed, somewhat puzzling responses, but none of them seemed to portend a widespread movement to swear off spending. A similar reading emerged from the sales indicators.

headline: 11 Killed on Shanghai Ferry
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of passengers stampeded onto a fog-delayed ferry in Shanghai today, and 11 people were killed and 76 injured in the crush, the official New China News Agency said. The stampede occurred as thousands of people pushed forward when the vessel docked after a delay of several hours.

headline: The Summit; West Germans Greet Arms Treaty With Relief and Anxiety for the Future
abstract: LEAD: After all the grief over first bringing American medium-range missiles into Europe - and then over removing them - Germans greeted the disarmament treaty today with a mix of relief and anxiety over what comes next.

headline: Ulster Ordeal: The Bad Years
abstract: LEAD:  Dec. 4, 1971 - A bomb planted by Protestants kills 15 Roman Catholics in a Londonderry bar.  an. 30, 1972 - In what is remembered as ''Bloody Sunday,'' 13 Catholic demonstrators are killed in Londonderry by British soldiers fearing an I.R.A. ambush.  Feb. 22, 1972 - Bombs kill 7 British soldiers and civilians in Aldershot, southwest of London, in what is believed to be revenge for ''Bloody Sunday.

headline: Crackdown Is Ordered In Bangladesh Strikes
abstract: LEAD: President H. M. Ershad ordered a fresh crackdown on his opponents today as their national strike against his Government continued to cripple the country.

headline: Greenspan Plays Down Record Trade Deficit
abstract: LEAD: In his first comprehensive review of economic issues since taking office in August, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the record trade deficit reported last week was an aberration.

headline: Wave of Profit Taking Lowers Coffee Prices
abstract: LEAD: Coffee futures prices fell on a wave of profit taking yesterday after reaching their highest levels since mid-May on Monday.

headline: Israel Says Arab Boat Taken
abstract: LEAD: A military spokesman said today that the Israeli Navy had intercepted a boat belonging to Al Fatah, a Palestinian guerrilla organization, forced it to dock at an Israeli port and arrested all of its passengers. The 250-ton tugboat Nadija, flying a Honduran flag, was stopped last Saturday somewhere west of the Israeli coast, the announcement said.

headline: U.S. PROTESTS TEST OF SOVIET MISSILES NORTH OF HAWAII
abstract: LEAD: The United States has protested two Soviet long-range missile tests this week that sent unarmed warheads into the Pacific Ocean about 600 miles northwest of Hawaii, the State Department said today.

headline: A Broker's Harried Day as the Big Customers Rush to Sell
abstract: LEAD: By 9:15 A.M. yesterday, the tension was building inside the trading room at Wertheim Schroder & Company, a medium-sized brokerage firm that caters to institutional customers and wealthy individuals. Clients were flooding the firm with orders to sell stock. ''There hasn't been a single buy order so far today,'' said Robert J.

headline: Continental Sets Commercial Pullout
abstract: LEAD: Under its new management, the Continental Illinois Corporation will be stripped of most of its traditional commercial banking activities and will concentrate on investment banking activities, Thomas C. Theobald, chairman of the bank holding company, announced yesterday.

headline: A Golf Ball That Avoids the Woods?
abstract: LEAD: Most golfers, from weekend duffers to low-handicap regulars, play with balls covered with a substance called Surlyn. Surlyn is durable and can be whacked a long way, but it doesn't provide the exquisite control that the touring professionals crave.

headline: About Real Estate; Housing on 89th St. Built in the Old West Side Style
abstract: LEAD: In the last few years, residents of the Upper West Side have become accustomed to seeing many of the neighborhood's old town houses restored to their original 19th-century and early 20th-century elegance. That is what seems to have happened to two adjoining buildings at 103 and 105 West 89th Street near the corner of Columbus Avenue.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 413 money market mutual funds decreased $907.6 million, to $261.40 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 112 institutional funds were down $178.2 million, to $73.09 billion. Assets of the 206 general purpose funds were down $581.8 million, to $79.22 billion.

headline: DOW RISES 11.60 POINTS
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, helped by signs that inflation remained in check.

headline: Sikh Rally Faces Amritsar Curfew
abstract: LEAD: The police imposed a curfew on this city today to prevent militant Sikh separatists from holding a rally at the Golden Temple, the Sikhs' most sacred shrine.

headline: Refugees From Sri Lanka Battles Tell of Hunger and Dead Civilians
abstract: LEAD: Caught in a battle between Indian forces and ethnic Tamil guerrillas, residents of a northern town are trying to flee by any means possible, refugees reaching here said in interviews today. They told of hunger verging on starvation and of the killings of civilians by Indian troops.

headline: Company Buybacks Increase
abstract: LEAD: Stock buybacks by major corporations accelerated yesterday as dozens of companies went hunting, both for bargains and increased insurance against takeovers.

headline: Jack Schwartz Shoes To Tim Love Agency
abstract: LEAD: Jack Schwartz Shoes has assigned the creation of advertising for its British Knights athletic shoe division to Tim Love Advertising. The New York-based Schwartz nationally distributes its athletic line to Foot Locker and Lady Foot Locker retail stores.

headline: Reagan on Contras: 'Strive and Struggle'
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech to the Organization of American States today:

headline: MARKET IS STEADY AND TENSION EASES IN SHORTER SESSION
abstract: LEAD: The stock market closed out its most wrenching week yesterday with something approaching calm.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Becor Western Inc., South Milwaukee, Wis., said its board would recommend that shareholders approve the previously announced acquisition of the company by B-E Holdings Inc., a management group.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper Tuesday at an average rate of 7.54 percent, up from 7.347 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.8584 percent, up from 7.583 percent.

headline: East Berlin Journal; Strange Bedfellows: Marxists Embrace Nietzsche
abstract: LEAD: A re-evaluation of the 19th-century philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche has begun here with the endorsement of the Communist authorities, despite Nietzsche's reputation as one of the principal spiritual fathers of Nazism.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The index of leading indicators fell 1.7 percent in November as stock prices, a component, dropped for the second straight month, the Commerce Department reported. The drop in the index has not been exceeded in more than six years, but most analysts remained confident that the economy would continue to expand, though probably at a slower pace than in the last several months.

headline: A Friend of H. L. Hunt Battles His Son in Court
abstract: LEAD: As the Republican gubernatorial candidate in Texas in 1964, Jack A. Crichton knew he did not have much of a chance.

headline: Japan Warns U.S. on Tariffs
abstract: LEAD: Japan warned the United States today to remove the $165 million of tariffs still imposed on its electronic goods or face a GATT dispute panel.

headline: 3 Are Killed in Bangladesh Riots
abstract: LEAD: At least three people were reported killed today in a clash between rioters and the police as anti-Government protests continued sporadically and shops in central Dhaka were shut for half the day.

headline: A.T.&T. Acts to End Delay on Contract Rift
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will try to convince a Federal judge today to allow its protest to proceed against the General Services Administration and the manner in which it awarded $55 million in telecommunications contracts.

headline: Morgan Grenfell Official Switching to Drexel
abstract: LEAD: Keith R. Harris, president of the United States subsidiary of Morgan Grenfell & Company, has left to join Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; Cost-Saving Device Helps Pay TV
abstract: LEAD: FOR years, pay-per-view television has been merely a dream for the cable industry. The technology required to offer the service was costly and few cable operators were willing to pay the price.

headline: THE DIFFICULT BIRTH OF THE LOTUS AGENDA
abstract: LEAD: MITCHELL D. KAPOR, the man who introduced spreadsheets to the computer industry, was grappling with a particularly vexing problem in 1985 when he was chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation: little slips of paper. The little notes intended to help him organize his life were everywhere - on his desk, stuck to his telephone, stuffed in the pockets of his brightly patterned Hawaiian shirts.

headline: Yields' Fall Is Slowing
abstract: LEAD: The decline in yields on savings that followed the stock market's plunge on Oct. 19 slowed in the week ended yesterday.

headline: Tamils Say 12 Indian Troops Were Killed in East Sri Lanka
abstract: LEAD: Tamil rebels said today that they killed 12 Indian soldiers in a major clash in eastern Sri Lanka, while officials said 9 militants had died.

headline: SHULTZ SEES CHINA AND SOVIET VOTING FOR IRAN ARMS BAN
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said yesterday that he thought the Soviet Union and China would endorse an arms embargo against Iran if further diplomatic efforts failed to get the Iranians to accept a cease-fire in their war with Iraq.

headline: Cable System Founders Sell Out at a Hefty Price
abstract: LEAD: Paul L. Field and David W. Pardonner, who started a cable television company from scratch just eight years ago, are selling it and four associated partnerships for $225 million.

headline: Market Place; Few Earnings Estimates Cut
abstract: LEAD: THERE have not been many downward revisions by analysts for 1988 corporate earnings in the wake of the stock market's Oct. 19 debacle, according to companies that gather such information.

headline: Goldome Raises Leslie Fay Stake
abstract: LEAD: Goldome, the Buffalo-based savings bank, said it had raised its stake in the Leslie Fay Companies to 21.1 percent, from 17.8 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Goldome continued to say that it had acquired the shares of the New York-based apparel concern for investment purposes only.

headline: NICARAGUA FREES 985 FROM PRISONS
abstract: LEAD: The Government freed 985 political prisoners nationwide today as one of its moves to comply with a regional peace plan.

headline: German TV Host Quits Over His Nazi Past
abstract: LEAD: The 74-year-old host of West Germany's longest-running television talk show resigned today, a week after a magazine reopened his past as a Nazi journalist.

headline: Tax Bill Revision Seen on Takeovers
abstract: LEAD: Congressional tax proposals aimed at slowing corporate takeover activity are likely to be dropped or at least toned down in any final tax package, according to House and Senate tax aides. Such proposals are blamed by some on Wall Street for bringing on the stock market debacle.

headline: Bonn Reduces Interest Rate
abstract: LEAD: The West German central bank moved to calm money markets today by lowering a key financing rate. An increase in that rate last week had provoked a public scolding of Bonn by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  International

headline: NEC Wins Order Against Intel
abstract: LEAD: NEC Electronics Inc., the American affiliate of the NEC Corporation of Tokyo, said it had won a court order that would stop the Intel Corporation from petitioning the United States Customs Service to block shipments of NEC microprocessors. The action stems from a nearly three-year-old lawsuit in which Intel contends that microcode, or the embedded instructions in its chips, can be copyrighted and that NEC's chips infringe on

headline: New York Bonds Upgraded Despite Worries on Economy
abstract: LEAD: New York City's bond rating was raised yesterday to its highest level since 1975, despite concerns that recent declines in stock prices and employment at securities concerns would weaken the local economy and strain the city's financial condition.

headline: Rumania Is Said to Release Woman Jailed in Rights Case
abstract: LEAD: A Rumanian woman arrested in Bucharest after an interview for a French television documentary was released Thursday, the League for the Defense of Human Rights in Rumania said Friday.

headline: Market Place; Loews Is Moving Off the Sidelines
abstract: LEAD: AFTER missing the stock market's move in 1986 and 1987, the Loews Corporation has been moving hundreds of millions of dollars into stocks in recent days. ''Stocks have become interesting, where they were not interesting six months ago or three months ago,'' said Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of the divesified company and one of the most closely followed investors on Wall

headline: Waiting Game Is Over in Mexico As Presidential Choice Is Named
abstract: LEAD: Mexico's ruling party today named Carlos Salinas de Gortari, a 39-year-old economist, as its candidate to succeed President Miguel de la Madrid in December 1988.

headline: Exchanges Seek Ways to Heal Split
abstract: LEAD: The top executives of the New York Stock Exchange, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade held an unannounced breakfast meeting at the Big Board's Wall Street headquarters on Thursday to iron out the increasingly bitter differences over responsibility for the stock market crash two and a half weeks ago.

headline: World Bank Giving New Drought Aid to India
abstract: LEAD: The World Bank announced today that it was giving drought-related assistance of more than $500 million to India, saying it was seeking to ease this nation's growing balance-of-payments squeeze.

headline: Central American Peace Accord Goes Into Effect
abstract: LEAD: Central American governments announced a series of measures today to be carried out over the next two months to comply with a new regional peace treaty.

headline: Market Place; Merck-Squibb Rivalry's Effect
abstract: LEAD: DESPITE the October market plunge, drug stocks have been big winners so far this year, thanks to promising new products, rising earnings and a falling dollar that enhances their income from overseas. But what helps one company in this high-stakes business often works to the detriment of a competitor.

headline: SHULTZ BEGINNING VISIT TO MIDEAST
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz leaves Thursday for a brief tour of the Middle East in which he is expected to urge Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to relax his objection to an international peace conference.

headline: Spain Rejects U.S. Deal on Bases, Foreshadowing the Treaty's End
abstract: LEAD: Spain has turned down a last-minute compromise proposal by the United States to salvage the 34-year-old defense treaty that permits American military installations on Spanish soil.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Michael T. Rogers is joining Campbell-Mithun, Chicago, as executive vice president/director of creative services.

abstract: LEAD: DAVID E. MOORE, a grandson of the publisher Joseph Pulitzer, is bankrolling the startup of a publication aimed at encouraging businesses in the Northeast to market internationally.
