headline: Business and the Law; Changes by U.S. For Pension Plans
abstract: LEAD: AFTER months of growing debate over pension laws and how to reduce the mountainous deficit of the Federal agency that insures pension payments, sweeping changes were enacted last week that will significantly affect the payments companies must make and the guidelines under which employers must operate.

headline: One Author Is Rankling Two Chinas
abstract: LEAD: Bo Yang is a mild-mannered, bespectacled scholar who scribbles Chinese characters on notebooks in his small study, and infuriates people throughout the Chinese-speaking world.

headline: Nynex Names Chief For Directory Unit
abstract: LEAD: Donald B. Reed is stepping into a competitive slot at the Nynex Corporation. The company has named him president of the Nynex Information Resources Company, which publishes white and yellow page directories.

headline: SOVIET WON'T PUSH POLICY ON ALLIES, GORBACHEV SAYS
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, calling for a ''more sophisticated culture of mutual relations'' among Communist countries, said today that the Soviet Union favored a more flexible approach in its relations with its allies.

headline: Amoco-Dome
abstract: LEAD: The Amoco Canada Petroleum Company has taken the first step toward allowing shareholders and creditors to decide on its proposed acquisition of Dome Petroleum Ltd., the debt-laden oil and gas giant, for $5.5 billion (Canadian), or about $4.18 billion (United States). Amoco Canada filed a petition in Alberta Court of Queen's Bench, and the court scheduled a hearing for Jan.

headline: Bargains in Closed-End Funds
abstract: LEAD: THIS year has brought another deluge of stock offerings in new closed-end investment funds; a total of 34 issues raised about $9 billion, according to one estimate. But even before the plunge in stock prices in October, investors in many of the equity-oriented funds shared a common experience: They were a bit poorer for having bought at the initial offerings.

headline: Syria Hopeful on French Ties
abstract: LEAD: Syria expects to have warmer relations with France after two days of talks in Damascus with the French Foreign Minister, Jean-Bernard Raimond, a Syrian Cabinet member said today. ''The Syrian and French republics are to bolster their relations and expand cooperation in all fields,'' Najah al-Attar, the Minister of Culture, was quoted by the Syrian radio as saying.

headline: 'It's Time to Act,' Constituents Say
abstract: LEAD: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a conservative Republican from Utah, is not one to advocate tax increases. But since the stock market plunge, messages from home have led him to view ''selective'' tax increases as acceptable.

headline: Reagan Imposes Punitive Tariffs Against Brazil
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan announced today that he would impose punitive tariffs covering more than $100 million worth of imports from Brazil in retaliation for Brazilian curbs on American computer and software products.

headline: Mutual Funds Limited Stock Sales
abstract: LEAD: The mutual fund industry absorbed, rather than increased, much of the pressure to liquidate giant holdings of stocks on Oct. 19 by using billions of dollars in cash reserves to meet shareholder redemptions, the industry's trade group said today.

headline: TAX SHELTERS

headline: Worldwide Selling
abstract: LEAD: Investors throughout Europe and Asia dumped shares today in a worldwide wave of distress selling.

headline: Decision Industries Gets Onset Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Onset Corporation has begun a friendly $8.75-a-share offer for the Decision Industries Corporation, which it said would cost $92 million, but a second company said that it would pay more for the computer concern based in Horsham, Pa.

headline: Exchanges Battle Over Fall
abstract: LEAD: The financial futures and options industry, bloodied by huge losses from the stock market plunge, is now waging a bitter battle with the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Boeing Officer Will Retire
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company said today that T. A. Wilson would retire as chairman on Dec. 31, ending a 44-year career. Mr. Wilson, known throughout the aerospace industry simply as ''T,'' will be succeeded by Frank A. Shrontz, Boeing's president and chief executive.

headline: Factories' Orders Fell In August
abstract: LEAD: Orders to factories fell 1.7 percent in August as lower demand for aircraft and military goods brought the first setback in manufacturing since January.

headline: Advertising; Agencies Share Tasks For Monica's Projects
abstract: LEAD: The first advertising for Claridge's Fine Food & Confections will start in the New York market in the third week in December, concentrating on radio ads.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Down 8.8% on Big Board
abstract: LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended Nov. 13 decreased from the previous month by 44.7 million shares, or 8.8 percent, to 465.5 million.

headline: Japan-Citibank Tie
abstract: LEAD: The New York-based Citibank and Japan's Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank said they would link their automatic teller machine systems beginning in January, allowing customers to use the automatic tellers of both banks. Citibank is the largest commercial bank in the United States, while Dai-Ichi Kangyo is the largest in the world in terms of assets.

headline: Credit Rise Is Slower
abstract: LEAD: Consumers took out $3.7 billion more in credit than they paid off in October, substantially less than credit growth in the previous two months, the Government said today.

headline: The Art Advances at Warp Drive
abstract: LEAD: MUSICIANS have been synthesizing sound electrically since the turn of the century, when Thaddeus Cahill invented the Telharmonium, a mostly mechanical piano-like contraption. The advancing art went into warp drive about eight years ago, however, with the arrival of digitally synthesized music.

headline: Bofors Names Official
abstract: LEAD: The Swedish arms maker A. B. Bofors, under police investigation for several bribery and smuggling scandals, said today that it had appointed a new managing director. Egon Linderoth, currently the deputy managing director of the car maker Saab-Scania A.B., will replace Bofors's acting chief, Per Ove Morberg, on March 1.

headline: Dollar, Stocks Fall In Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: The dollar reached yet another record low against the yen today, dropping to 133.30 yen in afternoon trading.

headline: Santa Fe Ends Henley Talks
abstract: LEAD: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said that it had ended talks about repurchasing the Henley Group Inc.'s 14.7 percent interest in the company and that it intended to proceed with a $4 billion restructuring. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Henley said it had rejected an unspecified offer from Santa Fe for its 23 million shares on

headline: Fisher-Price Job
abstract: LEAD: Waring & LaRosa, long a Fisher-Price agency, has been named to handle its Brand Licensed Products for infant and toddler businesses. The assignment was formerly at Towne Silverstein Rotter. Billing figures were unavailable.

abstract: LEAD: THIS MONTH, the faculty and staff at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School will celebrate the grand opening of the Steinberg Conference Center, an on-campus, $23 million complex that includes a health club, 100 guest rooms and scores of personal computers. headline: Patents; Reducing Aircraft Friction
abstract: LEAD: THE National Aeronautics and Space Administration received a patent this week for a structure described as reducing friction on the surface of an aircraft.

headline: NATO Foreign Ministers Praise Treaty and Urge Senate Approval
abstract: LEAD: NATO foreign ministers today hailed the Soviet-American accord on intermediate-range nuclear missiles as a ''treaty without precedent in the history of arms control,'' and called for its speedy approval by the United States Senate.

headline: Fear of AIDS Surfaces in Permissive Bangkok
abstract: LEAD: In Bangkok, where by conservative estimates several hundred thousand people make their living in the sex industry, fears of AIDS have been slow to surface. But the complacency may soon be over.

headline: Court Blow To a Plan For Texaco
abstract: LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge said today that a committee of Texaco Inc. shareholders must approve any settlement proposed by the company's creditors and the Pennzoil Company.

headline: A Franklin Bank Payout
abstract: LEAD: Nearly 14 years after the Franklin National Bank had to be bailed out in the largest bank failure ever, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said yesterday that certain preferred shareholders would receive accrued but unpaid dividends equal to $10.9 million.

abstract: LEAD: The Government banned all reports on the political opposition or on anything deemed to be criticism of the authorities today, a day after President H. M. Ershad imposed a nationwide state of emergency.

headline: For Art in Hungary, Wall St. Friends
abstract: LEAD: Wall Street, not normally a subject of interest for the people of a Communist country without a stock market, has been worrying a surprising number of Hungarians since stocks plunged in October.

headline: Electronics Sales Rise
abstract: LEAD: United States factory sales of electronic equipment, components and related products during the first nine months of the year increased 6.7 percent over the corresponding period last year, an industry association said Friday. Sales for the 1987 period totaled $165.5 billion, compared with last year's nine-month record sales of $155.2 billion, according to figures released this week by the Electronic Industries Association here.

headline: BEHIND SOME BRIGHT IDEAS OF '87
abstract: LEAD: A wonder drug for heart-attack victims. A book of zany but thought-provoking questions. Exciting advances in superconductivity. Buying postage stamps by phone.

headline: New Chief Will Stress GTE Core Businesses
abstract: LEAD: The GTE Corporation announced yesterday that James L. Johnson had been elected to succeed Theodore F. Brophy as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Brophy retires at age 65 in April after 30 years at the telecommunications company.

headline: U.N. CHIEF FAULTS TEHERAN'S STANCE
abstract: LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar told the Security Council today that its authority was being undermined by Iran's refusal to accept its cease-fire call and indicated he felt it was time to impose an arms embargo.

abstract: LEAD: Lenin probably never wanted them to found a Catholic university.

abstract: LEAD: The Henley Group said it had ended talks with the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation about the possible acquisition of one of the company's rail lines. headline: PATENTS; Locating Stars
abstract: LEAD: A device to aid astronomers in locating stars and other celestial bodies is described in patent No. 4,702,703, which was granted this week to Robert R. Herbst of San Diego. The invention is a hollow, transparent sphere with light-reflecting spots that indicate the position of stars. A light source brightens the spots and a ring and band indicate the north and south poles and equator.

headline: Tutu Urges Blacks to End Political Killings
abstract: LEAD: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu called on blacks today to halt factional bloodshed in Natal province, where at least 14 people have been killed since Christmas Eve.

abstract: LEAD: Britain's Plessey Company P.L.C. said Friday that it had established a joint venture with the Telenet Communications Corporation, a subsidiary of U.S. Sprint, to supply switching equipment to send electronic data by telephone. The venture, to be called Plessey-Telenet, will be 51 percent owned by Plessey but largely managed by Telenet.

abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev asked American business leaders today to help improve the economic relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union now that political relations are on what he called a ''more predictable footing.''

abstract: LEAD: WHEN a foreign-based advertising agency opens a branch in New York, it can't really be too hopeful of attracting local clients, what with the great selection of American agencies available.

Although Mr. Coleman had been convinced that the market would quickly rebound, yesterday's plunge shook his confidence.

abstract: LEAD: President Reagan conferred today with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India in what American officials characterized as a new atmosphere of increased cooperation.

abstract: LEAD: The plane that Mathias Rust landed near Red Square in Moscow has been brought to Paris by the author Paul-Loup Sulitzer, who plans to take it on a tour of France and the United States, a Frenh maga-zine said today. ''For me this plane is a symbol of a feat of peace and free-dom,'' Mr. Sulitzer was quoted as hav-ing told the magazine, Paris-Match.

headline: Market Place; CBS Puts Off Records Deal
abstract: LEAD: DISAPPOINTING investors who expected a decision on the future of its records group, CBS Inc. said yesterday that it would take a little longer to make up its mind.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN BUSINESS CELEBRATIONS
abstract: LEAD: IN the wake of the stock market's plunge, some budgets have been trimmed, but most businesses are still planning to follow their holiday traditions of years past, whether it's playing host to an employee party, wining and dining valued customers or giving gifts. Indeed, some companies that canceled parties right after the Oct.

headline: Labor Talks Continue at Exchanges
abstract: LEAD: Officials of the New York Stock Exchange, trading companies and the New York Futures Exchange, who are facing a possible strike by most of their clerical workers, continued contract negotiations with union officials last night, a spokesman for the exchange said.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; FIELDCREST CANNON PICKS A QUARTER-CENTURY MAN
abstract: LEAD: Charles G. Horn was pleased but not surprised by his appointment on Friday to the presidency of Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., an Eden, N.C., manufacturer of carpets and textiles for the home.

abstract: LEAD: In opening arguments yesterday in the trial of David W. C. Clark, a New York lawyer implicated in an insider trading ring, the prosecution and the defense painted contrasting pictures of a ''dishonest lawyer'' who stole millions of dollars from his clients and of a man who had been too trusting of a dishonest stockbroker.

abstract: LEAD: The New York financier Asher B. Edelman will meet with senior officials of the Telex Corporation on Wednesday to discuss his $65-a-share cash tender offer for the computer equipment concern. abstract: LEAD: A Pakistani-born Canadian businessman was convicted today of conspiring to ship material to Pakistan that could be used to produce nuclear weapons.

abstract: LEAD: The leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, arriving here today for their first summit meeting in more than a decade, face a region and a world that has changed profoundly for them since their organization was founded 20 years ago.

abstract: LEAD: The acquisitive British publisher Robert Maxwell said he was giving up his bid for the Bell & Howell Company, seemingly clearing the way for a rival group to take over the United States information-services concern. headline: Debt Swaps In Mexico
abstract: LEAD: Mexico is reviewing its debt-for-equity conversion program to assess the inflationary impact, but the program has not been suspended, the central bank governor said.

headline: Advertising; Holly Farms Shifts Account
abstract: LEAD: Holly Farms, a marketer of brand-name poultry based in Wilkesboro, N.C., has switched its agency to Long, Haymes & Carr, down home in Winston-Salem. Left behind in New York is a ''stunned'' Grey Advertising, the agency for the last five years, which saw the client move into chicken-marketing eminence.

headline: Tribune Fete: An American In Paris at 100
abstract: LEAD: With pomp and flourish, The International Herald Tribune, an American newspaper abroad, celebrated its 100th anniversary in Paris this week.

abstract: LEAD: The management consulting firm of McKinsey & Company said yesterday that Frederick W. Gluck had been elected its next managing director, effective July 1.

headline: London Subway Toll at 31
abstract: LEAD: The death toll in the London subway fire rose to 31 today, and thousands of mourners lined streets in central London for the funeral of a fire chief killed trying to rescue victims. The latest victim died in hospital of severe burns.

abstract: LEAD: THREE good-sized advertisers announced new agency alliances yesterday. The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is returning to Young & Rubicam, the agency that served it from 1945 to 1975. DDB Needham, Chicago, is getting the Discover credit card from Sears, Roebuck & Company. And Grey Advertising and its subsidiary, Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, are getting big pieces of work from

headline: 60,000 Jobs to Be Cut In Moscow Ministries
abstract: LEAD: A national newspaper said today that 60,000 Moscow residents would be dismissed by 1990 under Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign to streamline government by cutting 50 percent of all ministry jobs.

headline: Harcourt Sale Of Units Near
abstract: LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., which previously put its business publications unit and its school supply company up for sale, said yesterday that it had found prospective buyers for those operations as well as its book club business.

abstract: LEAD: * Making a living is becoming a family enterprise.

headline: Foreign Cars Up in Japan
abstract: LEAD: Foreign car sales in Japan rose to 6,627 in October, a 34.8 percent increase from a year earlier and the 46th straight year-on-year increase, the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today. But October sales fell from a record 10,089 automobiles in September. West German-made cars, accounting for 70 percent of the October total, rose 27.3 percent from a year earlier, to 4,637.

headline: For Commodity Traders, a Week Like No Other
abstract: LEAD: Herbert Malkind has had trouble sleeping this week. He woke up at 3 A.M. on Tuesday and 4 A.M. today, worried whether the trades he had made the day before on the floor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange would hold up in the morning.

headline: Prices on Bonds Fall Again
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices slumped for the second straight session yesterday, pushed lower by the dollar's weak performance on world currency markets.

headline: Spectrum Group
abstract: LEAD: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said it is offering to sell its Spectrum Group unit. Spectrum, based in Jacksonville, Fla., makes insecticides, herbicides and fertilizers. It had 1986 sales of $42.1 million. The decision is consistent with the company's long-term strategy of focusing on its traditional core businesses, which include cosmetics, fragrances, personal care products and packaged foods.

headline: Drug Approval For Genentech
abstract: LEAD: Genentech Inc. received approval today from the Food and Drug Administration for its blood clot-dissolving drug, tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A. The approval comes just five months after an F.D.A. advisory committee recommended against licensing Activase, as Genentech calls the drug, and asked for additional information about the its ability to save lives.

headline: Exiled Duvalier Appeals for Calm
abstract: LEAD: Jean-Claude Duvalier, the deposed Haitian President, appealed today for calm in Haiti and for an end to the violence that caused the postponement of the first free presidential elections in 30 years.

headline: American Let Go by Contras Says He Was Not Mistreated
abstract: LEAD: An American who was released Friday after being held by Nicaraguan guerrillas for two weeks said today that he had not been mistreated.

headline: Giuliani Sees Case Aiding Prosecution
abstract: LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, said yesterday that the United States Supreme Court's ruling against R. Foster Winans meant that his office ''was free to go ahead now'' with insider trading cases.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Berkey Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a diversified photographic equipment concern, said it had sold certain assets of its Berkey Marketing Cos. division and would be negotiating the disposition of several product lines.

headline: Kuwait Lifts B.P. Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Kuwaiti Government said today that it had raised its stake in the British Petroleum Company above 13 percent. The Kuwait Investment Office, which invests the Persian Gulf state's petrodollars worldwide, began buying B.P. stock last month. B.P. said the Kuwaiti agency now holds 13.07 percent.

headline: MARKET TURMOIL; Few Signs of Prescience By Company Insiders
abstract: LEAD: The giant fall in stock prices that took individual investors by surprise was also a bolt from the blue to many corporate insiders.

headline: Banks Add Charges, Cut Jobs
abstract: LEAD: Seeking to bolster its profits, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has begun charging a fee for withdrawals made through its cash machines and, according to banking industry officials, has planned to dismiss 2,500 employees by the end of March.

headline: Machinery of Government Shifts to a Higher Gear
abstract: LEAD: Washington's response to the collapse on Wall Street is intended to calm panic and restore stability to the markets. Beginning with the President, Here are the policymakers and regulators trying to guide the financial system through this crisis:  President Reagan

headline: Hong Kong Suffers Wild Fluctuations
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices fluctuated wildly in morning trading here today, after losing one-third of their value on Monday in one of the worst one-day losses ever suffered by any stock market.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Baxter Travenol Laboratories, Deerfield, Ill., a developer of health care products, systems and services, named as a director Martha R. Ingram, director of public affairs and director at Ingram Industries.

headline: U.N. Tells Reagan It Must Have U.S. Money
abstract: LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has written to President Reagan warning that the United Nations faces insolvency in a few weeks if the United States does not pay a substantial portion of its annual contribution by then, according to United Nations officials.

headline: Dean Witter Hires 27 From Salomon
abstract: LEAD: Rebuilding its municipal-bond operation, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said yesterday that it had hired 27 municipal-bond specialists, including two managing directors, from Salomon Brothers Inc. Salomon recently announced it was abandoning the municipal-bond business because of low profits.

headline: Develop Those Existing Technologies
abstract: LEAD: IN the Samuel Beckett play, ''Waiting For Godot,'' the central characters await the arrival of a special person - who never comes - while they watch the world pass by. The analogy with United States manufacturing management is startling. Manufacturers are waiting for new technology that will make them competitive in the global market without any risks or modifications in the way they currently do business.

headline: Cyprus-LTV Steel
abstract: LEAD: The Cyprus Minerals Company said it had filed claims totaling $1.07 billion against the LTV Steel Company and alternate claims of $722 million against its parent company, the LTV Corporation. Cyprus, based in Englewood, Calif., said the claims stem from LTV's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing in July 1986 and its subsequent rejections of two long-term coal supply contracts.

headline: Prices Paid To Farmers Up by 1.6%
abstract: LEAD: The prices that farmers receive for raw products rose 1.6 percent in September, recovering more than half of the losses of July and August, the Agriculture Department said today.

headline: European Plea To Spur Trade
abstract: LEAD: The European Community pleaded strongly today for the United States to cut its budget and trade deficits and for Japan to help lift the world economy by opening its markets to foreign goods.

headline: Kabul Says a Convoy Breaks Siege of a City
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet-backed Afghan Government asserted today that a convoy of 155 Government trucks ferrying food and other supplies had reached the besieged city of Khost safely.

headline: Dun & Bradstreet Withdraws Its Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation yesterday withdrew its offer for Information Resources Inc., a market research company, after the Federal Trade Commission said it opposed a merger.

headline: In Salvador, Harried Right Courts Army
abstract: LEAD: In the face of a strong attack from President Jose Napoleon Duarte, who has charged them with complicity in political assassinations, Salvadoran rightists are urgently seeking help from their traditional ally - the army.

headline: Iran Says Iraqis Raided a Nuclear Plant
abstract: LEAD: Iranian news outlets reported that Iraqi warplanes raided an unfinished Iranian nuclear power plant today, and that an Iranian nuclear official said the attack could lead to a release of radiation across international borders.

headline: SOVIET GIVES EXIT TO PROMINENT JEW
abstract: LEAD: Aleksandr Lerner, who has been denied permission to leave the Soviet Union for nearly 17 years, said today that he had been told he could emigrate to Israel.

abstract: LEAD: Indian forces have gone on the offensive against the most violent of Sri Lanka's ethnic Tamil separatist groups after more than 200 people were killed in terrorist attacks, Indian and Sri Lankan officials said today.

headline: Webb Chairman Steps Down
abstract: LEAD: Robert K. Swanson has resigned as chairman, chief executive and a director of the Del E. Webb Corporation. He mentioned health reasons.

headline: FNN Moves Into the Spotlight
abstract: LEAD: For Financial News Network, the cable television channel that covers daily stock market activity, last week presented the long-sought chance to make a reputation for itself.

headline: Investors to Seek Control of USG
abstract: LEAD: An investment group consisting of the Texas investors Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown said that it had decided to seek control of the USG Corporation and had hired Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. to act as its financial adviser.

headline: State Dept. Promise of Emergency Funds for U.N. Provokes Dispute
abstract: LEAD: A decision by the State Department to promise the United Nations $90 million in emergency financing is arousing political controversy in the Administration and on Capitol Hill.

abstract: LEAD: Wickes Companies Inc., streamlining further, said today that it planned to sell three operating units and expected to receive more than the book value of $600 million. The company plans to use the proceeds to retire debt, repurchase stock and possibly make acquisitions.

abstract: LEAD: WITH the Rockwell International Corporation scheduled to end production of its B-1B strategic bomber next spring, most Wall Street analysts carry a ''neutral'' opinion on the stock.

headline: Consumers Held Confident
abstract: LEAD: American consumers' confidence in the economy rose to the highest level in almost 15 years in September as people were cheered by the declining jobless rate, the Conference Board said yesterday.

headline: Castle & Cooke Has Amfac Stake
abstract: LEAD: Amfac Inc., planning to retrench around its Hawaiian land holdings, said that Castle & Cooke Inc., another leading island land owner, had acquired a 4.9 percent interest in Amfac and was seeking permission under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act to buy nearly 15 percent.

headline: 50.07 Drop Puts Dow At 1,924.40
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices plunged yesterday, amid what traders and analysts described as fears over the dollar and the arrival of another futures-related ''triple witching hour.''

headline: Patents; Safeguard for Appliance Immersed in Water
abstract: LEAD: An electrical shock hazard protection system was patented this week for the Leviton Manufacturing Company, Little Neck, Queens. It is intended to protect people if an electrical appliance is accidentally immersed in water. Bernard Gershen, Saul Rosenbaum and James N. Pearse were granted patent 4,709,293.

headline: Counterbid Seen In Martell Case
abstract: LEAD: The London liquor and hotel group, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., said it might bid for Martell S.A., the cognac concern that has agreed to be acquired by the Seagram Company of Canada. Seagram said Wednesday that it would buy the 40 percent of Martell's stock owned by the company's founding family for 2,500 francs, or about $450, a share.

headline: Chirac Linked to Iran Arms Sales
abstract: LEAD: France's arms dealings with Iran, which began in 1983 under President Francois Mitterrand, continued as late as this summer under his political rival, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, French newspapers reported today.

headline: HOW TO DESTROY THE 2,611 MISSILES
abstract: LEAD: The text of the treaty signed today by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev spells out how hundreds of American and Soviet inspectors will insure that 2,611 American and Soviet missiles are smashed, exploded, crushed, burned or launched to be destroyed.

headline: Banks and Insurers Irate Over Accounting Rule
abstract: LEAD: Banks and property-and-casualty insurers, their earnings already weak, are furious over a new accounting rule that is likely to depress their earnings further.

headline: Son Succeeds Father As National City Head
abstract: LEAD: Call the National City Bancorporation in Minneapolis and chances are that David L. Andreas will answer the phone. At least he did yesterday, while his secretary was out getting lunch. The informal Mr. Andreas is the new chairman and chief executive of the bank holding company.

headline: Treasury Sales Limited This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury auctions are limited this week to the three- and six-month bill issues sold every Monday. Except for a two-year note issue and one-year bills expected next week, government securities dealers do not expect any Treasury offerings other than short-term bills until the last half of December.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN FLOWERS
abstract: LEAD: SUSAN OVERTON, manager of Ana's flower shop in Riverside, Calif., calls the year-end holidays the ''big profit time of year.'' Chuck Alexander, owner of eight Alexander's Flowers shops around Cleveland, relies on the period after Thanksgiving for 35 percent of sales. A member of the Florists' Transworld Delivery Association, Mr.

headline: Patents; Improving Production Of Therapeutic Proteins
abstract: LEAD: Two patents issued this week to the Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company in Emeryville, Calif., are directed toward the use of a particular microorganism, bacillus subtilis, in genetic engineering. Patent Nos. 4,711,843 and 4,711,844 were granted to Dr. Shing Chang, vice president for research.

headline: Khmer Leader Sets Terms for New Talks
abstract: LEAD: The leader of the largest civilian Cambodian rebel organization says he will join Prince Norodom Sihanouk in reconciliation talks with the Phnom Penh Government, but only if Hanoi will first give a public assurance that it will withdraw its troops from Cambodia when the negotiation process begins.

headline: PATENTS; A Device to Collect Urine Samples
abstract: LEAD: Dr. Richard C. Fuisz of Bethlehem, Pa., noticed the difficulty of obtaining urine samples from infants or senile adults. He was granted patent No. 4,700,714 this week for a collecting device.

headline: Cannon Kills 5 in Spain
abstract: LEAD: A cannon misfired today during the re-enactment of a 15th-century battle between Christians and Moors and five people were killed and 33 wounded. The blast in this Mediterranean coastal town occurred when a spark from the cannon detonated 66 pounds of gunpowder in a nearby box, officials said.

headline: Memorex Offers to Pay $911 Million for Telex
abstract: LEAD: The Telex Corporation, which has been fighting a takeover bid from the New York financier Asher B. Edelman, said yesterday that it had received a proposal from Memorex International N.V. to acquire the company for cash and securities valued at $62 a share, or about $911 million.

headline: Kaisertech Leader Is Nursing Wounds
abstract: LEAD: Alan E. Clore, the British-born financier, is nursing two big financial wounds in the United States as a result of the stock market's plunge.

headline: U.S. Court Dismisses Charge On Iran-Contra Arms Dealer
abstract: LEAD: A Federal appeals court set aside a contempt citation today against an arms dealer who refused to give the special counsel, Lawrence E. Walsh, records of eight foreign companies involved in the Iran-contra affair.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Taft Sale Cleared
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the transfer of broadcasting licenses held by the Taft Broadcasting Company, clearing the way for a $1.44 billion buyout of the company. Taft shareholders are selling the media company to an investor group, TFBA Limited Partnership, that includes the FMI Financial Corporation, which is headed by the Cincinnati investor Carl H.

headline: Nationwide's Mortgage Bid
abstract: LEAD: First Nationwide Bank, in a move to increase its reach to 24 states and double its mortgage business, said it plans to buy the mortgage subsidiary of the Imperial Corporation of America. Terms were not disclosed. First Nationwide said its acquisition of the ICA Mortage Corporation of San Diego would not affect its continuing interest in acquiring the Financial Corporation of America, the parent of American Savings, the nation's largest savings and loan association.

headline: Delaware Merger Rules
abstract: LEAD: A special committee of the Delaware Bar Association last night approved, as expected, new rules giving companies incorporated there more protection against takeovers. The rules could have a major impact since many leading companies are incorporated in Delaware.

headline: MORE CHANGE DUE IN CHINA'S ECONOMY
abstract: LEAD: The acting Chinese party leader, Zhao Ziyang, said today China must intensify the restructuring of its economy along Western lines if it is to escape poverty.

headline: Bank Merger Set In Pennsylvania
abstract: LEAD: Pennbancorp and the Union National Corporation said they had agreed to a merger that would create a $6.5 billion institution which would become the sixth-largest bank holding company in Pennsylvania. Under the terms of the agreement, Pennbancorp and Union National shareholders would each receive about 50 percent of the common shares of the new parent on a fully diluted basis.

headline: MEETING WITH CHINA SET ON CAR VENTURE
abstract: LEAD: Officials of the Big Three automobile companies will meet with a delegation from China next month to discuss establishing a large joint venture to produce cars in that country.

headline: Goodyear Net Decreases 2%
abstract: LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the world's largest tire company, said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 2 percent, to $178.7 million, from $182.3 million a year ago.

headline: Mubarak Re-elected to Run Egypt
abstract: LEAD: Egyptians voting in a referendum gave President Hosni Mubarak, the only candidate, six more years in office by a majority of 97.1 percent, the Government said today.

headline: Police Shoot in Air To Disperse Strikers At Rally in Manila
abstract: LEAD: The police fired in the air to disperse a strike rally today as thousands of workers began what militant unions called a week of protests for higher pay.

headline: Fallen Apples Reduce Hudson Valley's Yield
abstract: LEAD: Ripe red apples on the ground in many New York State orchards are a sign that difficult financial times may lie ahead for some farmers.

headline: 1,000 Jobs To Be Lost At Kidder
abstract: LEAD: In the latest sign of Wall Street's foreboding view of the coming year, Kidder, Peabody & Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,000 jobs, or roughly 15 percent of its work force, as part of a stringent cost-cutting program.

headline: Economic Scene; World System Seeks Stability
abstract: LEAD: AFTER a week of intense discussions here among leading European and American economists and politicians, an agenda can be constructed of the critical problems to be solved if the stock market collapse is to be prevented from becoming a greater catastrophe.

headline: Trade Data Set Off A Market Plunge
abstract: LEAD: A brutal week for stocks gave the bull market its first serious correction since 1984 and even provoked some traders to start writing obituaries for the bull. The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 235.48 during the week, to close at 2,246.73. The daily action was even more spectular with what was thought to be a record plunge of 95.46 on Wednesday, followed by a 57.61-point dive on Thursday and then the real topper, a plummet of 108.36 on Friday.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:       $         Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.75   8.75   7.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.47   7.42   5.78        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.68   6.67   5.05        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.86   6.85   5.15        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   9.56   9.45   7.05        30-YR.

headline: Kodak-Matsushita Battery Venture
abstract: LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Matsushita Group of Japan have agreed to create a jointly managed battery factory in the United States. Kodak already sells alkaline batteries made by Matsushita. The new plant, which is scheduled to be built in 1988, would make batteries for both Kodak and the Matshushita Electric Corporation of America, a Kodak spokesman, Henry Kaska, said.

headline: Storm Surprises Truk Island; 5 Are Dead Amid Wide Ruin
abstract: LEAD: A tropical storm with 70-mile-an-hour winds slammed into the capital island of the Pacific archipelago of Truk early today, killing five people and destroying most of the buildings.

headline: Panel Says Futures Markets Did Not Cause Stock Plunge
abstract: LEAD: An independent panel appointed by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it had found no evidence that the futures markets accelerated the stock market's huge plunge on Oct. 19.

headline: Airbus Dispute Easing
abstract: LEAD: The European Community today reported progress in a dispute over aid to Airbus Industrie. A London meeting next week will explore American complaints that the plane maker gets unfair government subsidies from West Germany, France, Britain and Spain.

headline: A Tax Surcharge
abstract: LEAD:  To the Editor:

headline: 3 Car Bombs Kill One and Wound 40 in Pakistan
abstract: LEAD: Three car bombs exploded in two downtown shopping areas today, killing one person and wounding 40 people, the authorities said.

headline: Software Curb Eased In Brazil
abstract: LEAD: President Jose Sarney of Brazil today signed into law a computer software bill, but he eliminated provisions that would have set tariffs of up to 200 percent on imported software and imposed criminal penalties for using illegal software.

headline: A Push for All-Business Radio
abstract: LEAD: The collapse of stock prices last month touched off a surge in demand for news about business and finance. Consumers cleaned out newsstands and eagerly scanned the airwaves for the latest reports of market activity around the world.

headline: Sikh Violence in Punjab A Threat to Indian Unity
abstract: LEAD: The Sikh religion's holiest shrine, which used to bustle with thousands of worshipers, sits quiet and nearly empty here. Sikhs and others say fear keeps them away.

headline: BankAmerica Confirms Investment by Japanese
abstract: LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it would sell $350 million of new securities to Japanese financial companies, an action that will strengthen the ailing bank.

headline: U.N. and Arabs Protesting a Move In Congress to Shut P.L.O. Mission
abstract: LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar joined angry Arab representatives today in protesting a Congressional move to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission here.

headline: Curb on Program Trading Is Eased
abstract: LEAD: Relaxing one of its key bans on program trading since the stock market plunge two and a half weeks ago, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would now allow major brokerage houses to execute program trades for their own accounts.

headline: Another Uptick In Interest Rates
abstract: LEAD: Up, up and away went the prime rate, as banks raised the key barometer to 9 percent, from 8 3/4. The increase was the fifth so far this year, and, although it was expected, it still sent a chill down the spines of the people who had been thinking about borrowing money. Short-term interest rates have been on the rise - indeed, yields in the bond market have been at or near two-year highs - and the prime has followed suit.

headline: INSECTICIDE ASSIGNED
abstract: LEAD: S. C. Johnson, after a five-agency competition, is assigning Raid insecticide to Mingo-Jones Advertising, specialists in advertising to the black community. It is the first time the brand will be getting such advertising, and the budget, according to the agency, is about $1 million.

headline: Unesco Director Fails To Get Majority Again
abstract: LEAD: Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, running for a third term as Unesco's Director General, placed first again tonight in the executive board's fourth ballot and again failed to achieve the required majority - but for the first time received fewer votes than in the previous round.

headline: Advertising; Difficulties In Client Relations
abstract: LEAD: As the effectiveness of advertising increases so does the difficulty of advertising effectively.

headline: Caroline Jones Agency Gets Bahamas Business
abstract: LEAD: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles didn't get all of the business of the Bahamas Ministry of Tourism. When D.M.B.&B. landed the $13 million account last week, there was still some left over for Caroline Jones Advertising.

headline: Split in 'Tombstone' Ranks
abstract: LEAD: Wall Street's ''tombstone'' ads may look stately, but the politicking that goes on before they ever appear in print can get downright undignified.

headline: Byrd Expects Trade Action
abstract: LEAD: Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, predicted today that lawmakers would approve a trade bill before year-end. Mr. Byrd's statement on the

headline: Industrial Advertising Study by McGraw-Hill
abstract: LEAD: McGraw-Hill has released the findings of a study on industrial advertising that should make some converts to the cause.

headline: Seoul Is Alive With Sounds Of Politicians
abstract: LEAD: In this city loud with the blare of car horns, the cries of hawkers and the late-night bang of construction, there is a new sound: the talk of politics.

headline: Shift Is Seen At Montedison
abstract: LEAD: Raul Gardini, the leader of Italy's huge agriculture-business concern Gruppo Ferruzzi, is preparing to take the helm of Montedison S.p.A. away from the chairman who had returned the chemical giant to profitabilty.

headline: Arbitrager Had Loss of $100 Million
abstract: LEAD: Comdisco Equities is one of the biggest arbitrage houses in the country, and Martin A. Weinstein, its head, is truly a big spender, quick to buy 300,000 shares or more of a takeover stock at a clip. In the volatile market days of the last two weeks, Mr. Weinstein and Comdisco lost $100 million, or half the firm's capital, then quickly made back $20 million.

headline: U.S. Plan Stirs GATT Debate
abstract: LEAD: An American proposal to open service industries to more international competition was criticized today by third-world nations anxious to protect their fledgling service sectors.

headline: Brother of Top Afghan Is Said to Defect to Rebels
abstract: LEAD: The younger brother of Afghanistan's Soviet-backed leader has defected to the Afghan rebels, according to American intelligence reports and foreign diplomats.

headline: Ford, Laden With Cash, Will Lift Dividend 33%
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company is finally finding some uses for the large cash hoard it has been building.

headline: Business and Health; Overpayments On H.M.O.'s
abstract: LEAD: IN the 1970's, new health maintenance organizations boasted that they could provide medical care for up to 40 percent less than traditional insurance plans. The savings would be enormous, H.M.O. officials assured benefit managers like Bruce I. Taylor of the GTE Corporation.

headline: Ryan Beck Layoffs
abstract: LEAD: The investment banking firm Ryan Beck & Company said it would lay off 45 of its 275 employees as part of a plan to reduce operating expenses. About 25 of the layoffs will come from the company's community capital group, which is being disbanded, a spokesman said. The group was involved in the conversion of thrift institutions from stock to mutual form.

headline: Reduced Bid Taken By McLeod Young
abstract: LEAD: Bank of Nova Scotia, one of Canada's leading banks, cut its takeover offer for the McLeod Young Weir Corporation, the brokerage firm, in a reaction to the stock market decline, and the bid was accepted. Bank of Nova Scotia reduced its offer to $52 (Canadian) a share, or a total of $419 million, from $60 a share, or $483 million.

headline: RETAIL SALES BRISK AS PRICES DECLINE AT PRODUCER LEVEL
abstract: LEAD: The nation's shoppers seem to have been largely unfazed by the stock-market plunge that began in mid-October, continuing to spend freely, the Commerce Department's monthly report on retail sales indicated today.

headline: Caledonian Set To Sell Stake
abstract: LEAD: Britain cleared the way today for the Scandanavian Airlines System to buy a minority stake in British Caledonian Airlines, but announced steps to insure the carrier would remain under British control.

headline: Market Place; Ford's Strategy On Cash Hoard
abstract: LEAD: DESPITE its recent spending, the Ford Motor Company is still flush with cash and looking at possible acquisitions in financial services, aerospace and electronics - businesses whose cycles tend to balance the volatile auto industry, which is four years into a boom.

headline: Man in the News; A 'Step-by-Step' Leader for Japan: Noboru Takeshita
abstract: LEAD: In Japan's feudal days, Noboru Takeshita once recalled, privileged people were carried on their journeys upon a litter. Naturally, there were the less fortunate who had to bear the litter, he said. And then there those whose lot in life was to make the straw sandals that the litter-bearers wore.

headline: BankAmerica Earns $54 Million in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: A little more than a year after A. W. Clausen reassumed the posts of chairman and chief executive of the BankAmerica Corporation, the company today reported third-quarter earnings of $54 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with a $23 million loss in the comparable 1986 period.

headline: Economic Scene; Rescuing The Dollar
abstract: LEAD: THE stock market had a worrisome day yesterday, and analysts rounded up the usual suspects: Some feared that the dollar might plummet if the central banks were unwilling to support it. Others worried that, in Washington, cutting the budget deficit was stalled. Still others feared the budget cuts might be too little (to rally the markets) or too much (for the economy to sustain).

headline: Using Heat in Treatment of Some Cancers
abstract: LEAD: MEDICAL historians trace the idea of fighting cancer tumors with heat to Hippocrates, who successfully treated his fellow Greeks in baths of hot sand 24 centuries ago.

headline: Advertising; Nissan Debut For Chiat/Day
abstract: LEAD: The long-awaited Chiat/Day advertising for its new client, the Nissan Motor Corporation, will flash onto the TV screens of a waiting nation on ''Monday Night Football'' on the ABC-TV Network.

headline: S.E.C. Was Ready To Support a Halt
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the agency would have supported a shutdown of the New York Stock Exchange if top Big Board officials had decided to halt trading on Tuesday.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Kuwait Registering 3 Tankers for British Flag
abstract: LEAD: British officials said today that Kuwait had registered two of its tankers to fly the British flag and was in the process of registering a third.

headline: Kenya Charges a Plot by the Klan
abstract: LEAD: Seven United States missionaries have been deported from Kenya amid local news reports that they were involved in a plot supported by the Ku Klux Klan to overthrow the Government of President Daniel arap Moi.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Wayne B. Fulcher has rejoined McCann-Erickson/San Francisco as senior vice president and management supervisor.

headline: Blue-Chip Leader for Task Force: Nicholas Frederick Brady
abstract: LEAD: Nicholas F. Brady once described himself as the kind of man who likes to prove the experts wrong.

headline: Greyhound Begins Rural Bus Service
abstract: LEAD: Greyhound Lines Inc. began a pilot program for rural bus service in Tennessee that is expected to spread nationwide and revive the flagging public transportation industry, its officials said. The project links vans from eight rural transportation agencies statewide with Greyhound buses in larger cities, similar to the hub system used by airlines.

headline: Major Decisions in Insider Trading Law
abstract: LEAD: Trading of securities by company executives based on inside information has been illegal throughout much of the history of corporate America. It was not until the 1960's that Federal authorities sought to broaden the notion of ''insider'' to include printers, financial analysts and journalists. Following are some of the major developments - before yesterday's Winans decision - in insider trading law.

headline: CANADA MAY DROP NUCLEAR SUB PLAN
abstract: LEAD: Only five months after it was announced, Canada's plan to join the small group of nations that operate nuclear-powered submarines has run into difficulties with budget planners at home and among officials in Washington who could veto the transfer of American nuclear technology for the submarines.

headline: Treasury Issues Show Few Changes
abstract: LEAD: Dealers hurriedly marked down prices of Treasury securities late yesterday after a late surge in the stock market, then they marked them back up after underwriters of the four-part, $1.5 billion Southland Corporation offering reported the deal as ''done.''

headline: Earnings Rise at 3 Retailers
abstract: LEAD: Three leading retailing chains yesterday reported improved earnings for the third quarter.

headline: An Unpopular Bid to Go Private
abstract: LEAD: AMONG companies that tangled with short sellers this year, few were as combative as Commonwealth Savings Association of Houston. In the spring, Commonwealth tried to organize other targeted companies to resist the bears. Lately, though, Commonwealth has been preoccupied with its bad real estate loans.

headline: 3:30 P.M. Close On Big Board
abstract: LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would operate on reduced trading hours next week but that it was eliminating all restrictions on program trading.

headline: Verity Warns Japan on Curb
abstract: LEAD: The United States could retaliate if Japan continues to bar American companies from participating in public works projects, Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. said today.

headline: Corrections
abstract: LEAD: A table on Oct. 25 comparing stock market averages misstated the percent change of the American Stock Exchange market value index from Aug. 12, 1982, to Oct. 22, 1987. It was 127 percent.

headline: Shell Resists Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group has threatened to leave Brazil if a proposal to put the distribution of petroleum products solely in the hands of Government companies becomes law. It is the second economic issue this month pitting Government interests against those of multinational companies. Autolatina, a venture of the Ford Motor Company and West Germany's Volkswagenwerk A.G., has challenged the Brazilian Government's system of price controls in court.

headline: India in a New Offer to Tamil Rebels
abstract: LEAD: India made a new offer of amnesty to Tamil guerrillas in Sri Lanka today if they surrendered their arms to an Indian peacekeeping force, an Indian diplomat said here. There was no immediate reply from the guerrillas.

headline: Brazilians Sue A.T.&T. Unit
abstract: LEAD: Three Brazilian companies are suing the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's international subsidiary for approximately $1.4 billion.

headline: Specialty Health Care Booms
abstract: LEAD: Just as doctors did before them, hospital chains are discovering the attractions of hanging out a shingle that says specialist.

headline: Toyota U.S. Plant
abstract: LEAD: The Toyota Motor Company plans to invest about $200 million to build engines and axles in addition to cars at its new Kentucky plant site, a published report said. The Louisville Courier-Journal, quoting unidentified sources, said Japan's leading auto company's planned addition to its plant near Georgetown, Ky., could create up to 500 jobs.

headline: Peru Urged to Curb Abuses in Fighting Rebels
abstract: LEAD: Americas Watch, a human rights organization based in the United States, urged the Peruvian Government today to take stronger measures to prevent and punish abuses carried out by security forces in combating a Maoist guerrilla group.

headline: CONVENTIONAL ARMS ARE KEY IN NEXT ACCORD, REAGAN SAYS
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan, trying to reassure the European allies, said today that the United States intends to strengthen its conventional military forces in Europe and modernize its chemical weapons before it reaches any further arms control agreements with the Soviet Union.

headline: Spain Is Bullish on Its Market
abstract: LEAD: Alongside of Wall Street and other financial capitals, Spain's tiny stock market represented a speck in the international scheme of things in October as share prices plunged around the world. The Spanish are philosophical about the lack of attention, though.

headline: Salaries Begin to Rise For New Accountants
abstract: LEAD: In a move to compete with such higher-paying employers as investment firms and commercial banks, Price Waterhouse has given its beginning accountants a 20 percent pay increase, to $30,000 a year, while eliminating overtime pay.

headline: CENTRAL BANKERS IN TALKS
abstract: LEAD: As the presidents of the central banks of the major industrial nations gather here today, their major concern is when the dollar will stop falling.

headline: U.S. Links an Iran Envoy to Terrorism
abstract: LEAD: The State Department said today it has evidence that the new Iranian Ambassador to West Germany was one of the student militants involved in the 1979 seizure of the American hostages at the United States Embassy in Teheran.

headline: Housing Market Shows Unexpected Resiliency
abstract: LEAD: The housing market proved stronger at summer's end than had been expected, as sales of new homes rose 2.7 percent in August, the Government said today.

headline: C.F.T.C. To Analyze Trading
abstract: LEAD: The head of the independent Federal agency that regulates futures cautioned today that ''one should not jump to conclusions'' that computerized stock futures trading was a cause of the plunging market.

headline: Real Estate; Ad Firms' West Side Migration
abstract: LEAD: FOR decades advertising agencies were a mainstay in the office towers on the East Side of midtown Manhattan.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;
abstract: LEAD: The entertainer and businessman Merv Griffin has completed the purchase of the Beverly Hilton, but the $100.2 million price was less than what had been speculated. The 592-room hotel had been owned by the Hilton Hotels Corporation and the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

headline: Missing Korean Jet Is Said to Have Exploded
abstract: LEAD: South Korea said today that a Korean Air jetliner that disappeared in Southeast Asia last month was destroyed by a midair explosion, and a radio report said a woman suspected of planting a bomb in the plane had broken her silence.

headline: Libya Says Political Treaty With Algeria Is Near
abstract: LEAD: Libya and Algeria have reached agreement in principle on a treaty of political unity, Libya's chief delegate to the United Nations, Ali Treiki, said today.

headline: Battery Park Revenues To Back Housing Bonds
abstract: LEAD: With this week's bond sale by the Housing New York Corporation, New York City is taking a major step toward converting the financial success of the Battery Park City development in lower Manhattan into low-income housing in other parts of the city.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * John Kelleter has joined Caravetta Allen Kimbrough, Miami, part of the Omnicom Group, as senior vice president, director of marketing.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   9.00   9.00   7.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.67   7.14   5.83        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.06   5.23   5.20        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.88   6.02   5.26        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.77   8.72   7.18        30-YR. TREAS.

headline: Mathura Journal; Is the Raja Ready for War, or Losing His Steam?
abstract: LEAD: It had all the trappings of a political rally, except that the organizers insisted their cause was nonpolitical. In speech after speech, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was attacked by some of his most prominent former allies as tens of thousands of listeners applauded.

headline: Army's Leader in Niger Is Appointed President
abstract: LEAD: The army Chief of Staff was appointed as Niger's head of state today in a unanimous vote of the ruling Supreme Military Council, an official statement on state radio said.

headline: Market Place; Trump Hedging On Resorts Offer
abstract: LEAD: DONALD J. TRUMP, chairman and controlling stockholder of Resorts International Inc., hinted yesterday that he might revoke his tender offer of $15 a share for all of the company's class A common stock. The offer, made just two days ago, marked the latest chapter in the turbulent saga of the company that first brought legalized gambling to Atlantic

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Armco Inc., Middletown, Ohio, announced that it had signed an agreement with C. Itoh & Co. to build a $60 million cold rolling mill at the plant of an Armco subsidiary, Armco Advanced Materials Corp., Butler, Pa.

headline: 8 Latin Chiefs Urge Cuba Role In Their Region
abstract: LEAD: The presidents of eight Latin American countries, meeting here for their first conference held without the participation of the United States, agreed today that Cuba should be invited to rejoin regional organizations from which it has been excluded for more than two decades.

headline: Lintas Relinquishing Timberland Account
abstract: LEAD: Lintas: New York announced Friday that it had resigned the account of the Timberland Corporation because it could not agree with the new management on basic strategy. The account, billing about $4 million a year, came to the agency in 1985.

headline: Fallout Continues, On and Off Wall St.
abstract: LEAD:  Deficit Reduction Sought  White House officials and Congressional leaders discussed compromises that could reduce the budget deficit and calm nervous financial markets. It was unclear whether President Reagan might agree to some tax increases.  Inquiry on Volatility  An investigation into this week's stock market activity has been ordered by the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: GENERAL ASSEMBLY HANDED SETBACKS TO U.S. AND SOVIET
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union both suffered setbacks on matters of importance to them at the United Nations during the General Assembly session that ended this week, diplomats say.

headline: Left and Right
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Japanese Stocks Show Slight Gains
abstract: LEAD: Following Wall Street's lead once again, the Tokyo stock market rallied modestly today after tumbling precipitously Friday on a cascade of bad news.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Cruise Line to Goodby; Seagram Wines to Grey
abstract: LEAD: There have been two account switches of national interest involving San Francisco agencies this week. Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein has boarded the Royal Viking Line, and Grey Advertising found its cup running over courtesy of the Seagram Classics Wine Company.

headline: NEW YORK CITY TO SELL NOTES
abstract: LEAD: New York City plans to sell up to $325 million of short-term notes in a competitive sale between Nov. 24 and Dec. 15, city officials announced yes-terday. In order to sell the notes when market conditions are most favora-ble, the city plans to give prospective underwriters 24 hours' advance no-tice of the bidding deadline.

headline: An Amnesty in Mozambique
abstract: LEAD: The Legislature offered amnesty today to guerrrillas who surrender to the authorities or international organizations by the end of 1988. The rebels of the Mozambique National Resistance have been fighting for 10 years to overthrow the Marxist Government.

headline: The Reactions To Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: A day after Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech on the Bolshevik Revolution, American scholars drew sharply differing lessons about its meaning.

headline: New Council for Haiti Vote Sworn In
abstract: LEAD: Clement Maurice Barthelemy was eating dinner with his family Friday night when he heard his name crackle across the radio: the Government had appointed him to the civilian council that is to organize the next presidential election.

headline: Mexico on Sidelines in Peace Efforts
abstract: LEAD: When Foreign Minister Bernardo Sepuulveda Amor appeared before a foreign affairs committee of the Mexican Congress last week, the opposition peppered him with variations on a single theme: Why is Mexico not playing a more active role in the Central American peace process?

headline: Kraft's Profit Rises Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Kraft Inc. reported a nearly sixfold increase in third-quarter earnings, mainly because of strong sales of batteries and international food products.

headline: In Brazil, Evangelicals Are on Rise
abstract: LEAD: Most Friday evenings, members of a local Pentecostal church gather near the water's edge on Copacabana Beach for intense and emotional prayer sessions at which they try to exorcise ''diabolical'' African spirits from prospective converts.

headline: U.S. Implicates Military Contractor in Kickbacks
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department implicated a large arms contractor and six other American companies today in a $6.8 million kickback scheme on Philippine military contracts.

headline: Arab Is Killed in Gaza and Another Dies of Wounds
abstract: LEAD: Two more Palestinians died today as a result of clashes with security forces in the occupied territories.

headline: MOZAMBIQUE IS OFFERED HELP AGAINST REBELS
abstract: LEAD: Britain and other Commonwealth nations are offering military and economic assistance to Mozambique to protect railways, ports and other development projects against attack by South African-backed guerillas.

headline: Malaysian Crackdown Shatters a Bright Image
abstract: LEAD: Among the free-enterprise nations of Southeast Asia Malaysia always seemed poised for long-term success, diplomats and business leaders say.

headline: Deficit Discussions Start on Capitol Hill
abstract: LEAD: White House officials and Congressional leaders began talks today to see if they could reach a compromise that would reduce the budget deficit and calm nervous financial markets.

headline: PARAGUAY DECIDING FATE OF PRISONER
abstract: LEAD: Paraguay's longest-serving political prisoner completed a 25-year prison term today, but he was not immediately set free.

headline: A CHALLENGE TO GORBACHEV IS LINKED TO SUMMIT DELAY
abstract: LEAD: A key supporter of Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused him of fostering a cult of personality at a party meeting last week, igniting a political crisis that may have caused the delay in arrangements for a summit meeting, according to Soviet officials.

headline: ARMS TALKS DELAY WORRIES OFFICIALS
abstract: LEAD: American and Soviet negotiators have not yet agreed on some important verification procedures for the treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles that is to be signed next month, Administration officials say.

headline: Southland Proposal To Finance Buyout
abstract: LEAD: The Southland Corporation's on-again, off-again attempts to become a private company were on again yesterday as its investment bankers came up with a new plan to finance the $5.1 billion deal.

headline: U.S. Note Sales Highlight Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury auctions this week consist of today's regular sale of three- and six-month bills, followed by four-year notes tomorrow and seven-year notes on Wednesday. The Treasury plans to sell $12.8 billion of three- and six-month bills, $7.25 billion of four-year notes and $6.75 billion of seven-year notes.

headline: Crude Oil, Off Sharply, Rallies to Close Higher
abstract: LEAD: Crude oil futures took a roller-coaster ride today on the New York Mercantile Exchange, posting sharp losses early, then recovering to close higher in a late rally, traders said.

headline: Ethiopia Aid Lags, U.S. Groups Say
abstract: LEAD: American relief agencies are having difficulty mustering help for Ethiopia, which is again facing the threat of drought-induced famine that took hundreds of thousands of lives three years ago.

headline: Iran Sea Attack Reported Foiled
abstract: LEAD: Dozens of Iranian Revolutionary Guard speedboats raced in darkness toward a joint Saudi-Kuwaiti oilfield this morning that sends more than $4 million a day to Iraq's war efforts, according to diplomats in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Quebec Journal; Under the Fleur-de-Lis, All Canada Hails Levesque
abstract: LEAD: Rene Levesque's memory was honored here today not only by those who shared his dream of nationhood for Quebec but also by the leaders of the Canada he rejected.

headline: 5 Soviet Generals Die In Crash of an Aircraft
abstract: LEAD: Five Soviet generals who served on the General Staff or in command positions of a Soviet Army group have been killed in an air crash, the Defense Ministry newspaper said today.

headline: Strong Quake Kills 2 in Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: A strong earthquake rocked the Tokyo region this morning, killing 2 people, injuring 10 and causing buildings to sway violently for several minutes, authorities said.

headline: New Chief Executive For Martin Marietta
abstract: LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation announced its expected management transition yesterday. Thomas G. Pownall, who kept the company out of the hands of raiders, relinquished the chief executive's post to Norman R. Augustine, a former Under Secretary of the Army and author of a ''Murphy's Law'' type of book called ''Augustine's Laws.

headline: Sandinista Defector Being Questioned by U.S.
abstract: LEAD: United States officials said today that they were intensively questioning a Nicaraguan military defector to determine his value to them.

headline: Kirkpatrick Is Cheered in Managua
abstract: LEAD: Clouds broke and the sun shone on Jeane J. Kirkpatrick here Sunday as she drove a wildly cheering crowd of Nicaraguans to the brink of delirium.

headline: New Chairman Seeks A Stable Computerland
abstract: LEAD: Despite its pre-eminence as the world's largest retailer of personal computers, the Computerland Corporation has its share of problems, including lengthy litigation, fractious franchisees and declining margins. But to William Y. Tauscher, who took over as chairman last week, the chain, based in Hayward, Calif., seems a good investment.
