headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * American Stock Exchange Inc., named Joseph B. Stefanelli senior vice president, options marketing.

headline: Home Equity Loans Studied
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board may soon order banks and thrift institutions to give consumers more information about the terms and conditions of home equity loans, Martha Seger, a Fed member, said today.

headline: Relief Plane in Ethiopia
abstract: LEAD: A Belgian Air Force Hercules transport plane arrived in Ethiopia today to airlift emergency food to drought victims in the northern province of Tigre, where rebel ambushes are hindering transport by road. Jean-Jacques Fresard, the delegate of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Ethiopia, said the plane would start work Monday, ferrying more than 70 tons of food each day from Asmara, the capital of Eritrea province, to Mekele, the capital of Tigre.

headline: Soviet Is Aiding Nicaragua In Buildup, Defector Says
abstract: LEAD: A former senior officer in the Nicaraguan Army who defected recently to the United States has told American officials that the Soviet Union is preparing to send large quantities of new weapons to Nicaragua, despite provisions of the new regional peace accord that called for limiting the size of national armies in Central

headline: Savings Units, Banks in Loss
abstract: LEAD: The 13,888 banks and savings and loan associations in the United States lost $5.4 billion in the first half of this year, according to Sheshunoff & Company, a bank-rating service, in contrast to earnings of $9.03 billion a year earlier.

headline: Coke Invests In a Film Deal
abstract: LEAD: A group of five entertainment industry veterans, including Rob Reiner, the producer, said today that they had founded a new film venture called Castle Rock Entertainment that will receive $30 million in start-up money from the Coca-Cola Company, which will become a 40 percent shareholder in the new company.

headline: Sandinistas Again Refuse Talks With Contra Leaders
abstract: LEAD: Despite assertions at home and abroad they have not done enough to fulfill terms of a regional peace accord that are to go into effect next week, Nicaraguan leaders today again indicated they would not accept political talks with contra leaders.

headline: Wall Street Gripped by Layoff Fear
abstract: LEAD: Wall Street is facing its coldest Christmas in years.

headline: Four Haiti Candidates Unite And Demand Regime Resign
abstract: LEAD: The four leading presidential candidates united today in opposition to the army-dominated provisional Government and, in a hardening of their position, demanded that the Government step down.

headline: Seeking a Versatile 'Easy' Camera
abstract: LEAD: THE popularity of the ''point and shoot'' 35-millimeter camera has significantly affected the photography business in recent years. The automatic cameras - like the Canon Sure Shot, Minolta Freedom and Nikon One-Touch - make it easy for a beginner to take good photographs, buoying interest in conventional still photography and revitalizing the industry.

headline: China Names Acting Prime Minister
abstract: LEAD: Li Peng, a 59-year-old Soviet-educated engineer, was named Acting Prime Minister of China today. He succeeds Zhao Ziyang, who gave up the post to devote himself full time to his duties as head of China's 46-million-member Communist Party.

headline: China Theory on Plunge
abstract: LEAD: China, in its first comment on the collapse of world stock prices, said today that the drop was an inevitable consequence of the ''casino economy'' in the United States. Pu Shan, the director of the influential Institute of World Politics and Economy, said that the plunge of prices on the New York and other world exchanges had been expected for some time.

headline: Harcourt Sells 3 Units
abstract: LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. will sell its History Book Club and two smaller clubs for $25 million to the Book-of-the-Month Club, a division of Time Inc., Harcourt's chairman, William Jovanovich, said Friday. The sale, which includes the Pre-School and Instructor book clubs, will be concluded Tuesday, he said.

headline: Potential Buyer For Shoe-Town
abstract: LEAD: Shoe-Town Inc., a discount footwear chain, said a potential buyer had indicated an interest in the company. The news sent Shoetown shares up $1.625, to $7, on the New York Stock Exchange. At yesterday's closing price, the sale price would be about $75 million. Shoe-Town, which operates 200 stores in 11 states, earned $5.5 million last year on sales of $142.4 million.

headline: Martell Counterbid From Grand Met
abstract: LEAD: The British hotel and liquor group Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. announced a counterbid in its quest against a Canadian rival, the Seagram Company, for control of Martell S.A., the French cognac maker. Grand Met, which makes Smirnoff vodka and other spirits, said it would offer 2,675 francs, or about $495, a share for Martell.

headline: Pro-Marcos Activity Persists but Ranks Thin
abstract: LEAD: Several dozen children were christened Ferdinand and Imelda at a small but emotional rally the other day to mark the 70th birthday of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

headline: 12 Tamils Reported Killed, 150 Captured in Indian Drive
abstract: LEAD: Indian troops killed 12 guerrillas and captured 150 in their drive to disarm Tamil separatists in northern and eastern Sri Lanka, the state radio said today.

headline: Manila Is Split Over Order To Oust Australian Reporter
abstract: LEAD: The Philippine Government ordered the expulsion of an Australian reporter today, revoked the order, then reinstated it in a bureaucratic tug of war.

headline: Bank Drops Eurobonds
abstract: LEAD: Toronto Dominion International, a unit of the Toronto Dominion Bank of Canada, has withdrawn from the Eurobond market, it said today. Eurobonds are bonds that pay interest in a currency outside the country of issue. Several banks have reduced Eurobond activity as unprofitable.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday began offering $300 million of 8 5/8 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.588 to yield 8.749 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Advertising;
abstract: LEAD: John Emmerling Inc. has been named the agency for Holsten Bier, a beer that Mr. Emmerling calls ''the Budweiser of West Germany.'' He said the client was planning to spend more than $1 million for advertising. At first it will all be in print - magazines probably - but before the end of the year there could be some dabbling in radio.

headline: Repurchase Offer By Florida Bank
abstract: LEAD: Hugh F. Culverhouse, the Tampa, Fla., investor, disclosed that Florida Commercial Banks Inc. had offered to repurchase his 1.54 million shares of the Miami-based bank holding company for $30 a share. In a filing Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Culverhouse said that he had been contacted last Thursday and last Friday by two different directors of Florida

headline: Advertising; In the Nile Valley, It's the Pyramids
abstract: LEAD: With the exception of the headline and illustration, the ads in the campaign for the new Helmsley Palace hotel will be pretty much alike. And even the headlines will change very little.

headline: The Dollar's Drop
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * C. R. Bard Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., a maker of surgical products, elected George A. Davis executive vice president and Terence C. Brady Jr. senior vice president.

headline: Northrop Has Profit
abstract: LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said today that it earned $34.1 million, or 73 cents a share, in the third quarter. The aerospace company had lost $30.5 million in the period last year after taking a $90 million write-down on its highly classified research and development contract for the Air Force's Stealth bomber program.

headline: Eurotunnel Issue Weak
abstract: LEAD: Eurotunnel's offering of shares to the public is undersubscribed in Britain, with about 20 percent of the shares still in underwriters' hands, the company said today.

headline: One Killed and 4 Wounded In Gunfire at a Haitian Mass
abstract: LEAD: One man was killed and at least four people were wounded today when three gunmen fired into a memorial march for the victims of last month's election day violence.

headline: Guatemala to Meet With Rebels
abstract: LEAD: The Government and leftist rebels announced today that they would meet next week in Madrid in the first peace talks held in the 25 years of political violence here.

headline: Sihanouk Gets Pledge on Vietnam's Troops
abstract: LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk met again today with Prime Minister Hun Sen of the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government and said Hanoi pledged to pull its occupation troops from the country next year if the two could reach an agreement to settle their differences.

headline: Pactel Offers Stock in Unit
abstract: LEAD: California telephone operating company, said today that it would issue up to 15 million common shares in Pactel Personal Communications, the company's cellular telephone and paging unit. Further details of the offering were not announced, pending the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange

headline: Markets Mark Time In European Trading
abstract: LEAD: The dollar marked time and the prices of stocks were mixed and hardly changed in Europe today, with markets still uncertain about the value of recent Western efforts to shore up the dented global economy.

headline: Arab Summit Talks Opening Today
abstract: LEAD: The presidents, kings and emirs of the Arab world began to converge on this hilly capital today amid concern that failure to close ranks behind a united policy could polarize the Arab world into blocs of moderates and radicals for a long time to come.

headline: Crude Oil Falls a Fifth Day After an Early Rally Fizzles
abstract: LEAD: Crude oil cash and futures prices fell yesterday for the fifth day in a row after an early rally found little support. Futures prices of heating oil and unleaded gasoline also declined.

headline: Ford Raises Prices by 1.3%
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had raised prices of its 1988 cars by an average of 1.3 percent above 1987 models with similar equipment.

headline: Worry Grows That Korean Army Might Intervene in the Elections
abstract: LEAD: Serious concern has been raised here that South Korea's military might step in to cancel next week's presidential election or to nullify its results if the opposition wins.

headline: Mexico's Border Plants Thrive on Weak Peso
abstract: LEAD: The rapid spread of foreign-owned assembly plants along the Mexican border will likely be sustained because of the latest plunge in the peso's value, industry officials here said.

headline: OTHER VOICES: David Riesman; Days of Distrust
abstract: LEAD: Excerpts from an interview with David Riesman, professor emeritus of sociology at Harvard University:

headline: The Big Board Battle to Contain the Damage
abstract: LEAD: BY noon Tuesday a groggy John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, had come to his wit's end. The tiny pool of ''buy orders'' on hand at the opening had dried up. And temporarily closing the Big Board seemed like the only way to prevent the market from another debilitating tailspin on top of

headline: A Shift in Policy
abstract: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the Government managed to resist the impulse for dramatic action, such as closing the exchanges, it was forced by last week's stock market plunge to make some abrupt and important policy changes. One result could be a breakthrough in the long political impasse over the Federal budget deficit - one of the main causes, economists say, of the market's instability.

headline: ISRAELIS REINFORCE GAZA STRIP TROOPS
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army poured reinforcements into the Gaza Strip today, trying to quell a wave of Palestinian unrest.

headline: REPORT WAS A GROUP EFFORT
abstract: LEAD: The report of the House and Senate committees investigating the Iran-contra affair is that rarest of species: a well written, readable Government report.

headline: Statement on Meeting
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of the statement issued today by Karl Otto Pohl, president of West Germany's central bank and chairman of the Group of 10 central bank governors. The group consists of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Sweden.

headline: Conferees Complete Bill For $23 Billion Tax Rise
abstract: LEAD: Congressional tax aides worked out the final details today of a $23 billion tax-increase package approved late Thursday night by House and Senate negotiators.

headline: G.M. Hughes Adds
abstract: LEAD: The G.M. Hughes Electronics Corporation said that it had acquired M/A-COM Telecommunications of Germantown, Md., for $105 million. The company, which was a subsidiary of M/A-COM Inc., of Burlington, Mass., manufactures digital communications equipment used in satellite systems that link subscribers - mainly businesses with widely dispersed branches - in much the same way that telephone systems do.

headline: A Million-Contract Day
abstract: LEAD: For the first time in the history of the Chicago Board of Trade, more than a million futures and options contracts were traded during a single session, the exchange said today. The record-breaking day came Wednesday, when 1,031,714 contracts changed hands, surpassing the previous mark of 918,411 contracts set April 9.

headline: Key Hearing In Robins Suit
abstract: LEAD: The A.H. Robins Company, maker of the Dalkon Shield, and the thousands of women who say they were harmed by the contraceptive will square off Thursday in a long-awaited hearing to determine how dearly Robins will have to pay.

headline: Good '88 Seen By Executives
abstract: LEAD: Executives of the nation's largest corporations predicted today that the economy would weather rising interest rates and higher inflation and be strong through the 1988 Presidential election.

headline: Thatcher Urges Budget Action
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today urged White House and Congressional budget negotiators to act decisively and said big cuts in United States deficits were needed to restore confidence to the world's financial markets.

headline: Army Coup in South African Homeland
abstract: LEAD: A 32-year-old officer with the rank of general in the tiny army of nominally independent Transkei, the largest of South Africa's black homelands, staged his second coup today in less than four months and installed himself in power.

headline: Senate Defies Reagan on Arms Issues
abstract: LEAD: The Senate, taking an unusually defiant stand on arms control, approved legislation today that Republicans said would tie the President's hands in negotiations with the Soviet Union.

headline: Optimism at Ford
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company remains optimistic about the 1988 market because the lower stock market has not forced November car sales below levels a year earlier and truck sales have actually risen, the company's chairman, Donald E. Petersen, said. Mr. Petersen told reporters that he expected overall industry vehicle sales of about 15 million in 1988, with trucks making up one-third of the market.

headline: Plugging the Leaks in Your Tax Shelter
abstract: LEAD: BEFORE the Tax Reform Act of 1986, many high-bracket investors bought tax shelters. They could use the losses from these deals to offset earned income, or income from such traditional investments as stocks and bonds. But the new law imposed tough restrictions on shelters, and did so retroactively.

headline: Bleak Season For the War On Apartheid
abstract: LEAD: A police crackdown and an economic recession have set back but not broken a longstanding campaign of resistance to apartheid in this black township.

headline: For Munsingwear, A Goal Is Fulfilled
abstract: LEAD: Munsingwear Inc., which has seen several top executives come and go in the last several years, said yesterday that it had named William W. Compton as its new president and chief operating officer.

headline: G.M. to Shut Plant And Lay Off 3,700
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would close indefinitely its 3,700-worker assembly plant in Framingham, Mass., because of slow sales of the Chevrolet Celebrity and the Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera.

headline: Advertising; G.E. Has Four Spots Ready for World Series
abstract: LEAD: Among the advertisers on television broadcasts of the World Series will be General Electric, which has four new 60-second commercials from Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn. These ads have the same high-quality production values as those of the last campaign, and although the line ''We bring good things to life'' seems not to be as dominant as it was previously, it is there.

headline: G.O.P. to Report on Iran Deal Special to The New York Times
abstract: LEAD: Republican members of the House committee on the Iran-contra affair have concluded that President Reagan did not know about the diversion of profits from the Iran arms sales to Nicaraguan rebel groups, Congressional officials said today.

headline: Oil Rigs Increase in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The number of operating rotary rigs, an indicator of the oil industry's health, rose by 33 last week, to 1,174 -a big jump over last year's 910 rigs, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. In Canada, the weekly rig count fell by 38, to 277, compared with 113 a year ago, when oil prices touched bottom.

headline: Mickey's Magazine
abstract: LEAD: Donald E. Welch's latest entry into the kiddie magazine field will be Mickey Mouse magazine, a colorful quarterly for the 3-to-9-year-old set due out next month. It will join such Welsh Publishing Group winners as Muppet, Barbie and He-Man and the Masters of the Universe magazines and, of course, will carry advertising.

headline: Developer Has New Job At Management Firm
abstract: LEAD: James R. Endler has been named president of Lehrer Bovis McGovern Inc., an international construction management firm.

headline: American Economy Is Reported Shifting To Exports to Grow
abstract: LEAD: The American economy, long dominated by its free-spending consumers, is rapidly being transformed into one whose growth depends heavily on producing goods for foreign markets.

headline: 2 More Arab Nations Renew Full Ties With Egypt
abstract: LEAD: Kuwait and Morocco became the latest Arab nations to resume full diplomatic relations with Egypt today. Iraq and the United Arab Emirates took similar steps this week.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  Market Turmoil

headline: Wertheim's Chairman Gets Key Job at Ames
abstract: LEAD: James A. Harmon, an investment banker who has served on the board of Ames Department Stores Inc. since 1967, was named chairman yesterday, succeeding Herbert Gilman, one of three brothers who founded the chain.

headline: OTHER VOICES: Martin Marty; Everywhere, Paper Cities
abstract: LEAD: Excerpts from an interview with Martin E. Marty, a professor of history of modern Christianity at the University of Chicago:

headline: Investment Strategist Recommending Cautious Re-entry
abstract: LEAD: A month ago investors were wondering whether the five-year-old bull market in stocks was nearing an end. Today Byron R. Wien is actually wondering whether the end of a bear market is at hand.

headline: British Airways Buys 50.02% of Caledonian
abstract: LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. said today that it had acquired a controlling stake in the money-losing British Caledonian Airways, ending a six-month battle with Scandinavian Airlines System.

headline: Arms Scandal Puts Mitterrand on Defensive
abstract: LEAD: An Iran arms scandal that has exploded on the French political scene has thrown President Francois Mitterrand and his Socialist Party on the defensive just as he is deciding on whether to run for a second term.

headline: Upjohn Swine Vaccine
abstract: LEAD: A new bioengineered vaccine against pseudo-rabies, a swine disease, won approval for marketing today from the Agriculture Department, the Upjohn Company said. The Tolvid vaccine, developed by Upjohn, is produced by Diamond Scientific. Pseudo-rabies is a contagious virus that affects about 6.4 million, or 8 percent, of the nation's 80 million hogs.

headline: Listen to Workers
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Renault Debt Plan
abstract: LEAD: The French Cabinet approved a plan to transform the state-owned car maker Renault into a limited liability company, involving a write-off of $2 billion in debt and no more Government subsidies. A Government spokesman said the bill would be discussed in Parliament this autumn. The Government announced last week that it was writing off 12 billion francs (about $2 billion), or nearly a quarter of Renault's debt.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''Liedtke should send a big Christmas card to John Mckinley at Texaco to thank him for buying Getty at the top of the oil market.''  Bryan Jacoboski,  an analyst at Paine Webber

headline: Modest Rally Pushes Stock Index Prices Up
abstract: LEAD: The market for Standard and Poor's 500 stock- index futures staged a modest rally today, touched off by a wave of institutional buying.

headline: NEC Chip Output
abstract: LEAD: The NEC Corporation plans to start mass production of four-megabit dynamic random access memory chips, the next generation of computer chips, in late 1989, an NEC spokesman said. It seems that NEC will be the first producer to be able to make the chips available commercially. The company also plans to increase production of one-megabit D-RAM's from 500,000 units a month, to 2 million units a month by March 1988.

headline: Texas Banks Allowed to Cross Lines
abstract: LEAD: The Comptroller of the Currency in Washington today opened the door for nationally chartered banks in Texas to cross county lines to open branches.

headline: Auto Sales Fall 33.5% In Period
abstract: LEAD: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks declined 33.5 percent in early October, after the end of most of the Big Three auto makers' incentive programs.

headline: INVESTOR PROFILES: Yields Improve the Quality of Life; Saving for Kids And College
abstract: LEAD: IF Steven and Susan Moel's investment strategies work according to plan, their children, 5-year-old Andrew and 2-year-old Erin, will have a substantial financial cushion for college and beyond.

headline: Anheuser's Net Gains by 19.2%
abstract: LEAD: The Anheuser-Busch Companies Inc. said today that its third-quarter profits climbed 19.2 percent because of strong beer sales.

headline: Argentina's Woeful Services
abstract: LEAD: The Argentines may disagree about many things, but there is one opinion almost all share: The quality of public services is wretched.

headline: Contra Aid Flier Suing Company That Hired Him
abstract: LEAD: Eugene Hasenfus, the American whose airplane was shot down over Nicaragua last year on a run to deliver weapons to the contras, has filed a civil lawsuit against the company that employed him for the mission.

headline: Advertising; Transition For Levine And Schmidt
abstract: LEAD: HAROLD LEVINE and Robert H. Schmidt, the disparate pair that have been running Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver since it began with $1.5 million in billings in 1972, have now completed a sort-of second-generation management transition.

headline: Chemical Will Drop 170 in London
abstract: LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off 170 people in London, or 18 percent of its British work force.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  International

headline: Advertising; Stevens & Buchsbaum Takes Cosmetics Client
abstract: LEAD: Stevens & Buchsbaum is celebrating its first anniversary ensconced in former Warwick Advertising space at 875 Third Avenue and billing almost $25 million. Or so they say.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: U.N. Chief Frustrated Over Gulf Peace Effort
abstract: LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is frustrated by Iran's delay in sending an envoy for talks on the Iran-Iraq war but he will continue trying to bring peace to the area, his spokesman said today.

headline: REAGAN ADAMANT IN VOWING TO PUSH MORE CONTRA AID
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would fight for $270 million in renewed aid for the Nicaraguan rebels that would continue until a cease-fire is in place ''and full democracy is established.''

headline: Austria Investigating Iran Arms
abstract: LEAD: Iran has probably obtained 110 heavy Austrian artillery guns destined for Brazil and Libya over the last two years, apparently in violation of Austrian law, the Austrian Foreign Minister said today.

headline: U.S. Sues LTV On Pensions
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Government filed suit against the LTV Corporation Friday in a bid to make the company take responsibility for three pension plans and to assure payment of full benefits to retirees, officials said.

headline: 15-Year-Old Hijacks KLM Plane; Incident Ends With Boy's Capture
abstract: LEAD: An unarmed teen-ager who said he had a bomb hijacked a KLM airliner with 97 people aboard today, forced it to land in Rome and demanded $1 million, airline officials said. The police overpowered him four hours later, and all hostages were released unharmed.

headline: Patents; A Voice Recorder For M.I.T.
abstract: LEAD: THE Massachusetts Institute of Technology received a patent this week for a voice recorder and a synthesizer. Patent No. 4,710,959 was granted to Edward M. Hofstetter, a staff member, and Joel A. Feldman, a former member.

headline: I.B.M. INTRODUCES SYSTEM/36 MODE
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new entry-level model of its System/36 minicomputer line yesterday.

headline: Merrill Lynch Official To Join World Bank
abstract: LEAD: Donald Roth, the chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company's merchant banking subsidiary, yesterday was named vice president and treasurer of the World Bank, one of the most important positions at the giant lending institution.

headline: Sale of Edinburgh Brokerage Is Set
abstract: LEAD: County Natwest Ltd. announced today that it would acquire Wood Mackenzie & Company, an Edinburgh-based brokerage house, in the most significant consolidation move in the British securities industry since the worldwide stock market plunge in October.

headline: 23 in the Foreign Service Fight to Retain Jobs
abstract: LEAD: Twenty-three career Foreign Service officers have filed a grievance with the State Department charging that they are being wrongly forced out of their jobs.

headline: Spain Expels Iranians
abstract: LEAD: Five Iranians were expelled from Spain and put on a plane for Istanbul today after unsuccessfully seeking political asylum. The police said the five Iranians - two women, a man and two children - had been held in custody at Madrid's Barajas Airport since arriving on Wednesday on a flight from Denmark, where their plea for asylum was also rejected.

headline: Salvadoran Human Rights Activist Slain
abstract: LEAD: The president of a Salvadoran human rights commission was killed by two gunmen today as he left home to drive two of his children to school, officials said.

headline: Advertising; Departure at Doremus
abstract: LEAD: G. Barry McMennamin is retiring after 42 years at Doremus & Company, where he has been vice chairman since 1984, and served as president from 1973 to 1984. Mr. McMennamin, 65 years old, has another job lined up. He will be publisher of Worldpaper, a Boston-based monthly publication with a circulation of 650,000 in 22 countries.

headline: 2 Returning Salvador Rebels Make Quick Political Impact
abstract: LEAD: They will not win an election anytime soon. But in their first week home from exile, El Salvador's two top civilian rebel leaders appear to have already had an impact on political thinking here that outweighs their potential showing at the polls.

headline: Ancient Boats Still Ply a Tense Gulf
abstract: LEAD: Visibility in the shipping lanes of the Persian Gulf was dropping in the amber dusk. Suddenly, a young, twangy American voice came over the marine radio: ''Unidentified dhow one mile off my port bow, this is a U.S. Navy warship. State your intentions.'' The admonition was repeated once, then again, and each time the sailor's voice grew more insistent.

headline: Iran Missile Hits A Gulf Tanker Owned in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: An Iranian missile struck an American-owned tanker in Kuwaiti waters today, causing a huge explosion and setting the tanker ablaze, the Pentagon said. But the Reagan Administration ruled out a response because the ship was not flying the American flag and was not in international waters.

headline: The U.N. Today; General Assembly
abstract: LEAD:  ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

headline: Prospects
abstract: LEAD:  Diamonds Still Dazzle

headline: Patents; 2 Nuclear Reactor Devices
abstract: LEAD: Two inventions regarded as useful in nuclear operations were patented this week for the Department of Energy. One automatically shuts down a nuclear reactor if the coolant liquid gets too hot.

headline: Successor to Chief Is Named at Cigna
abstract: LEAD: The Cigna Corporation, a large insurance and financial services company based in Philadelphia, yesterday chose Wilson H. Taylor as the eventual successor to its chairman and chief executive, Robert D. Kilpatrick.

headline: Volcker Plea In GATT Talk
abstract: LEAD: Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the recent dramatic declines in stock markets worldwide showed the need for large countries to better coordinate their economic policies.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Pennbancorp, a Pennsylvania-based bank holding company, to Wyse Advertising, Cleveland, for Gallatin Bank.

headline: Critic Charles Spurs Debate By Londoners
abstract: LEAD: Britain's best-known architecture critic, Prince Charles, has touched off a spirited public debate about modern buildings and royal privilege with a stinging attack this week on property development.

headline: Employee Parties With Less Pizazz
abstract: LEAD: THERE will be no company Christmas parties at Bear Stearns, Shearson Lehman and some other Wall Street houses this year. Still, judging by the volume of corporate bookings reported by hotels and party planners, most organizations will continue to celebrate the holidays.

headline: Commission Windfall Has Worrisome Aspect
abstract: LEAD: For the nation's 70,000 individual stockbrokers, this week's torrent of selling on Wall Street was overwhelmingly disappointing. But there was a silver lining: The selling will generate millions of dollars in additional commission income for the brokers, possibly making this their most profitable week ever.

headline: Patents; System for Helicopters Adds to Torque Control
abstract: LEAD: Helicopters are subject to twisting and turning pressure, called torque, due to rotation of the helicopter blades. A system patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reduces the size and power requirements of anti-torque equipment.

headline: PATENTS; Camera Puts Images On Both Film and Disk
abstract: LEAD: Alfred B. Levine of Chevy Chase, Md., a patent attorney and inventor, has developed a dual electronic camera that takes two images at the same time.

headline: Chrysler to Raise Output and Layoffs
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation announced a cautious first-quarter production schedule today that slightly increases its output of cars and trucks but will raise the number of workers on indefinite layoff in this country by 1,600.

headline: L.F. Rothschild to Cut Jobs and Part of a Unit
abstract: LEAD: L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc. announced yesterday that it would dissolve a large part of one of its divisions and lay off about 700 workers throughout the company within the next three to six months.

headline: Coleman Heads Effort To Rescue Pan Am
abstract: LEAD: With the collapse of an almost yearlong effort by the Pan Am unions to find a buyer for Pan American World Airways, the initiative to find a way to keep the airline operating has fallen largely on the shoulders of William T. Coleman Jr., a member of the Pan Am Corporation's board and noted Washington lawyer.

headline: Coors Biotech
abstract: LEAD: The Coors Biotech Products Company, a division of the Adolph Coors Company of Golden, Colo., said it would form a venture with Meiji Seika Kaisha Ltd., a Tokyo confectionery company. The venture would market a food additive that the Japanese company had developed and sold in its country for more than three years.

headline: Dow Up 6.63; to 1,848.97; Volume Dips
abstract: LEAD: Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday as investors remained cautious about the course of the economy, the dollar and the nation's budget and trade deficits.

headline: Financial Corp. Reports a Loss
abstract: LEAD: The Financial Corporation of America today reported a $75.8 million loss in the third quarter, citing a $70 million addition to reserves for problem loans.

headline: KOREAN STUDENTS READY TO PROTEST
abstract: LEAD: This nation's students, aflame with idealism and self-righteousness, are preparing to move back to center stage.

headline: Mexico Market's Fall Is the Steepest
abstract: LEAD: Throughout the boom months of 1987, the volatile Mexican stock market performed more spectacularly than any other in the world. But with bulls having turned to bears all around the globe, Mexico is now suffering the steepest, most rapid slide of any leading exchange.

headline: Tool Orders Jumped 29% Last Month
abstract: LEAD: Orders for American-made machine tools rebounded significantly in September, rising 29 percent from the previous month's level, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

headline: Pretoria Censors to Let 'Cry Freedom' Be Seen
abstract: LEAD: Government censors today unexpectedly approved the release of Sir Richard Attenborough's movie on South Africa, ''Cry Freedom,'' without any cuts or restrictions.

headline: Pakistan Chief Assails U.S. on Nuclear Stand
abstract: LEAD: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan today accused his American critics of double standards on the question of nuclear nonproliferation, and reiterated that Pakistan is opposed to the production or acquisition of nuclear arms.

headline: Pace of Change Upsets Traditions for Malays
abstract: LEAD: When Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad seeks to justify an unprecedented recent wave of arrests without trial, the closing of newspapers and the banning of public gatherings, he warns of the danger of rising animosity between the Malay people who gave this country its name and the Chinese who have been living among them for generations.

headline: Investors Moving In, Cautiously
abstract: LEAD: With the stability of the stock market still fragile, small investors are acting with caution, choosing to make safe investments or to hold on to what they have, analysts and brokerage officials say.

headline: Panama Orders U.S. Aid Agency Shut
abstract: LEAD: Panama has ordered the United States to close the operations of the Agency for International Development in Panama and is expelling the agency's American employees and their dependents, the State Department said today.

headline: Business and the Law; Compromise Near In Delaware
abstract: LEAD: AFTER more than six months of speculation and debate, a committee of Delaware's bar association is on the verge of approving new rules governing corporate takeovers, lawyers say.

headline: Saudis Seeking an Arab Alliance Against Iran
abstract: LEAD: Saudi Arabia is leading an effort to forge a united Arab front against Iran at an Arab League summit meeting scheduled next month in Amman, Jordan.

headline: ITT Unit Offers Noncallable Notes
abstract: LEAD: ITT Financial, an operating unit of the ITT Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 1/4 percent noncallable notes due in 1992 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's, the notes yield about 87-hundredths of a percentage point more than

headline: Cooper's Lenses
abstract: LEAD: The Cooper Companies said that its Coopervision group had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing the first ultraviolet light-blocking contact lenses in the United States. Cooper, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., has been marketing the Permaflex UV lenses in Canada, West Germany and Britain for the last year.

headline: ECONOMY REPORTED HOLDING UP WELL SINCE STOCK SLIDE
abstract: LEAD: Defying widespread predictions, the economy has held up well since the stock market collapsed in mid-October and an imminent recession appears quite unlikely, private and Government analysts maintain.

headline: Cuts by Hutton In Municipals
abstract: LEAD: E.F. Hutton & Company announced yesterday that it was terminating its municipal bond underwriting and trading operations in five regional offices. Hutton became the latest

headline: Uncertainty of Administration Dollar Goals
abstract: LEAD: The coordinated cuts in European interest rates today could dissuade the markets from pushing the dollar down for a while. Beyond that, the cuts fulfill a major condition that the Reagan Administration had set for doing more on its own to stabilize the dollar.

headline: Tokyo Journal; Like It or Not, Japan Has 20,000 Fugitive Guests
abstract: LEAD: Behind an unvarnished message that Japan is for Japanese, the Government is trying hard to shut the door on unskilled laborers who have flocked here from other Asian countries to find work.

headline: Saatchi and Omnicom Plan Consolidations
abstract: LEAD: Both Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi and America's Omnicom Group have announced a wee bit of consolidation.

headline: Britons Hail a Comeuppance
abstract: LEAD: For the London financial district, the recent slide in stock prices has been a source of understandable distress. But beyond the Victorian palazzos and pin stripes of the City of London, Britain's equivalent of Wall Street, there has been an altogether different - and, in some ways, distinctively English - reaction to the travails of the financial markets.

headline: 2 Promoted At Seafirst
abstract: LEAD: The Seafirst Corporation, the Seattle bank holding unit of the BankAmerica Corporation, said today that its board had named Luke S. Helms president and Roy A. Henderson vice chairman, effective Jan. 1. Seafirst also said that Richard P. Cooley would remain as chairman for approximately three years.

headline: In the War Crimes Archives: Rifts on Prosecutions
abstract: LEAD: A former West German state official and a fugitive former minister of pro-Nazi Slovakia who was admitted to the United States are among 35,000 suspected war criminals named in recently unsealed United Nations files, a first review of the vast archive has disclosed.

headline: Market Place; Cloud Over Avon: Dividend Worries
abstract: LEAD: MENTION Avon Products Inc. and Wall Street professionals immediately think of the $2 annual dividend rate on the common stock that has been paid regularly since 1983. Most analysts believe Avon's dividend is secure for now, but its safety is like a shadow that keeps lingering over the stock.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * AVX Corp., Great Neck, L.I., a maker of multilayer ceramic capacitors, said it had completed the purchase of the multilayer ceramic, glass and tantalum capacitor operations of Corning Glass Works for $66 million. Separately, Corning sold its resistor operations to Vishay Intertechnology Inc. for $37 million.

headline: Young Shoppers
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT RISES 0.2%
abstract: LEAD: The output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, with gains in the steel and energy industries offsetting further declines in automobile production, the Government reported today.

headline: Rates Rise Sharply For Citicorp Paper
abstract: LEAD: The surge in short-term interest rates generally in the past week led to increases of nearly half a percentage point at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday.

headline: HERCULES WINS MARIETTA CONTRACT
abstract: LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation said it would award a contract, expected to exceed $500 million, to the Hercules Aerospace Company for 15 sets of solid rocket motors to power the Titan 4 launching vehicle. The motors will be upgraded to carry a heavier payload.

headline: Bonn Urges U.S. to Cut Its Deficit To Help Stabilize World Markets
abstract: LEAD: A day after West Germany's central bank succumbed to international pressures and lowered interest rates, German and other European officials challenged Washington to make the next move to stabilize world financial markets.

headline: Ruse Journal; In Babel on Danube, All Tongues but One Are Still
abstract: LEAD: The Danube is majestically broad here and its currents are strong as it gathers speed for the final rush into the Black Sea. The river is in the home stretch of its 1,770-mile course, which begins as a rivulet in West Germany and leads through Austria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Yugoslavia before reaching

headline: Plan to Tax Takeovers Is Dropped
abstract: LEAD: Bowing to pressure from Wall Street and the White House and Senate, tax writers from the House of Representatives agreed today to drop all their major proposals aimed at slowing corporate takeover activity.

headline: Monkey Rampage Threatens Soviet Satellite
abstract: LEAD: A monkey aboard a Soviet research satellite is creating such havoc that the mission may have to be aborted, the Soviet news agency Tass said today.

headline: Luanda Aide Asserts South Africa Still Has 3,000 Troops in Angola
abstract: LEAD: A high Angolan official says 3,000 South African soldiers remain in southern Angola after the fiercest fighting in a decade between Angolan troops and South African and guerrilla forces.

headline: Head of OPEC on Tour
abstract: LEAD: Rilwanu Lukman, president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, left today to visit Persian Gulf oil states to bolster support for OPEC price policies. Mr. Lukman, who is also Nigeria's oil minister, told reporters that OPEC members must stay within their production quotas before oil prices can improve.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: Chase Manhattan Bank appointed Thomas C. Lynch and Robert G. Murphy executive vice presidents.

headline: Tokyo Journal; Sweet Dreams of a Home and the Sour Awakening
abstract: LEAD: For more than 25 years, Japanese have talked of ''mai homu,'' an expression adapted from ''my home'' that became a symbol of how far Japan had come from postwar poverty. But because of soaring land prices, young Japanese in the nation's capital have all but given up hope of ever owning a home.

headline: Big Reserves For Taiwan
abstract: LEAD: The foreign-exchange reserves of Taiwan may grow to as much as $90 billion (United States funds) next year, according to economists.

headline: More Killings Laid to Police In Argentina
abstract: LEAD: What the judicial authorities describe as a kidnapping-for-ransom network within the Argentine federal police force has come to light with the discovery in recent days of the bodies of three missing businessmen.

headline: Kleinwort Benson Ltd. Names New Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Kleinwort Benson Ltd., the merchant banking subsidiary of Kleinwort Benson Lonsdale P.L.C., has named David Peake chairman, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Michael Hawkes, 58, who becomes the company's executive deputy chairman. Mr Peake will also become the executive chief chairman of the Kleinwort Benson holding company when Robert Henderson, 70, retires Dec.

headline: Surprise! OS/2 Is Practically Here
abstract: LEAD: THE waiting for OS/2 is almost over. The International Business Machines Corporation announced here on Tuesday that the first version of OS/2, the advanced operating system for the more powerful members of its personal computer family, will be in the stores Dec. 4.

headline: Bombing in Manila
abstract: LEAD: A bomb went off tonight behind the Philippine International Convention Center, where leaders of Southeast Asian nations are to meet from Dec. 14 to 16, the police said. There were no reports of casualties. The police said the blast damaged a fire hydrant and broke the building's windows. Three weeks ago, the police found more than 80 sticks of dynamite inside the building.

headline: Banco de Bilbao
abstract: LEAD: Spain's banking community speculated that Banco de Bilbao might revise its takeover offer for the nation's second-largest bank, Banesto, which Friday rejected its first offer. In announcing that the bid by the smaller bank had been turned down, a spokesman for Banesto, whose formal name is Banco Espanol de Credito, said that the bank was prepared to consider another offer if one were made.

headline: J. P. Morgan Forms Group
abstract: LEAD: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that it had formed a new strategic planning and research group for the entire company and had named Robert G. Engel, currently in charge of corporate finance, to head it.

headline: New Tamil Raids in Sri Lanka
abstract: LEAD: Tamil separatists continued a rampage against majority Sinhalese residents today in attacks that have left more than 2,500 homeless in the last three days.

headline: Investor Buys 7.3% of Showboat
abstract: LEAD: Paul W. Lowden, the investor who controls the Sahara Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev., has purchased 7.3 percent of Showboat Inc. and has said he might seek control of the casino company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Lowden said he planned to discuss the acquisition of Showboat's Las Vegas Casino Hotel and other properties with the company.

headline: Net at Morgan Stanley Jumps
abstract: LEAD: The Morgan Stanley Group Inc. announced yesterday that earnings in the third quarter soared 84.6 percent, on a 53.6 percent increase in total revenues.

headline: G.M. Layoffs
abstract: LEAD: General Motors of Canada Ltd. said it would indefinitely lay off 200 employees at its Windsor transmission plant in January because of declining car sales. The unit also said there would be weeklong layoffs of 3,000 transmission plant workers in December and January.

headline: About Real Estate; In Connecticut, a Home Design Contest
abstract: LEAD: When landowners consider selling tracts near their homes, their business goals may be in conflict with a desire to preserve their environment. Reconciling the conflict may be especially difficult in an area with an unspoiled rural character where most of the residents want it to be retained.

headline: Korea's Growth Survives a Summer of Strikes
abstract: LEAD: Despite ample hand-wringing here last summer about the potential harm created by a surge of labor unrest, South Korea's economy has weathered the crisis with aplomb.

headline: Talley Industries Sets Restructuring
abstract: LEAD: Talley Industries said it plans to sell its apparel and clock-making operations to focus on its aerospace, industrial and real estate businesses. The company said the restructuring would result in an unspecified loss for the year, its first in five years. After a 30-minute halt in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Talley stock rose 87.5 cents to close at $22.625.

headline: U.S. Says It Will Cut Staff in Haiti; Impasse on New Vote Worsens
abstract: LEAD: The United States announced today that it will withdraw all non-essential personnel from Haiti, as signs increased that a political impasse could lead to renewed violence.

headline: Market Place; Stocks Face New Pressures
abstract: LEAD: THE stock market has been no place for the faint of heart lately. Tuesday's unprecedented 91.55-point decline in the Dow is but the latest in a series of wild swings.

headline: U.S. FUNDS SCARCE FOR U.N. AGENCIES
abstract: LEAD: The United States is expected to pay only about 60 per cent of its budget share this year to the 44 United Nations and other international bodies to which it belongs, according to Administration and United Nations officials.

headline: Texaco Spurns Bid By Pennzoil
abstract: LEAD: The Pennzoil Company has proposed a provisional settlement of its longstanding dispute with Texaco Inc., but Texaco yesterday called the amounts involved ''clearly unreasonable.''

headline: The Midnight Side of Wall St.
abstract: LEAD: Past midnight on Wall Street, long after most traders and brokers have gone home, all is calm and quiet, the tension of the working day seeming to dissipate into the cool morning air.

headline: IT'S A BIT LIKE MARRIAGE; Dealing With Your Broker
abstract: LEAD: WALL STREET'S ''Black Monday'' was blacker for some investors than for others, and brokers were partly to blame. In the wake of the stock market collapse, complaints to the Securities and Exchange Commission's Office of Consumer Affairs and Information Services in Washington dramatically increased, according to Bonnie Westbrook, the director.

headline: Bank Merger Approved
abstract: LEAD: The New York State Banking Board has approved a merger of Norstar Bancorp and the Fleet Financial Group of Providence, R.I. The new company, to be called Fleet-Norstar Financial Group Inc., will have $25 billion in assets and will be among the 25 largest bank holding companies in the country. Its headquarters will be in Albany and Providence.

headline: Iran Announcement: Offensive Is Due
abstract: LEAD: The Teheran radio said today that Iran was preparing to mobilize troops for a major new offensive against Iraq, and American and Iraqi officials here said they believed it would begin soon.

headline: London Mourns Fire Victims
abstract: LEAD: The Princess of Wales joined about 400 mourners at a memorial service today for the 31 people killed in a London subway fire on Nov. 18. The ecumenical service was held at St. Pancras Church, a landmark 1820's church a few hundred yards from King's Cross subway station, where the disaster occurred.

headline: ACCOUNTS
abstract: LEAD: *  Brown Egg Council of New England to Theodore J. Charron Advertising.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Michael Zaremba has been elected senior vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago.

headline: Trailmobile to Bid For Fruehauf Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Trailmobile Group of Companies, of Brantford, Ontario, intends to make a tender offer of $39 (Canadian), or about $29.70 (United States), for each of the outstanding shares of Fruehauf Canada, the company said.

headline: Salvador Rebel Arms: Noriega Link?
abstract: LEAD: A former employee of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military leader, has told Congressional investigators that the general authorized arms shipments to the Salvadoran rebels in the early 1980's when the Reagan Administration was trying to keep Nicaragua and other nations from arming them.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Cheryl Lodinger has been promoted to executive vice president at AC&R/ DHB & Bess Advertising.

headline: With South Korea's Stability in Balance, Millions Vote for a New President
abstract: LEAD: With their country's political stability hanging in the balance, millions of South Koreans voted today, their first chance in 16 years to elect a president on their own.

headline: Economic Scene; Japan Will Seek Balanced Growth
abstract: LEAD: JAPAN is starting to rejuggle its economy in an effort to attain faster domestic growth and slower external growth. Prime Minister Noburo Takeshita and his Cabinet accepted a plan yesterday, prepared by the Economic Planning Agency, for transforming the country from a supercompetitive export machine to a more balanced and affluent society ready to play a larger role in stabilizing the world economy.

headline: How Icahn Talked Pennzoil Down a Billion
abstract: LEAD: More than a week and half ago, J. Hugh Liedtke, Pennzoil's chairman, and one of his key trial attorneys, Joseph D. Jamail Jr., flew to New York from Houston to meet with Carl C. Icahn, the investor and owner of Trans World Airlines who had recently become the largest shareholder in Texaco.

headline: TASS SENDS REPORT ON PARTY DISSENT, THEN CANCELS IT
abstract: LEAD: On Saturday evening Soviet newspapers received a report from the press agency Tass that Boris N. Yeltsin, head of the Moscow party organization and a nonvoting member of the Politburo, had threatened to resign at a recent party meeting.

headline: Eagle That Flew to Ireland Will Be Returned to the U.S.
abstract: LEAD: A North American bald eagle that flew across the Atlantic and landed exhausted in Ireland will return home, but not under its own power, officials here say.

headline: SANDINISTAS SEEN AS BADLY EQUIPPED
abstract: LEAD: A Nicaraguan military plan made public by the Defense Department here portrays a haphazardly organized and equipped Sandinista armed force that is short of not only weapons and ammunition but also basics like food, clothing and medicine.

headline: The Treaty at a Glance
abstract: LEAD:  Missiles Eliminated (Articles III, IV and V)

headline: Morgan Reports 3.6% Gain in Profit
abstract: LEAD: J. P. Morgan & Company, helped by declines in its provisions for credit losses and in income taxes, reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings edged up 3.6 percent.

headline: Plea to Business: Don't Dump, Donate
abstract: LEAD: WASTE does not help a company's profit margins - or its image. But in the food industry, where much of the product is fragile and short-lived, waste is an accepted part of doing business. Or at least it was.

headline: The Summit: Missiles and Other Matters; A Scorecard on Weapons
abstract: LEAD:  Arsenals Eliminated in This Pact  Ground-Launched Cruise Missile

headline: Aid to Renault Irks Peugeot
abstract: LEAD: The French Government faced a battle today with the French independent auto maker Peugeot S.A. over a decision to write off nearly a quarter of the debts of Peugeot's state-owned rival, Renault.

headline: PENTAGON PLANS FIRST LASER TEST IN SPACE IN 1990'S
abstract: LEAD: Defense Department officials said today that they planned to conduct the first test of a laser weapon in space in the early 1990's, as part of one of the costliest and probably most disputed experiments in the Reagan Administration's effort to build a defense against nuclear missiles.

headline: Dealer' Inflation Worries Recede
abstract: LEAD: Attention in the bond market shifted last week from the dangers of inflation stemming from a weak dollar to the prospects of low inflation stemming from lower oil prices.

headline: The U.N. Today: Oct. 20, 1987
abstract: LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY  Political and Security Committee

headline: Smaller Trade Gap Seen for September
abstract: LEAD: The trade deficit for September will be announced today, and the amount is likely to be lower, but not by much, than the $15.7 billion deficit for August that helped to set off the stock market collapse last month.

headline: Financiers React to the Plunge - Then and Now
abstract: LEAD: Believing that fundamental conditions of the country are sound and that there is nothing in the business situation to warrant the destruction of values that has taken place on the exchanges during the past week, my son and I have for some days been purchasing sound common stocks. We are continuing and will continue our purchases in substantial amounts at levels which we believe represent sound investment values.

headline: Defense Dept. Aide Calls Defector's Nicaragua Data 'Speculative'
abstract: LEAD: A senior official in the Defense Department acknowledged today that evidence provided by a Sandinista defector of a Nicaraguan plan to invade other nations was ''speculative.''

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * L. (Kay) Schultz was named president of Simmons Major Market Research.

headline: A COUP IS REPORTED IN TUNISIA
abstract: LEAD: President Habib Bourguibia was deposed today by his Prime Minister, Zine el Abidine Ben Ali, who named himself President of the North African nation of 7.4 million, the Tunis radio reported.

headline: Joint Navy Contract Seen
abstract: LEAD: Marconi Communications Ltd., a division of General Electric P.L.C. of Britain, said today that it expects to receive a United States Navy electronics contract worth at least $3 billion in a joint bid arranged with the Rockwell International Corporation of Pittsburgh.

headline: Business and Health; Kaiser Fears AIDS Influx
abstract: LEAD: FOR years Kaiser Permanente has proudly proclaimed that it could supply good medical care at a reasonable rate. Its promotions have been wildly successful, and Kaiser has become by far the nation's largest prepaid-health-care organization, with more than five million members.

headline: Iranian Attack Damages Tanker
abstract: LEAD: An Iranian vessel attacked a loaded Norwegian tanker in the southern Persian Gulf shortly before midnight tonight, starting a fire aboard, maritime executives reported.

headline: China-Australia Project
abstract: LEAD: Australia and China signed a joint-venture agreement today to mine iron ore in Western Australia. The project at Mount Channar, worth $250 million (Australian), or about $170 million (United States), is China's biggest overseas investment, Prime Minister Bob Hawke said after the signing ceremony here.

headline: Kerkorian Pan Am Plan Has Unions in Quandary
abstract: LEAD: It has been almost a year since four unions formed a coalition at Pan American World Airways and hired high-priced investment bankers to help them find an investor who would buy a large stake in the company, bring in new management and give the employees a sizable portion of stock in return for concessions.

headline: Chip Maker's Profits Surge
abstract: LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc., reporting strong orders in both semiconductors and military electronics, said today that its third-quarter profits jumped sharply, to $69.1 million, or 79 cents a share, from $14 million, or 14 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 13 percent, to $1.42 billion, from $1.25 billion.

headline: NATO Ministers Urge Senate to Back Treaty
abstract: LEAD: Western defense ministers urged the Senate today to approve the emerging treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles.

headline: Stalin's Daughter Isn't Moving
abstract: LEAD: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, said today that she had no plans to move to Britain, although she inquired informally about a work permit.

headline: BRITAIN ASSAILED IN COMMONWEALTH
abstract: LEAD: Outbursts by fellow Commonwealth leaders against Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain marked the conclusion today of the 47-nation Commonwealth Conference.

headline: Food Banks
abstract: LEAD:  To the Editor:

headline: Mattel to Make Toys for Disney
abstract: LEAD: Mattel Inc. said today that it would design and make a line of infant and preschool toys for the Walt Disney Company.

headline: Florida Legislators Vote to Repeal Tax on Advertising and Services
abstract: LEAD: The Legislature voted early today to repeal the state's tax on advertising and professional services, and Gov. Bob Martinez indicated he would sign the bill Friday.

headline: Radiation Team Sent to Brazil Saves Two With a New Drug
abstract: LEAD: Members of the international medical team that treated victims of the Chernobyl disaster have spent more than two weeks in Brazil where they used an experimental technique to save two of the most gravely injured victims of a radiation accident.

headline: Italian Policemen Arrested
abstract: LEAD: A prosecutor announced here today that 10 police officers were among 36 people charged with being members of a heroin trafficking ring in the northwestern Veneto region. The prosecutor, Roberto Staffa, identified the ring's leader as Edoardo Ceresi, 25, a brigadier in the paramilitary Caribinieri force.

headline: Lebanon's Militias Providing Social Services
abstract: LEAD: Lebanon's political and religious militias, which after 12 years of civil war have virtually replaced the central Government as the effective authorities in most of the country, have started their own networks of social services ranging from providing textbooks to operating buses.

headline: Kenya-Uganda Accord To Cut Border Forces
abstract: LEAD: Kenya and Uganda agreed today to reduce security forces at their border, a move expected to ease tensions that led to shooting between the East African neighbors two weeks ago.

headline: Army Defector Arrives in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Pvt. Wade E. Roberts, an American soldier who defected to the Soviet Union last April, arrived early today in the United States, where he faces charges of desertion, officials said.

headline: Sri Lanka Emergency Stays
abstract: LEAD: Sri Lanka's Parliament voted today to extend the state of emergency for a further month as Indian troops continued their drive to disarm Tamil guerrillas in northern and eastern areas. Members supported the extension after Acting Parliamentary Affairs Minister M. D. Premaratne said political assassinations were on the increase in the south and rebel violence still flared in Tamil-dominated areas.

headline: Court Upholds Acquittals in Plot on the Pope
abstract: LEAD: An Italian appeals court today confirmed the acquittals of three Turks and three Bulgarians accused of plotting to assassinate Pope John Paul II in 1981.

headline: Upheaval in the Financial World: Baker Talks To Germans About Dollar
abstract: LEAD: Against the backdrop of sinking stock markets and a bitter dispute with West Germany, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d met today with top German economic officials in Frankfurt and, according to a statement from his office, agreed to work with other countries to keep currency rates ''around current levels.

headline: Hanna Nickel to be Sold
abstract: LEAD: The United Consolidated Companies of Fremont, Ohio, plans to buy the Hanna Nickel Smelting Company, reopen its smelter here and produce a steel-making agent instead of mining nickel. United Consolidated has signed a contract with the M.A. Hanna Company of Cleveland to buy Hanna Nickel's assets, most of which will be sold, Bill Niggemeyer, United's president, said last week.

headline: Market Place; Plunge Brings New Favorites
abstract: LEAD: STOCKS that benefit from lower interest rates and slower economic growth have bounced back into favor as a result of the equity market's brutal selloff. Last summer the popularity of these groups - utilities, foods, beverages and tobaccos - began to wane as cyclical issues with prospects of sharper earnings gains took over the leadership on Wall

headline: Heyman May Buy More GAF Shares
abstract: LEAD: Samuel J. Heyman, the chairman of the GAF Corporation, said he might increase his stake in GAF to 15 percent from 10.2 percent.

headline: Money Managers Seek Bargains Amid the Ruins
abstract: LEAD: Money managers who purchased stocks during Monday's debacle and Tuesday's partial recovery snapped up blue-chip issues at bargain prices, thanks to the sharply rebounding market yesterday. One reason for their move back into stocks, these professionals said, was that prices had simply fallen too far too fast.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Mary Kay Founders Acquire New Titles
abstract: LEAD: Richard R. Rogers is moving up to chairman of Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc., the direct-sales cosmetics company he and his mother, Mary Kay Ash, founded in 1963.

headline: Program Trades Spur Index Futures Volume
abstract: LEAD: As stock prices fell sharply, trading was heavy in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index pit today. Some market experts attributed the higher volume to program trading by some institutional investors.

headline: A Mourning Ulster Abstains From Violence
abstract: LEAD: Solemn memorial services replaced demonstrations as the focus of attention here today as Northern Ireland marked the anniversary of a landmark treaty signed two years ago by Britain and Ireland in an effort to bring peace to this troubled province.

headline: Police Scatter Moscow Protesters Denied Permission to Leave Soviet
abstract: LEAD: A swarm of plainclothesmen scattered a small demonstration today by people denied permission to leave the Soviet Union, tearing their placards and roughing up Western television journalists trying to film the event.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Boeing Co., Seattle, has received an order from Canadian Airlines International, which was formed last March with the merger of Pacific Western and Canadian Pacific airlines, for two 767-300 extended-range jets, plus options on eight more, worth a total of $660 million if all the options are exercised.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  COMPANIES  Public Service of New Hampshire moved closer to bankruptcy when its board voted to skip a $37.5 million interest payment due tomorrow. The missed payment will automatically begin a 30-day grace period after which the company could be declared insolvent. Public Service has been driven to the brink of insolvency because of its $2.1 billion investment in the Seabrook nuclear power plant, which may be blocked from opening.

headline: U.S. BLAMED AS CANADA'S STOCKS FALL
abstract: LEAD: Toward the end of trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange last Tuesday, after the market's leading index had fallen 17 percent in two days, a group of battered traders gathered under microphones that carry the hubbub to the visitors' gallery. Amid the din, traders could be heard shouting, ''Vultures, go home!

headline: Economic Spotlight Is on Bonn
abstract: LEAD: Wherever the Germans turn, someone is telling them what to do.

headline: Gorbachev Accuses Former Ally Of Putting Ambition Above Party
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, backing the removal of a former ally as Moscow party chief, accused him of mismanagement and undisciplined behavior, Tass, the official press agency, reported today.

headline: Cadbury Objection
abstract: LEAD: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. said it would reject any request for management involvement from the General Cinema Corporation, a United States company that has more than doubled its stake in the British candy and beverage maker. As yet, it has received no approach from General Cinema, Cadbury said, but it described the share purchase as a highly opportunistic move by an American corporation with a market capitalization little more than half of Cadbury's.

headline: Suspect in Korean Crash Recovers From Poisoning
abstract: LEAD: A woman suspected of involvement in the crash of a Korean jetliner last weekend has recovered from a suicide attempt and was moved today from a hospital here to police custody, the Government said.

headline: Venezuela's View on Oil
abstract: LEAD: Venezuelan President Jaime Lusinchi has said he does not expect world oil prices to collapse, describing their current slide as a passing phenomenon in an unstable, manipulated market.

headline: A MighMy 'Wallflower' at NBC
abstract: LEAD: Were it not for his red ties, Henry S. Kanegsberg could easily disappear in a crowd. Even his employer, the National Broadcasting Company, describes him as ''a wallflower.''

headline: Premier's Party Leads Turkish Vote
abstract: LEAD: For the first time in seven years, Turks voted today in national elections free of military supervision, a poll depicted as reinforcing the revival of democracy.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: Los Angeles County announced plans yesterday to issue $1 billion of short-term securities through various securities dealers, who would then re-invest the money at slightly higher interest rates for the county.

headline: Koreans Find New Freedom For Vote Talk
abstract: LEAD: One flight up from the dusty side street, the clacking of plastic discs could barely be heard over the chatter of politics in Chun Woo Wang's baduk parlor.

headline: Cambodia Is Short of Everything but Vietnamese
abstract: LEAD: Even the weather conspires against the battered nation of Cambodia, which is already short of money, expertise, labor, reliable statistics and communications with the outside world.

headline: Economic Scene; Germans Move, But Cautiously
abstract: LEAD: WEST GERMANY's Government and its central bank, the Bundesbank, are at last moving to stimulate the national economy. But the question remains whether the actions proposed are too little, too late and too grudging to restore confidence that international cooperation can restore stability to exchange rates and prevent a deterioration of the world economy.

headline: U.S. Policy Is Said to Leave Dollar Value to the Markets
abstract: LEAD: Despite last week's cuts in European interest rates and other actions abroad to stabilize currencies, the Reagan Administration is sticking to its new policy of leaving the value of the dollar largely to the judgment of the financial markets, according to Administration officials and Wall Street currency experts.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American General Corp. filed a shelf offering of up to $400 million of debt securities.

headline: Iran and Iraq Report Heavy Fighting in Gulf War
abstract: LEAD: Iran and Iraq both reported heavy fighting today on the south-central front in the Persian Gulf war, but they differed sharply on the outcome.

headline: U.S. WEIGHS EFFECT OF NEW ARMS PACT
abstract: LEAD: The Strategic Air Command is assessing which nuclear weapons could fill the gap in European defenses expected to be opened when intermediate-range missiles are removed under the coming arms agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union.

headline: The U.N. Today: Oct. 7, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: Magazine Conference Under Way in California
abstract: LEAD: The annual American Magazine Conference started yesterday in Palm Desert, Calif., amid the first rain since June.

headline: Court Order for Blinder
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge has ordered Blinder, Robinson & Company to comply by Monday with a Securities and Exchange Commission subpoena for records sought in an investigation of purported stock manipulation. In an opinion issued Nov. 24 but not released until this week, United States District Judge Harold H.

headline: Chile's Leader Takes to Task Foreign Foes
abstract: LEAD: Within Chile's increasingly heated electoral climate, the role of foreign governments, politicians and organizations has become a point of contention between President Augusto Pinochet and his opponents.

headline: Stocks Mixed Amid Rate Worries
abstract: LEAD: Stocks ended mixed yesterday as worry over higher interest rates and inflation erased an early gain on the Dow Jones industrial average.

headline: Big-Ticket Purchasing Seems Steady, for Now
abstract: LEAD: The stock market's historic collapse on Oct. 19 so far appears to have caused barely a ripple in the spending habits of people who like imported cars, exotic vacations and high fashion.

headline: Shamir Has No Regrets on Israel's Iran Arms Role
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that he had no regrets about Israel's involvement in American covert arms sales to Iran.

headline: Paris Sees Market Challenges
abstract: LEAD: Some French stockbrokers are calling it ''our Big Bang,'' while others have dubbed it the ''petit bang.''
